job_title: Senior Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: Oracle has the most outstanding talent that I've worked with.  It is a pleasure to work with such smart and passionate employees. cons: Oracle is full of type-A personalities.  These employees feel passionate, competitive and cut-throat towards their work. Oracle operates like a start-up at every level.  Driven employees are working extremely hard making it possible to lose sight of life outside Oracle.  Again, given the size of the company, there are chances that you might meet a manager that does not exactly see eye to eye with you.  Given that there are no explicit guidelines and training for first level managers, individual experience may vary.

review_title: Great Breadth of Capabilities, Nasty Culture
pros:
Oracle is a force to be reckoned with in the industry.  It has an incredible breadth of product capabilities, a strong installed base and is highly acquisitive - the major source of innovation at the company these days.

The benefits package is good.
cons:
The sales model is fundamentally broken.  A key differentiator is effectively removed by splintering sales coverage down to a salesperson for each individual product area where much of the value is in the combined proposition.  Sales rarely have value-led conversations because they are purely motivated to sell single product areas.

The harsh, macho and aggressive culture means that the wrong people succeed and commercial exploitation of existing contracts prevails which has a knock on effect of losing customers' trust.

Many of the management "fell up the stairs" during the boom years of database expansion and have a unique level of arrogance and misplaced view of their own capabilities.  IQ level is not high in sales but aggression is.

Pay rises are absolutely exceptional once you are in role, so negotiate hard if you are planning to join.

pros: There's a culture of collaboration and skill sharing that can only be called 'generous'; I worked with a lot of very talented and kind people. cons: I really take issue with their claim of interest in one's professional development. Aside from throwing people colorful HR e-mails with links to Oracle University, there was no real effort to cultivate me, and I worked there for 4.5 years with one review, one performance-based raise, and one cost-of-living adjustment. The rhetoric was that there would be a performance review annually, but my team got hot-potatoed around so often that the performance process never stabilized before we got bounced again. Due to execs not really knowing how to compete with established cloud providers, it seemed like there was a lot of flailing around, throwing stuff at the wall to see if it would stick, and when something didn't, it was the frontline folks who got RIF'ed. The way the switch from OPC to OCI was handled was mismanagement, pure and simple.

job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Redwood Shores, CA
pros:
1) The company is all hands to the cloud - and there is more interesting work underway. I meet a lot of veterans here who stuck with the company because of its ever changing landscape - unlike any other companies - oracle owns its stack - top to bottom and you learn a lot from each stack if you are in the right team.
2) Acquisitions doesn't hamper innovation - quite the opposite. You learn so many things from it - and at the some time you get to know how it can be improved, or what to pick from it to improve Oracle's existing process.
3) PLENTY OF TRAINING materials! Be it LVC, On demand or Instructor based - employees get access to those as long as your manager is cool with it.
4) Awesome gym / HQ atmosphere - nothing like it in the bay area
5) Engineering work culture
cons:
1) Internal tools are very old - and it takes so long to see them upgraded. (damn you Iprocure)
2) There is always a question between 'doing it the architecturally correct way' or 'doing it to meet the deadline' - and can be dangerous to find a middle ground for such cases.
3) Some product teams have a weird motto: 'if it works, why bother improving it?' which is one of the reasons Oracle lag behind competitors in terms of simplified interface

review_title: No vision, awful culture, poor compensation, customers hate Oracle
pros: Wide application portfolio which can solve customer problems
cons:
Negotiate hard on salary and the package, because once you're employed, it's not going to be changing. Even moving roles into a more senior position, Oracle will do everything to not pay fairly for the promotion, promising to review it in a year... problem is, the review never comes. 
Although the base of the sales package is competitive, quotas are set such that the vast majority of sales people do not hit quota, and a significant portion won't even hit 50% of the quota. 
Oracle is incredibly inflexible contractually, customers feel trapped and in this age of Cloud, Oracle still rewards its sales people for fixed term committed contracts over pay as you go. This is not customer centric, and customers do not like dealing with Oracle as they have been burned with onerous terms and aggressive sales people
There is very little delegated authority to local offices, it's extremely difficult to do anything agile or innovative when working with customers, even to do PoCs with customers require significant internal justifications and is painful for customers
A lot of backoffice functions have been insourced to lower cost countries, which has created poor and onerous processes for local teams and very poor experiences for Customers around creating contracts and responding to commercial queries
Teams are very siloed, with very little collaboration and often competition across silos when dealing with the same customer. Customers struggle to know who to talk to, and may deal with 10+ different product lines with no overall coordination

review_title: they could care less about you as an employee
pros:
benefits
You can work with some amazingly smart people.
cons:
Teams are global so work/life balance means you should be available whenever they want you. They might not say this out loud, but they say it in their actions if you refuse.
Long term, top-performing employees cut without batting an eye. No opportunities given to transfer because they really could care less about the people.  I was shocked at who they decided to lay off  vs who they kept. They prefer to hire from India so they can pay less and expect them to work at whatever schedule they are given. lots of late evening meetings for them. 
Technology is stale.
Pay could be better
They used to give bonuses, no more.
They used to give raises, hardly ever anymore and if you get one, it's minimal.
They prefer to give stock options instead but then you have to wait 4 yrs for them to vest so they are worthless if you don't stay that long. I prefer my "raise" in the same timeframe I am working in. Oracle is cheap.
Career advancement is really just based on how long you've been there. Performance evals are a waste of time. You self appraise and maybe you have a mgr that actually spends time giving feedback but most of them don't bother because they know it makes no difference.
Not a lot of sense of family/camaraderie among people, you have to really work hard at making friendships and getting to know people outside of work.

review_title: Unless you like the status quo, do NOT work at Oracle
pros: There are great people who are smart and want to do right by the company. And, the pay is great. If you just want to punch a clock and get paid well, this company is for you.
cons: This is an old, institutionalized, uncreative, "that's how we've always done it" company. While the technology may be cutting edge (some would say that's debatable),  if you're looking for an innovative culture that's open to new ideas then stay far away. In addition to being burdened by so much process - there's a complex process for everything there - that holds up speed and time to market, Oracle is swimming in employees with such a long tenure that creativity and new thinking has been stomped out. At least 2-3 times a week, I heard, "thats how we've always done it" or a form of that phrase that dissuaded new thought. And, if there was room for new thought, changing the current process would make it too hard to implement. Again, if you want the status quo, punch the clock, micromanagement, process-oriented lifestyle, then sign up fast. pros:
Oracle is a big name.  It is a respected brand name in the tech sector.  Because it covers so many vertical and horizontal solutions, working at Oracle will enhance your resume.  It is a good stepping stone to launch a career.

There are so many organizations and people within the company that you will find excellent people to learn from.  But, finding these key people is difficult as there are a lot of 'fat' in the company that do nothing productive.

Working at Oracle also makes you become politically savvy as this is the single most important thing to get ahead at Oracle.
cons:
The quality and leadership skill of most middle management is very poor.  It really frustrates me to see these bozos in the position that is well over their heads.  As mentioned before, they are a savvy political players though.  They know who to kiss up and who to attach themselves to.  

Middle managers really don't know how to 'manage', develop and coach employees.  

Consequently, career growth at Oracle is not based on merit.  If you are the smartest person who comes up with the greatest ideas, but are not politically savvy and know how to 'market' your talent, you are not moving up.  Period.  In fact, if you come across as threatening (aka, too smart for the middle managers), you will get buried in a hole.

Due to size of the company the internal bureaucracy can be stifling. review_title: It was the best of times...it was the worst of times...
pros: Fairly decent benefits. Very talented people who persevere despite the bureaucracy and culture.
cons: Unless a member of the "chosen few", raises and bonus have become a thing of the past...not even cost of living increases. Difficult seeing the compensation of the few at the top and the large cash reserves, while experiencing what amounts to a pay cut over the past few years. Total emphasis by senior management on shareholder value and increasing revenue is the recurring theme. Ambitious growth goals, but Oracle arrogance as perceived by the marketplace seems to constantly punish Oracle share price. Internally seems very much a shark tank. Larry likes it that way. Survival of the fittest and all that. The consequence of that culture is the growing silo effect between "clans" and very inconsistent organizational cooperation. Have I mentioned "customers"? Unless one is a consistent  multi-million $$$ "donor", mainstream Oracle just doesn't really care. The smaller organizations that have been swallowed up by the Red Beast still have remnants of those for whom SMB customers do matter, but slowly they are being assimilated into the Borg.

review_title: Oracle can be a great place to work.  However, it is a mixture of well-run and dysfunctional teams; choose wisely.
job_title: Vice President of Business Development & Marketing in Redwood City, CA
pros: Solid company.  Great benefits. Excellent brand recognition.  If you are on a team that is well run and isn't faced with internal competition, you have the potential to work in a very collaborative environment where you will be challenged to contribute your best.  Expectations are high, but the quality of talent around you is also high. The resources and tools around you are top-notch.   You will learn and grow.
cons:
If you are in a group where there is either internal competition (such as multiple groups doing similar jobs) or a lack of a stable history (constant restructurings, name changes or leadership changes) you may be faced with heavy politics, people throwing others under the bus and a constant worrying of whether your job will continue to exist.  

Annual raises have been nonexistent for entire divisions over the last couple of years.  

Many people have left and returned to Oracle because that was the only way they would get their fair market value.  The company has caught on to this and is heavily discouraging that practice. 

A manage-up culture.

pros: If you kill your number you will make decent coin.  Many clients don't like Oracle's culture but it is a necessary evil.
cons: Where to begin?  First off, I believe Larry must have had a bunch of older brothers and grew up impoverished.  Every bit of the culture is set to force almost every pillar against all other pillars in a Darwinistic play that is bordering on insane.  There is absolutely MINIMAL collaboration between license teams.  My middleware team was always ad odds with the tech team.  Plus there are multiple services organizations--and all of them have the exact same message and literally spend all their time just trying to position themselves against their own company.  Why would you have 3-4 circles all completely overlapping in message?  What a waste of overhead!  If this is done simply to try and make the individual reps stronger by spending most of their time infighting, it is a major mistake.  Fire the reps who can't handle the job and get everyone working together.  Skip the viper pit step in the middle.

review_title: A case study for what bad organizations look like

-Terrible culture that stems from uninspiring, ultra-competitive and selfish upper management. You may have already heard about Oracle rigging its accounting for cloud numbers--it's true most of the cloud revenue is done using the 'nuclear tactic' which ends up actually hurting the company because customers will never use our cloud products again after that terrible experience.

-No accountability on several layers. Lead generation team will cheat all its numbers but no one has the incentive to be honest. Huge disparity in incentive and goals between sales team and business development.

- Unreliable. Never pays what it says it will pay, forces you to take vacation to deduct the vacation days on their books, isn't transparent, rarely ever addresses issues brought up from the bottom

-Despite having TWO highest paid CEO's in the country ($50m+ each) overall revenue was down, and the only figures that were up (cloud) were pretty much engineerd and fabricated to show like there was growth but in reality the product sucks and is too expensive so most of the market goes with microsoft, AWS, or open source anyways

-Cut the bonus payout during the most important payout period by 50%, including organizations that outperformed its commitment, then took no action to address the issue professionally or provide an explanation or keep the morale high.

pros:

review_title: Oracle - Could be a lot better
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Burlington, MA
pros: It is a big company and hence there is job security to some extent. Your experience would vary depending on which group you are in.  Some great mentors to work with, from whom you can learn a lot.  There are a few people who make the company worth working for. You will get to work on really large products with enough challenges and opportunities to learn. If the group is flexible, there might be opportunities to try out different roles and see where your true interests are. However,  few groups are open to it, as they would prefer you to continue in your role to avoid potential time delays to product releases.
cons: Each group has its own management/promotion policies. The group I was in did not promote my career growth. For several years there was no raises or bonuses. Be it in technical track or management track the career path is not well defined. Again this was in one group, but I have heard of employees being very happy in other groups. I would strongly recommend talking to more people in the group you are joining before you accept the position. During the interview process, do request for time with the rest of the team and talk to your peers to get a good handle on what the job is about.

review_title: Oracle is a tough place, but it can be rewarding.
job_title: Consulting Account Manager in New York, NY
pros: Oracle is an industry leader.  Because of the company's huge existing license footprint, the access that you get to accounts is impressive.  A lot of senior executives (from customers) will take the time to meet with you if you're from Oracle.  The company pays fairly well.   The power you can harness within the internal network is pretty remarkable.  If you need someone who is an expert on some facet of enterprise software, there is probably someone you can track down internally if you work hard enough.  Also, the caliber of the average Oracle employee is impressive.  You will definitely encounter talented, aggressive people that can teach you something.
cons: Oracle is a very rough environment to work in.  The stress level is constantly high.  There is not a real sense of being collegial.  People are mostly very focused on their self-interests and they need to be in order to stay alive.   There tend to be a lot of emergencies where a situation runs up and down the management chain.  When this happens, life can be difficult.  There is not much of a mentorship culture at Oracle.  There are a lot of processes to follow, so it can be very difficult to get things done, even after you have learned the processes inside and out.

review_title: Oracle India is a good place to work. Growth very difficult
pros:
The best thing about Oracle India is the work culture. 
Flexi timings (decide your own schedule and amount want to spend in office), work from home facility when needed, meetings mostly over the phone and the management is usually supportive about vacations and leaves, but may vary from manager to manager. 
Work and personal life balance is great, and working on weekends is not encouraged or expected here, as it may be many other companies.
Well work and challenges may vary from team to team, but you will surely find a wide range of opportunities to choose from, Oracle being the second largest software product company.
cons:
Promotions and appraisals is not as transparent as you would want it to be. It is usually at the the whim of the manager and compensations might vary widely for the same level.
There is no reverse feedback which sometimes might have a lot of negative implications for a subordinate stuck under a inconsiderate manager.

pros: We were acquired (previously Phase Forward) by Oracle.  By in large, Oracle has left the organization intact.  Bright and talented coworkers.  I'm not sure how the rest of Oracle outside of HSGBU, but everyone is friendly and helpful to one another.  Good benefits:  401K matching up to half of the 6% max, decent health plan, they pay for my mobile service, $5k education reimbursement, quarterly bonuses, free soda/coffee/snacks...  It's a good place to work for a while.
cons: Since we've become Oracle, we've barely received any substantial raises.  I feel as though I'm getting paid less than market.  I know that a recent new hire that I'm training is making more than me.  Long hours and hard work.  Many of former Phase Forward employees were let go or have left on their own and many of the positions were never refilled causing lots more work.    Work/Life balance is not considered with Oracle.  Burning out is very possible.  It is difficult to move up in the company.  Kind of a dull place to work.

pros:
-The top sales representative in Oracle Direct made $400,000 last year.  So the potential to earn huge commission checks is there.
-Job Security is pretty good.  I have never seen any sales reps get fired at Oracle for not hitting their number(s)
-The inside sales organization is growing rapidly which is leading to many management and inside organization openings.  It seems as though Oracle will become an "inside out" organization as opposed to an "outside in" organization which means the inside sales roles are becoming more and more valuable
cons:
-If you get stuck in a bad patch, you cannot leave the position internally for at least 12-18 months. The only way to move internally is to hit your number, which you can't do if you're in a bad patch. It's a catch 22 which forces many people to leave.  In some organizations the patch you are put in is 80%-90% of how well you will do. You have very little leeway to influence some of your patches.
-High turnover.  Many sales reps leave to go to greener pastures aka jobs with higher bases and a better culture
-They are very stingy with raises.  Base is determined on experience alone.

review_title: Customer Experience Service Automation Inside Sales Rep Review
pros: Came in as a class of after graduating college. They had 4 weeks of training in SF which pretty awesome. The name takes you far if you decide to leave oracle and it will get you interviews at a lot of other tech companies. i know people that have left oracle to go to other sales roles, and they are able to make a ton of money in their base salary. they have a solid sales training program.
cons: after being there for two years, it got to a point where i did not enjoy coming to work. to be honest, i didn't enjoy going to work after month 6 of being at oracle. but i wanted to stick it out to get a better territory the second year, which i did. i didn't make money my first year, but i did my second. a lot of it depends on your territory. you can be an A rep but if you were assigned a bad territory, you will have to wait until the year ends typically until you get a decent territory. so some people who are lazy can and will make more money then you. morale is kind of low, very top-down , red tape everywhere management style. it has gotten better where you are able to have a 2-1 mapping (2 territories for the inside sales rep) so it allows for people to make money.

pros: BUPA, reps in the odp team minus management. Can't think of anything else for ODP
cons:
If you are reading this because you are looking to apply for a role. I beg you not to take the offer. These people are inhumane. They will show you dreams that are all lies. They don't care about you. They will hire you because you are an experienced field based sales rep and make you get on the phone like you are an inside sales. Basically you will be getting paid a rep's salary to do an inside sales job.

You will need to make 90 minutes of calls a day and build around $50k worth of pipe every week regardless of how dead your accounts are. The mid market does not want to hear from us, they don't like us. Customers know how we operate and know our tricks. They would rather be with AWS or Microsoft or any other vendor for that matter.

The person tasked to put the tech team together quit after 3 months in. Now that he's leaving, he's been tasked to fire reps left right centre on his way out. He couldn't deal with his boss. No one can. If he can't take it, there is no way you are going to survive here. You are better off at a different company but not at ODP at Oracle. I am already looking around for jobs and will be out of here asap. 

DO NOT TAKE A JOB WITH ODP TECH (IAAS/PAAS).

job_title: Technology Sales Representative in Indianapolis, IN
pros:
The company has an excellent product portfolio.  There is an ever expanding set of products to sell.  Oracle has one of the highest base pay and sales commission plans in the software industry.  Overall, the people are very good, but very stressed as well.  There is a decent amount of opportunity to advance your knowledge of Oracle through internal training.  
Oracle has one of the most liberal expense policies I have ever seen.  If it remotely ties to closing new business, it is expected that it will be paid for by the company.  They also provide a monthly car allowance that is well above average.
cons:
The biggest negative in working for Oracle is the lack of work/life balance.  The mentality in the sales organization is win at all costs.  If you are a total type A, this is the place for you.  I was asked to do things to get commitments from customers that I was not too comfortable with (like waiting outside of people's offices until they leave for the day).

The way that quota is distributed is also a little odd...instead of basing the growth objective on some reality, like the previous year's revenue, the region's quota is equally divided among reps with no consideration for territory, opps, etc.

review_title: Great work-life balance, new technologies, perks and OCH
job_title: Applications Engineer in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: work life balance is amazing. You can crawl, walk, run, whatever you like. Of course, if you work hard you will be rewarded. The HQ campus is amazing, probably the most beautiful of all Bay Area companies. Thy gym is super awesome, and food is top notch. All product development teams have a program for recent college grads called Oracle College Hires (OCH). Free trips to Reno, white water rafting, free lunches, social mixers with all other college hires, wine and beer socials, cruises and crazy events every week! As a college grad, you will know more than a 100 people just like you within the first month. Great program to keep college grads here, amazing perks and something you would never expect at a B2B Enterprise company.
cons: Incremental raises are small. If you want to get a big salary hike, consider switching teams / rolls. Job title and Salaries aren't correlated. The best best to getting a big salary is to leave and join back. Recent hires get a very competitive salary. which is larger than that of people with 3-5 years experience!

pros: I started working when it was still Responsys - sad to see Oracle ruin such a great company. The benefits are good other than dental. I was pleased with the eye care benefits. The people are good (but I am referring to mainly former Responsys employees which are dropping like flies). Nice clients (but that is if you're lucky). Lots of random perks - Passport, My Oracle Perks, and other random discounts.
cons: Oracle treats you like a number and only cares about your impact on the bottom line. Who wants to work for this? No one. It's not bad enough they show no respect to you as a human, you will also not get a raise. And if you are bonus eligible don't expect more than $300. Every single system in Oracle is archaic, slow, and to be blunt - crap. I have seen some of my best coworkers leave this company because there is no future here and your hard work is not appreciated. The company itself is too old school - doesn't support work from home. The random perks they try to flaunt about aren't that special - and sure do not make up for all the downsides Oracle has. In this highly competitive environment Oracle isn't providing ANY reason to stay there.

pros:
- big flexibility - working from home, managing your own working hours, etc
- training - you can sign up for many courses and take full advantage of personal development
- career growth - if you have the right talent Oracle can help you easily transition into a new career direction, new division, get you a great mentor, even relocate you to another country
- benefits - you choose what benefits you need and you can even select to cash your benefits points. 
- due to so many new acquisition you have the chance to constantly develop your experience in any direction you wish to take
cons:

- information overload - so many portals that it is hard to learn where to find what

review_title: Good working environment, flexible work schedules, and an exciting product/service offering that won't have you snoring.
pros: Oracle provides solid benefits.  The work schedule is flexible but can be demanding as we work in a global community.  They are also very good about allowing employees to work from home or remote locations which is at the top of my list of perks.  We have the ability to work with cutting edge technologies and have the resources and economies of scale that come along with working for such a large corporation. There are so many career opportunities available at Oracle that your options are endless. Overall, Oracle provides a good working environment, flexible work schedules, and an exciting product and service offering that won't have you snoring.
cons: HR policies and practices are very dark and secretive...although benefits are solid, salary, bonuses and promotions are not handled properly leaving some disgruntled employees.  Those that do not understand how to manage their own careers are often left in the dust as mentor programs are lacking.  As with most large corporations, being outside of HQ makes it difficult to really climb the corporate ladder. Communication is sporadic with some real gaps as employees are often left in the dark on key initiatives decreasing morale and lack of respect for senior leadership. However,  I would have little to complain about if the HR and compensation practices improved.

review_title: Where marketing careers go to die
job_title: Marketing Director, Corporate Communications in Redwood City, CA
pros: - flexible about work location
cons:
- the culture flows downhill.  so arrogant jerks abound throughout the organization, and the higher you go in the org, the bigger the egos and arrogance level.  
- marketing is not valued by C-level execs
- marketing is based on executive whim and point tactics, with no strategy behind it.
- senior management provides NO direction about goals, expectations, job responsibilities.
- career advancement is almost nonexistent, and based on brown nosing ability, not talent, contribution, delivered results, or demonstrated skills.
- HR openly admits that if you've been at Oracle longer than 3 years, you are compensated under market rate. 
- raises are almost nonexistent, and bonuses are even more scarce, even when the company is making record profits.  ALL raise and bonus pool goes to senior management, with almost NOTHING trickling down below a VP level.
- nasty politics make nice people do weird things, so you can trust no one.
- there are no HR processes in place, so don't expect to have clear goals or measurement, and good luck getting any sort of feedback on performance, annual goals.  
- no training for management, so there are people at upper levels who are bullies and tyrants. And there is no process to provide input about your manager because they don't have a 360 talent review process.

review_title: Lame culture, overbearing manager, and faking phone stats?!
pros: The money was good, when one person on a sales team closed a sale, everyone got paid.  So it was ridiculous (but good for me) that I was getting paid on deals I had no idea even closed.  Was able to easily earn six figures, but most of it came in the summer time, after Oracle's Q4 ends in May.
cons: The management made it unbearable.  There was so much corp red tape, bureaucracy and cronyism it was nuts.  Probably the worst part was the fake phone calls.  Everyone on the sales floor did it too, and even management, who was promoted up from the ranks, knew all the phone stats were fake.  There's no way one person can make 225 calls per week into a limited base of only 15 core companies, but that's what all Oracle Direct (Inside Sales) reps are required to do.  The job is more of a glorified order taking job, rather than a true hunter position.  I finished #2 for FY09, but nonetheless my manager put me on Sales Improvement Plan within weeks of that, simply because my summer pipeline was weak and fake stats were low.  Pathetic management there drives out good talent over cronyism.

review_title: Great place to be a programmer.
job_title: Consulting Member of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros: Oracle has an excellent software development team in the server division. The average quality of the developers is surprisingly high for a mature company of this size. There are a substantial number of world-class people there, although perhaps not in as large a concentration as 10 years ago, due to long-timers retiring and losing a lot of the best young talent to places like Google, but it's still a lot better than Sun was at its peak. The scale of software development at Oracle dwarfs almost anyplace other than Microsoft, and the engineering culture is, to my mind, far superior.
cons: It's a huge company, so it's hard to stand out sometimes. There are politics, but they aren't crippling. I worked at a number of smaller companies, and any of the other places with more than 100 people had worse politics and worse outcomes. While I worked at Oracle, they would have "bake-offs" when there were conflicts about how things should be done, and the best code would win. Being involved in one of these is a lot of pressure, but you can actually win just by doing a good job. You also have to learn to think a little outside the box - but not too far - to make useful contributions, and your boss needs to toot your horn in order for you to be adequately compensated.

review_title: Train yourself, then get chewed out for how you weren't trained
pros: Pros:  Free drinks.  You can probably get time off whenever you need it.  One guy went for "a haircut" for 5 hours!  If you enjoy going to pointless meetings all day and not doing any real work, you are apparently management material at Oracle.  If you enjoy getting a "fun"-sized box of miniature cereal for a Christmas bonus, you'll love it here too.  Certain positions have no accountability or responsibilities, so you might get lucky and get one of those jobs.
cons: Cons:  Our company "merged" (was Borged) with Oracle and everything we were promised before the merger never happened.  Oracle gave no raises to anyone in our facility in 2013 despite the company making billions.  Whatever you were hired at, is probably what you are stuck with, so negotiate a big salary right off the bat.  Oracle loves micromanagers and nitpicking.  Very little training or feedback provided.  Nepotism is rewarded.  They will promise big and deliver nothing.  Laughably outdated software system.  Inflexible, inattentive to innovation.  Your manager will probably take all the credit for your hard work while you just get asked to do even more.  CEO is more interested in racing boats and getting product placement in Iron Man than in spending much-needed money updating decrepit hardware and software.

job_title: Executive Assistant in Redwood City, CA
pros: Met some nice people, WFH option, beautiful campus, cafeterias galore, lots of social/networking events.
cons: This is specific to the org I was in as Oracle is obviously huge and Lines of Business often operate like medium size companies.  There are hardly any women in senior leadership roles.  Attendees at executive meetings are almost always Indian males.  There is a long learning curve and peers are mostly no help.  Executive Assistants are not appreciated for their true value and are just seen as "secretaries" by most.  Think Madmen.  If you are a career EA who likes to get lunches and start conference calls all day long this org is for you!  Basically there is no career path for an EA.  HR is not to be trusted.  There is a culture of fear that starts from the top.  Constant re-orgs and changes all day and all night long.  Employees average a new manager at least once a year.  Politics galore.  Lots of gossip and talking behind backs with the EAs in this group.

pros: Generally very good people to work with. Oracle have ramped up their cloud presence significantly int the past 3 years. There are plenty of resources if you know who to ask or where to find them
cons: There has been significant attrition in local business which continues to spiral out of control given the specialization model that HQ has imposed. Territories and quotas have been significant reduced without any meaningful adjustments to quotas. Given the sheer size and acquisitive nature of the organisation the back-office is extremely difficult to navigate with many different owners across multiple-geographies within a single process. There is little to no collaboration cross line of business which makes it near impossible to present the Oracle story. Finally, the company is totally inflexible around compensation with no CPI adjustments or ability to review pay. Despite good local management they are effectively dis-empowered by a rigid and ruthless HQ when it comes to territory assignment and compensation.

review_title: Systems (former Sun) - Clueless management, unbelievable bureaucracy
job_title: Software Engineer I in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Senior engineers left over from the Sun days are very cool people, and some are famous in Unix lore of old. Good work life balance; few deadlines; flexible hours and working from home.
cons:
I am a "software engineer" and maybe 50% of what I do is idiotic paperwork passed down from endless corporate departments and nontechnical managers and PMs. One coworker says that's closer to 90% of the job.

Management is largely nontechnical and has no idea what is going on at any given time. They don't even know what features are in the product. Your manager's opinion of you will have more to do with your presentation and first impressions than any technical ability or performance.

Raises have been nonexistent for 10 years.

So many coworkers work remotely that those in the office might as well be - there is likely no one relevant to talk to!

In my group, only new grads are hired (no one with experience) and furthermore, there are no technical interviews. So the average engineering talent is dropping. But it might not matter because so much of what we do is paperwork and attend meetings.

review_title: Avoid unless you're related to/good friends with the managers
job_title: Help Desk Analyst in Bucharest, Bucuresti
pros:
Stable working environment
Some good quality people
One of the best medical plans
Over Time is payed accordingly (200%)
cons:
Horrible work/life balance.
Late shifts end at midnight.
Apart from December 25th there is no guaranteed holiday, you have to work during weekends and bank holidays.
Zero promotions unless you're good friends with the managers.
Also if you don't continuously flatter your managers, there is no room for empathy, they are also very VERY suspicious and will micromanage everything 
Zero training opportunities.
"There is no budget" is every manager's catch phrase. 
This is a company that hires lots of people based on the family ties/close relationships with management, needless to say that many new hires have close to no skills whatsoever.
In some departments/LOBs, Oracle lost 75% of their existing clients because the organization delivered poor quality technical support. 
Working staff members (usually veterans) are treated like disposable material (in hope that they quit) and are forced to work extra whereas a person who is a close friend of the manager doesn't have to work at all - if you make the mistake of bringing this up in a 1-2-1 meeting you're marked as an enemy and the subject is quickly disregarded: "right now we're not talking about X does and doesn't do, we're talking about you".
You are encouraged to leave if you don't like it there but internal transfers are impossible (unless you're friends with the hiring manager of course).  
Upper management (VPs and up) lie to your face as often as they can.
Satellite teams are often arrogant and don't share any knowledge.

review_title: Really wanted to like this company......
pros:
Pros:
*  Health insurance benefit options are great and low cost compared to a lot of other companies  -  I have been really happy with the insurance
*  Flexibility if you are allowed to take advantage of it -  a lot of people work from home/remotely, but my understanding is that the company wants to move away from that more these days
*  Winter Break -  The company shuts down from Christmas to New Year's -  it is really nice to have a real break without any expectation of getting work done.  Very rare
cons:
Cons:  There are so many -  I will try to keep the list short:
*  The pace if you work in Sales or support Sales.  It is unbelievable.  Everything is micromanaged and every week is busy  -  there are no slow weeks at this company
*  The shockingly terrible lack of better internal systems/automated processes considering the products that this company sells.  All of my deliverables are manual and I do not have direct access to data -  I always have to rely on another group to send me data
*  The disappointing alpha male mentality in Sales/supporting Sales.  It is 2018, not 1990 -  the environment needs to be more balanced and less frat boy-like

pros: Oracle's recruitment team must be fairly talented as many of my initial coworkers were smart, fun, hardworking people. Networking opportunities are great. If you get your work done, most managers are truly flexible with your hours, which isn't as common as you would think in the Bay Area.
cons: The attrition rate for recent college grads hovered above 70% at the one year mark for many of the sales teams during my tenure. Although the recruiters were bringing in good people, those same people were very likely to quickly leave. A lot of the unhappiness stemmed directly from a lack of transparency in the compensation structure. The base salary was simply not enough to live in the Bay Area, and very often folks "hit their number" but were not paid out anywhere near what has been indicated to them by their managers. There were huge discrepancies in expected bonus versus what was actually received. A great example: one quarter the product we "sold" hit a development roadblock on the engineering side and failed to ship causing my entire team to lose their sales commissions. This meant we had to attempt to live half a year on a virtually unlivable salary, with the possibility of the same scenario repeating. Most of my team left after that.

Engineers have quite large workloads and many are complaining, but this situation is in accordance with the company policy, judging by the lack of headcount increase in the teams where workload has been a challenge for quite a while.

pros:
Human Capital Management - world class, highly transparent and friendly. They teach you that your Manager is your HR Manager to make fully immersed in the teamwork environment and cultivate strong bond with the team. But when it comes to heart talk and contingencies you can fully confine in your HR and they make you feel taken care of like at home.
I have loved working for Oracle as a worthy employer - the first and greatest reason for that is my on-boarding process at Oracle, they rare and enlightening meetings with HR and the grace with which they bid adieu to you. It was unique when I was walking out of their doors I had a proud feeling of trust and shared values that were saying to me that I will never mind coming back to this employer or enabling a 100 more people join them for a meaningful workplace experience.
cons: Management needs to grow up to their highly qualified talent's career expectations. Need to be more open and liberal to embrace individual aspirations. Good thing is that Oracle as a giant and well structured organization has a broad scope for allowing horizontal movements and often times it is more about lateral moves than about the vertical progression. The HR is cognizant of the advantages of letting employees thrive on opportunities, however the management creates undue barriers.

pros: Oracle is definitely a place where the strong will survive. Everything pretty much is self service which means don't expect your manager to hold your hand thru the on boarding process. If you need something you can order it thru the self service app and there is usually no major restrictions. Benefits are pretty good and health insurance is really cheap. The healthcare is provided thru UnitedHealthcare which I am sure is fine (I personally don't like them) but you can also choose Kaiser. Oracle has a tuition reimbursement of around $6,000.00 and 6% 401k match which is also good. Salaries are good, but make sure you negotiate hard before you join (they expect you to) You can work from home whenever you want and your managers are pretty supportive overall. The culture to over perform is definitely there and the company itself is going thru a huge shift.
cons: The number of systems you have to navigate thru to get things done really makes doing things difficult and everything pretty much works thru an elaborate workflow. I have heard rumors that Oracle does not offer raises in salary but I have not seen that yet. I think it all depends on who your managers are.

review_title: Oracle is not as good as it seems.
job_title: Senior QA Analyst  in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Good compensation package and Oracle has a good name recognition.
cons: My immediate manage and director do not respect the people who work for them.  They are not willing to take advice and other's opinions.  It is like a dictatorship.  The group that I work in desperately needs more people but for some reason, we are unable to get more people.  This problem has existed for over two years now.  Because of the lack of people, we have to do extra work.  When some of us complained about the extra work, we were lectured on and giving a bad rating on our performance review stating that we are complainers.  Furthermore, we got punished with the bonus even though our group made money.  In addition, when I wanted to take a vacation for more than a week, I was given a hard time and my manager actually told me to try to delay my vacation or cut it short.  This is fine if we were in a crunch time but we weren't.  After I refused to delay my vacation or cut it short, I was told to bring my laptop on my vacation and leave my cell phone number with my manager.

review_title: Working for Oracle is a mixed bag
pros: Ability to be involved with the latest technology and having the status of working for a large and fairly well respected technology company.   Flexibility to work from home and not a lot of micro-management.  The health benefits are also very good.
cons:
Overall, morale is pretty low due to the fact that raises and bonuses across the board are almost non-existent.  People always complain to each other under their breath, even though they put on a smile in front of management.  The only way to get a raise is to quit and re-negotiate when you come back.  You might get a .7-1% raise every 3-4 years, if you are lucky or someone quits above you and you can take their job.

The people that stay tend do do so because they really like what they are doing, even if they won't get any real financial rewards, because promotions are also something that are EXTREMELY rare unless it is to fill a position that someone left.

review_title: Great place to work; slow promotion
job_title: Senior Director of Engineering in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Very smart people. Lots of support for new ideas. Beauracracy is manageable, not onerous. Interesting projects to work on and you can have a big impact on revenue. Actual utilization of your software is quite low; enterprise software - including cloud - requires a lot of integration and configuration, which takes customers a long time to do, because they often rely on consultants. Easy to form strong relationships, and you can have an outsize impact if you bring energy to the position. If you are a *technical* manager you can be very successful. If you are just a manager-manager, your progress will be limited.
cons: For better or worse, literally every small detail - down to the smallest purchase - must be approved by the president, which means you often have to present status and progress to the president multiple times during development. Projects aren't "approved", but rather "approved for now with further reviews at regular intervals where your project may be summarily cancelled if you don't demonstrate a good plan".

review_title: Oracle Marketing Cloud - startup within an enterprise
job_title: Principal Sales Consultant in London, England
pros: The oracle marketing cloud is one of the most exciting and challenging areas of oracle to work in. There is ongoing and heavy investment in the product. Oracle is a great place to be an "intra-preneur". That being said this culture is not for everyone. working from home is almost the standard at oracle which lends itself to a great work life balance. Oracle have a flexible benefits scheme in UK which is fantastic as it essentially gives you a 10% boost to your salary providing you choose to take the benefits as cash which is obviously not the most tax efficient way to use the benefit but helpful nonetheless.
cons: It is difficult to obtain a pay rise at oracle. There are numerous cloak and dagger tactics used by management and the feeling is that they don't want to reward loyalty and achievement. it is widely accepted by employees across sales and presales that an offer from a competitor is one of the only ways to go about getting fair reward for your efforts.

job_title: Oracle Direct Sales Account Manager in Austin, TX
pros: I learned a ton about enterprise computing, data centers, applications, middleware, and how everything fits together.  It's all very cool and high level stuff that runs the modern world.
cons:
I had an inexperienced manager, who gave very little direction on how to run day to day business. Basically it's sink or swim at Oracle - the training is not comprehensive enough to help you succeed.   Oracle provides you with all the things you need to run a business, but no direction or guidance. 
Cold calling the same account list every week gets old very fast and customers hate it.  
Turnover is high as people get burned out from the grind.  The environment is stressful as management is intimidating and not willing to provide structured feedback or coaching.
Ultimately your territory dictates your ability to hit your quota. If you have oil and gas industry when oil prices are at their lowest price in 10 years, and your accounts are going bankrupt - your not going to hit.

review_title: Maybe too big a company to work for
job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros: Good work-life balance. Lots of vacation days, lots of floating holidays, and excellent benefits. Reasonable in granting flexibility in working hours. Working from home is usually not a problem. Food is available on-site and parking is plentiful. Peers are intelligent and respectful. So the day-to-day operational aspects of working there are pretty painless. Perform your job diligently and you'll be rewarded with job security and no intrusions on after hours life. Plenty of opportunities for training here to help you acquire new skills or improve the ones you have with supportive management that doesn't see it as stealing corporate time.
cons: Too big a company. News from top management takes a long time to filter down to the rank-and-file. Large size also hinders basic operational procedures like procuring a computer or requesting reimbursements of business expenses. Most often, too difficult to gauge the impact one has on the company. And too often, business aims of groups are not aligned with each other, thus creating in-house competition and redundant work. Perhaps management does this deliberately, but probably just a result of division heads carving out their fiefdoms and doing their best to survive and succeed. As a result, whole teams can be redirected at entirely new tasks with all produced work going to waste.

job_title: Principal Technical Support Engineer in Amsterdam
pros:
The name is great for your resumé. Whenever you hear Oracle in the IT world you know you are working for one of the greatest in the industry. 

They promote working from home, which is great to balance your personal- and worklife. Remote management is in this case a great pro; no-one breathing down your neck.
cons:
But that is about it. The company is a factory and you are nothing more than a number to them. Support is outsourced to Romania or India/China, which means you get made redundant after 9+ years experience. You get a laughable amount of money to get lost; preferrably as soon as possible.

There is no room for promotion and even if you do get a promotion; it does not warrant any payrise whatsoever. Nor do any yearly reviews (I had 9 years of straight 5/5 reviews, but got nada. Not even a pat on the shoulder)

New hires get hired with nearly 50% more pay without any (relevant) work experience and you are required to share all you knowledge (only to get replaced after that)

If you want to make your resumé look pretty; make sure you get in high and only stay for a year or 2 to 3 and then leave before your soul gets sucked out of your miserable worklife.

review_title: The Song (and comp.) Remains the Same

I read another comment several years ago that was spot on (and mystifying): I moved from one org to another over a year ago, with the new position listing a "higher" level of experience and presumably, comp. When I was hired at the new (now current) position I was told that my level and comp would remain the same-yes I was qualified for this position (or they wouldn't have hired me) but "policy" stated that I had to work in the new job for a year before any discussion of a bump, even though my new position was at a higher level. After a year so far? My Manager and Director have made it clear that I'm still in the learning phase and so no go.

job_title: Technical Support Operations Engineer in Bozeman, MT
pros:
Oracle is huge, and this review system doesn't seem to allow you to categorize your employment within a big company as well as it should.

Anyways, I worked in the Technical Support department for Oracle RightNow, which is a software company recently acquired by Oracle that makes a CRM solution. Over the year and a half that I was there, I worked in two different roles: as a technical support agent specialized in the customizable aspects of the product and as a developer resource for the department. I gained a lot of experience and insight into how "truly technical" technical support is actually done. As a developer resource, I got to do some C# and web development, which I enjoyed. I also enjoyed working with my coworkers and made some good friends.
cons: My management left something to be desired. There was a lot of reacting to stuff happening or that was going to happen, rather than creating carefully thought out plans for improvement. Priorities were constantly shifting at times. Also, technical debt was stark reality, and not enough thought or effort was being put into eliminating it. A lot of times we, the developer resources for the department, were victims of the fragility of a massively complex system that had grown out of control.

pros: Strong financials, great reputation in industry, tremendous market share. When you work in field sales at Oracle the company name is a positive in many situations, but can also be a negative. The biggest pro is the sheer market share and presence. In my near five years at Oracle I've never called on a company that hadn't heard of Oracle. By in large, Oracle builds great products and has strong executive management. Compensation is very strong. You can make big money as a field rep at Oracle.
cons: With so many products I sometimes question whether or not Oracle is truly great at any individual thing due to the fact they have to focus on so many lines of business and products. Additionally, you will run into a large number of customers that have a negative bias towards Oracle and will not listen to you with an open mind. Finally, Oracle has gone through an amazing amount of hiring over the past few years, which has just added to the sheer amount of noise that many executives hear from Oracle. It's not uncommon to have as many as 25 reps calling on a single account in the Enterprise space.

cons: Your success will be based on three buckets.  Territory, Timing, and Talent..   In that order!  Most selling in Oracle Direct is tactical and transnational.  Not to many value selling opportunities.   Lots of turnover at all levels.  If you blow it out one year comp plan will adjust..  You will not beat the house twice...

review_title: Just get a couple of years with this company on your resume....and LEAVE! Cash in on the brand name.
pros:
- Free soft drinks / biscuits / tea / coffee
- Good work-life balance
- No real limit on printer use. I have seen people printing out textbooks. so yeah.
- Bi-annual company functions (which used to happen yearly by the way) are good. Credit where its due.
- If you are lucky, you get WFH option. Depends on your manager really.
- Work pressure is manageable. Not too stressful. Again, this depends on what kind of a manager you report to.
cons:
- Horrible cafeterias with the worst possible food
- No professional growth (promotions? forget about it!)
- No salary hikes. Bonuses, you ask? What's that?
- Some of the most unethical and incompetent managers i have ever seen in my professional career. Don't let the brand name fool you. This is a company built by acquiring other companies ever since it's birth. They've retained a lot of the garbage along with those acquisitions.
- Bureaucracy (It's not what you know, it's who you know. You could be a top-performer but still rot in this company if you aren't sucking up to the manager and his cronies.)
- HR is non-existent.

pros:
1) There is a lot of freedom when it comes to internet usage within office hours. Be it youtube or hotstar, etc.
2) Work from home is always an option. Very easy going life, nothing hectic. 
3) You may get to learn a lot initially if you get a decent project as the timelines are not that stringent so one can always explore a lot on his/her own.
cons:
1) There is hardly any growth whether it is salary or designation. 
2) No activities from the HR department to keep the atmosphere lively. Have never seen any cultural festival being organized.
3) If you are looking for good career growth with challenging work then this is the not the right workplace for you.
4) The technologies being used in the product unit that I am a part of are really outdated and few teams look adamant not to use something as popular as Spring and Hibernate.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Reston, VA
pros:
Oracle has some of the most brilliant people I've ever worked with and an excellent working environment. It's not as sexy as Google or Facebook, but we are working on cutting edge stuff and I feel like the people I work with are some of the smartest in the field. Many of us have turned down or left jobs at the big Silicon Valley places because we didn't want to live on the west coast or do government crap. I still feel like I have a ton of stuff to learn and there are a ton of cool new things on the horizon to build. I've peeked around at the other top places in the area and none have impressed me or offered me anything I don't have right now. 

One uniquely nice thing about Oracle is that when people say cool stuff is going to happen "in a few months" it actually does happen in a few months. I feel like our upper management is really advocating for us.
cons: Oracle Cloud sucks and we're obviously stuck with it, the legal department is pretty much a waste of air and water but what legal department isn't

pros:
- Good compensation specifically their health benefit that covers both you and your immediate family (parents, siblings, children). This is my topmost reason why I stay
- Semi-flexible hours but it depends on the project
- Offers lots of training
- Quarterly/annual free movie nights
- Free coffee, free snacks in the pantry
- Quarterly bonuses
- Basically Oracle Taguig offers a lot of tangible benefits
- Overall stability of the company. Working here pays the bills.
cons:
- Too much red tape
- If you're a hardcore programmer, Oracle may not be the perfect workplace for you as your skills will be limited to only one product. 
- Oracle trains you with a skill set that only a few companies would hire for.
- There's this manager that's toxic to work with and I'm not the only testimony to that, as he has been reportedly one of the reasons why a lot of people resigned - but management keeps him around because he's undeniably one of the company's talents.

pros: Good company with good benefits
cons: Too big and very hierarchical

review_title: A good place to learn new things but has some down sides.
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros:
1) There are some very smart people working at Oracle.They have been there for a very ling time. During a project,  you can learn a lot just by talking to the senior people who help you with your project.

2) Oracled database is a challenging product to work on. Kernel code has been there since 80s and one of Oracle's best success has been to keep this code pretty stable. Just browsing thorugh the code helps one build on his intellectual capital. Getting involved in some projects for Oracle's database related products is a great plus.

3) Oracle management is pretty OK with working from home. You can have a flexible schedule as long as you get the work done.

4) benefits at Oracle are OK.
cons:
1)In some groups,  work is not allocated fairly. I know some people who have been at Oracle for a while but who have not done any major work.

2) Some people at  management can be rude at times.

3) If you recently entered Oracle, then there is not much chance of a career growth simply because there are too many people ahead of you.

pros: Company that very thoroughly checks their balance sheets and knows how to wiesly invest their money for preservation and growth.   They have strong history of making strategically sound acquistions which allow them to expand to new markets.  They offer comprehensive benefits including stock options and bonus for salaried employees.  Hourly workers get handsome overtime compensation for their extra hours. 401k matching for everyone.  Standard offerings for dental, eye and healthcare.  Most positions have some flexibility to work from home periodically.    Most of their locations boast gourmet cafeteria and world-class fitness facilities.
cons:
New Employees through acquisition get fulltime postions but are NOT informed whether their new position is "transitional" (ie temp).  If employeed here via acquisition, Generally a good idea to look for work while being employeed here rather than settle in and buy that new car you always wanted.   There's no barometer for when reductions in force are made.  They will be done quietly and quickly.  Some departments are total sweat shops particularly those that are considered cost centers. 
Oracle loves to follow any hip new trend in 'in-sourcing' to bring in cheaper talent and save where possible.  They are very excited about their expansions in Mexico and overseas.

pros: Oracle has a great name to put on your resume - it is well known and respected and has great benefits. It gives you a great look into what it is like to work at a large company in a large sales division.
cons:
Working at Oracle was not one of the best professional experiences I've had. Success at Oracle is not determined by work ethic, effort, or intelligence. In sales, it is the luck of your territory and your product. You see people "succeed" that have little to no work experience, and making minimal effort. The culture I experienced there was also less than positive.

This is not to take away from the people that do succeed and work hard (which is abundant there as well). I made lots of great relationships with people that inspired me to be my best professional self. However, many of those in upper management have gained their titles solely because of their "luck" and have been promoted despite their lack of morality and professionalism.

It was difficult to grow personally and professionally there, and I do not recommend working in the sales division if you want professional freedom, a good culture surrounding you, or the ability to grow your skills and career.

review_title: Business Development Consultant-- Public Sector, Reston
job_title: Business Development Consultant in Reston, VA
pros:
1) Easy job, with lax environment (depending on manager you get to come to work and leave pretty much whenever you want as long as you are hitting your number)
2) Pay is respectable for the amount of work put in
3) Benefits are grade A, especially the 401k match
cons:
1) culture is completely convoluted and political with upper management having NO idea or CARE for what happens at our grunt level
2) Bonuses are COMPLETELY MADE UP in terms of how much you get paid for the amount of performance you attain-- I was a top performer for Q4 (which is Oracle's best selling period) and got paid HALF of what I was expecting-- all due to "performance was lacking in other areas of the business)-- complete BS excuse.
3) work is often extremely boring and monotonous with no critical thinking skills needed
4) No real investment in terms our organization and we are viewed as useless by the more senior sales representatives that we are supposed to help.

review_title: Where Do I Begin?  - Rant From A Senior Employee
job_title: Senior Designer in Redwood City, CA
pros: The benefits are good...I guess.
cons:
I'm going to be upfront and it may sting but whatever.  This is the most dinosauric, backwards-thinking company Ive had the displeasure of working for.  I've applied myself for 6 years and NEVER received a promotion or any type of advancement.  Just pointless reprimands for the most asinine crap like "attendance issues" despite my flawless track record of submitting my work on time.  Yeah, who cares if the Senior Designer has never missed a deadline, so lets lecture him like a high school student cause he wasn't in his seat at a certain time.  Well how about working remote?  Or sorry, you can only do that for ONE day a week and its only when we say you can due to....reasons.  

Lets shovel more repetitive assignments that require zero effort.  Since we're devoid of creativity, lets force obsolescent design trends cause its easier to produce.  It's like these people are stuck 10 years in the past and refuse to evolve with modern industries.  Pitching ideas are constantly rejected in favor of something mediocre to hide imperfections.  Hire ups playing favoritism with others, management being stuck in outdated business cultures.  Constant stubbornness to innovate.  No vacation time permitted in the summer.  WTF?!  How this place still exists is beyond me.

pros: Amazing Healthcare Benefits, Great Colleagues, Can be lucrative (but rarely feels ethical)
cons:
- Serious support issues that give us a terrible reputation with our customers
- Hard to get hired elsewhere once this company has been on your resume for a while because everyone else in the industry is aware of the shady dealings Oracle undertakes
- Difficult to get paid on work you've done (company will implement new policies at random and claim you are no longer eligible)
- Your success depends highly on the territory you are assigned and the manager you work  for. The company makes it difficult to get anything done internally.
- The applications used internally are outdated and buggy. Leadership insists on adoption even though the tools are incredibly slow.
- Leadership is disconnected and focused on the wrong things. Wants to see shifts in the business model but doesnt offer proper guidance to make that happen.
