review_title: Managers with poor skills, No policy of yearly hike
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Gāndhīnagar, Gujarat
pros: Flexible working hours, Work from Home benefits, Good work life balance.
cons:
No proper project planning from Management. 

Layoffs.

There is no policy of yearly hike. So even if you have worked really good, there are chances you might not get a hike and if you get a hike it may take more than 1 year to see the salary change. Last time there was a hike after 1.5 years and that too not everyone was considered (event top rating guy wasn't given HIKE.)

Recent major changes in Upper Management impacted a lot on Product planning. This left middle managers in tricky situations as they have no experience of how to handle this added responsibility.

No forum to raise concern of our managers to higher management. They have a very poor way to speaking with employees.

Too much bias. People who have lunch and spend time with managers are in their good books. They are given faster promotions and more hike, even though others are doing better work.

job_title: Customer Success Manager in Boston, MA
pros: Oracle's a huge company - lots of good benefits and flexibility.  Tons of self-service training (both a pro and a con).
cons:
Complete lack of understanding their clients needs.  Complete lack of employee success.  No raises EVER even after 2+ years!  And in comparison to competitor companies, CSM Pay was FAR BELOW the national average (by tens of thousands of dollars).   Inconsistent bonus structure hidden behind a secret metric that's not released to the pleebs below management.  

Company's customer success efforts were completely derailed into a FAILING model.  Company thought a pivot to KPI's would be important to customers, but in reality, those customer just wanted stable environments and someone to listen to them.  

CSMs were told to go out and take a ton of learning and training to get "Certified" as most CSMs never had access to training on the products they were managing.  But it was mostly too little too late.

review_title: Good work-life balance; Internal Politics will make your job 500% harder
pros:
Management stays engaged
Good managers will fight for you
Considerable Remote workforce gives flexibility 
Average tenure is high in certain areas because of the decent work-life balance
cons:
* Tension between Field and Inside Sales orgs
* Internal politics slows deals and momentum. ex: you offer customers will take ages to get approved
* Tribal knowledge is key; you must know the right people to get answers to questions
* Competing priorities by teams; renewals / sales are compensated to be against each other
* Internal tools often buggy
* Aging management has old school mentality, ex: still believes in hub-model with butts in seat 
* Management hounds reps to make cold-calls daily to prospects/customers in the Enterprise space (cold-calls don't work anymore)
* You will be tracked on every metric. They fire the highest earners, so beware of hitting your quota for the year or you'll be the next one on the chopping block (C suite makes financial decisions, not smart business decisions)

job_title: Technical Support Engineer in Jack, AL
pros: no salary increases, no bonuses,
cons: very bad management, a lot of office politics. A 'you scratch my back and I'll scratch yours' attitude between managers in the detriment of the employees

review_title: Not a good place to work in at a low level (probably better if you're in upper-tier management position)
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
World-class products to sell, that's a lot when you are a sales person
Clearly a resume builder 
The strategy and vision of the market is impressive in many ways
Sales training is probably the best you can have out there
Some Perks
cons:
Bureaucracy :  you spend less than 15% of your time actually selling
Countless efforts to actually get anything done internally
Politics, politics and  more politics
Your promotion depends on who you know, not who you are or what you do. 
Little support from middle management
If you can't handle the constant pressure on numbers, find another company to work for
In a nutshell, if you're not a self-starter, with a clear vision of your career path, able to handle the pressure don't work here

job_title: Applications Sales Manager in Burlington, MA
pros:
*Strong brand recognition.  
*Strong products to position.  
*Decent compensation.  
*Plenty of room to grow if you're willing to hustle.  
*Great training. Training has significantly improved over the past 5 years.
*As soon as Oracle is on your resume prepare to be hounded by recruiters.
cons:
A lot of college hires mixed with professional hires which can be off putting to those with a lot of experience.

High stress.  If you're assigned a tough patch it's likely you won't hit your OTE (especially in year 1).  Rising in the company is extremely difficult if you do not hit quota.

Territory - like most companies - is luck of the draw.

pros: Flexibility, travel, high commission rate, you can get very lucky and make a lot of money for nothing (bluebirds),
cons: Lack of transparency, nepotism, incredible lack of organisation at times, it can be like the blind leading the blind, always problems with account alignment, if you get the wrong product it will be impossible to sell, still using excel sheets to profile, account managers still do most of their own business development work, marketing is drastically under funded and generally useless, using old version of CRM that works horribly, extremely complex processes, the hardest part of the sales cycle is generating the OD for the customer, it can take months, canteen food can be brutal, also is not free.

review_title: Nice Place but full of Politics
pros:
There are many good things about this company.
- The management is supportive and listens to your stuff however that depends.
- You get the option of work from home when there is a need.
- Work quality is good however that depends upon the project and team.
- Good Laptops and Cab facility is there.
- Office Location is Good.
cons:
- You work for 12 hours a day and make a mistake and your head is on the knife rather you will be safe if you are safe if you work less and do politics.
- Few times you feel that you have too many managers that you report and work for.
- There is less opportunities to travel abroad or onsite.
- There are few employees who does not work at all and you if complain to the management, no action is taken.
- Very less appraisals.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Redwood City, CA
pros: Remote work, Corporate policies against harassment/ intimidation etc.
cons: Unless you are an executive level employee, you are treated only as a number. Your vacation is easily absorbed into working hours. You will lose your health within 2 to 3 years. You will not get any promotion no matter how long and how well you work here. You will not get any raise with the exception of a minimal/ negligible one - may be once in your tenure here. Business priority stays alive half the year without a fail (half of every revenue quarter) and during that time, you are a slave. Your time is Oracle's time and your life is Oracle's during that timeframe. You will get hired for lower than the market going rate. You fall for the brand name. And then you are consistently expected to work overtime or get fired Legally.

review_title: Big Company, Good Pay, Zero Creativity and Vision
pros: My immediate team is awesome, my current manager is awesome and the awesomeness stops there.
cons:
Upper management lacks vision and strategy, and it appears they are more interested in acquiring customers via acquisition than in real product research and development. As it stands providing value to their customers is an afterthought. 

Larry Elision has tuned out and all management does now is buy companies, stitch together Frankensteins and pitch it as Brad Pitt. It's pretty painful to watch all these two bit VPs sink this company with acquisition of crappy companies with crappy product then turn around and try to sell it to customers.

review_title: Seattle Oracle Public Cloud Cloud Infrastructure Review
pros:
Compensation and Benefits match Seattle's competitive job market
Holidays and vacations ? not so much. You get less holidays in Oracle than Amazon/Microsoft.
Parking and commute are not reimbursed. Even the ORCA card is not free. You have to pay $350+ for your ORCA card.
 
Work culture is a mix of Amazon/Microsoft/Google. Mostly everyone is nice and helpful. There are folks from F5 networks as well
Everyone is super helpful and accessible. 
Kitchen is stacked with food/snacks/drinks
cons:
Since it a mix of different cultures and a relatively new organization, you can be caught in weird mix of people and cultures. Some of the people, especially from F5 networks seem to bring in a lot of negative energy and influence. They seem more interested in power games and putting down others, typically by exaggerating mistakes and embarrassing you. Stay away from these people. You can also expect corporate bullying and hazing if you have to deal with people from F5 ( the bad kind)
Be very careful if you have to work with such folks.

review_title: Spoil you career in OBP Testing Team!!
job_title: Quality Analyst- Product Development in Pune
pros: Only One - You get to work for a fake brand and can proudly say "I Work for Oracle". But in Reality you are still working for i-Flex.
cons:
1. Don't ever work under OBP Testing Team. The Testing Head is of the worst one may come across. The Team has a culture of Micro Management, they do not care about the work you do. But you have to be in office from 9.45-7PM. And if you dont do it you are screwed.

2. Crap Culture of calling your managers as BOSS.. Highly Unprofessional.

3. You will be called to office on Saturdays when releases are near, even if you don't have any work. Just because they wants to please their BOSSES..

4. The work itself is not too great. Same test cases are executed in every releases. New members in the team do not even get to write test cases.

5. The model which they use for Software development is absolutely outdated. Same test cases are executed in IUT, then in ST and again in Regression. Donkey Work !!

6. The cycle of Appraisals and Hikes are not confirmed. You may get it you may not. It's entirely luck based, as there is no concept of yearly hikes in Oracle.

7. You will never get the Bonus which you were promised at the time of recruitment.

pros:
Large company with good benefits. Nothing exceptional but good. 
Flexibility to redeem benefits in cash instead. 
Obviously looks good on the CV.

Plenty of internal jobs available and they are clearly advertised on the internal site.
cons:
Company direction is not clear in our department. They want to rule the world but refuse to approach it in manageable steps. They want to go from zero to world leader in one step. Thats never going to happen. 

Once you get hired it is very hard to get a pay increase. Even when moving jobs internally they don't want to change your salary, even if its moving to a more senior role. I don't understand this logic. It is a guaranteed way to lose good staff. They are forced to leave every few years to keep their salary relevant. 

Top Tip: If you are coming to work for Oracle make sure your salary is above the current market rate, because you wont get a change anytime soon, or be willing to quit in a year or two.

pros: Pay - Nice Coworkers - Nice location
cons:
They hire top professionals and build teams but due to the political fractions inside Oracle some teams  get ZERO work to do because it is competing with other internal teams.
My team was one of the unlucky ones. As a presales i was used to deal with several new opportunities per week, in Oracle i got less than 10 opportunities within 18 months.
On top of this, management was really poor, first, in handling the opportunities situations, but also in keeping fairness within the team and ensuring a healthy environment.
There were team mates sitting side by side where one could do work from home on a weekly basis where another "unlucky" one could not do it at all.
The tools that are given to the PreSales team are borderline to be ridiculous ,  sometimes you need to sell a service that is not available to you to test it and build a demo, therefore making your job very difficult.
The plethora of systems, policies and even communication channels within Oracle makes it a very bad place to work in my opinion. In fact, many people have left in the last month and many are planning to do so.

pros:
- Oracle has a reputation which serves them both good and bad. On the good side, Oracle loyalists are easy to work with and the network is strong and widespread

- Oracle pays, at least in Spain, a high salary compared to the average. 

- Once you have worked at Oracle, at lot of doors opens up at other companies, as the reputation is still intact
cons:
- The company seems to have lost foothold through late arrival to the Cloud trend, but also in the way the treat customers and partners.

- Especially partners are treated oppesite of Microsoft partners,  which gain from being part of MS network. Oracle charges their partners and give them very little business, even the sale staff are in some way competing with the partners in order not to lose commission.

- Oracle has an thick layer of managers and 99% are only doing one thing, sending their sales staff excel sheets about their sales and forecast. The word forecast is word of all time, everyone are always talking about forecast and if you can do that you can become a manager.

pros: work-life balance.. more kind of life balance only
cons: no growth at all. 0 growth

review_title: Good for Grads and Senior engineers
pros:
Life work balance is very much part of the ethos. Work with great team & learn a huge amount from experienced colleagues. Chance to work on cutting edge tech and software.
Internal training easy to access if related to your job.
Ability to work remotely and in office if manager approves. Generally opportunities to travel vary dependant on team.
cons:
Self help is the way internal tools work and can be very difficult to use.
New employees can and do get hired on higher pay than existing employees.
Pay is an issue, opportunities for pay & promotion limited and annually. Dry promotions very common so end up on higher grade with more work for same money. Then graded at a higher level at pay review. 
Global Rules put in by senior management make it harder for your manager to negotiate a good deal.
Pay and promotions are grouped together by org so can be little for each team in that org.
Do not reemploy engineers who leave so once you leave its final.
Very middle management heavy which tends to allow politics to influence decisions.

review_title: Happy Place to work, but with limited career progression and don't a pay rise.
pros: Solid Technology, leader in nearly all technology areas.  Plenty to keep you busy and training is first class.  Bright people and I've really enjoyed my 17 years at Oracle.   Recent focus on CLoud computing is a little late but they are making strong acquisitions in order to catch up fast.
cons: The normal big company issues, mostly political issues.  Lots of Sales/Presales doing similar customer engagement but overlap is inevitable leading to duplication.  Most of the time you feel like the pawn in someone elses jam for promotion.  Manager are only thinking about themselves rather than you.  Once you've reached a certain level and don't want to go into management then you are limited to which jobs are available to you.  People plateau and coast along and Oracle does nothing to make it easy to move around.   Recent focus on career development is a ploy to get rid of the people that don't progress.   Lots of people leaving for Saleforce.com.   No pay rise for the past 5 years.

review_title: Stable employer with flexible working practice
job_title: Technical Analyst III (Support) in Reading, England
pros:
Flexible management style (not over your shoulder) Flexible working hours and probably the best software library you can get at the moment. Plenty of online training available. Autonomous working attitude, self service concept.
Higher management excel at investing and in the art of finance, cash flow and customer base has currently no match in this line of business.
cons: Middle management a little bit too remote and stretched. Too many procedures, as can be seen in most comments about this company. Hardly any pay rise can keep motivation low especially when performance reviews are good. Global teams means that in some departments, there is no sense of belonging to a team as there is little to no communication among employees. It appears that management recently tried to resolve this issue by suddenly discouraging home working habits but the core issue is a middle management issue, not individual contributors whose efficiency can sometimes outperform that of their peers in the office.

Managers will make every effort to try to push you out the door so they can hire more developers with their budget in India. Will work you to death. Late hours, weekends.

pros: There are lots of avenues to learn in Oracle and there is a lot of autonomy
cons: 2 years in and no promotions in sight. Horrible response to BLM

job_title: Account Manager- Core Tech in Mississauga, ON
pros:
-outstanding solutions, technical colleagues and ongoing training
-you'll earn a lot of money if  you can get one of the few productive patches,  but for the  most  part, those just AMs stick around forever
-base salary for Sales is higher than average
-based on previous reviews, the India office sounds splendid, at least.
cons: When I was interviewing, I was assured the  OTE is attainable (it's not-35% of  your comp is out of your control, either OD or field counterpart dependent). Managers are completely inept- worn out, former reps without any mgmt training who throw reps under the bus regularly, paranoid about losing their own jobs, to be fair.  Expect to be micromanaged, and to consistently deliver not just impossible sales quotas but performance metrics ( 50+ calls/day, 10 tracked c-level appointments/week, 12 hours talk time/week, etc).   We're so busy faking our stats we don't have time to sell!  Last year's Q1 kickoff consisted of everyone squeezing into the floor director's office for one serving of orange juice from the vending machine and sparking wine ("mimosa!" ..almost) in Dixie cups.  Don't be deceived, carefully review what people are saying here and separate reviews for the hub you are considering.  There are valid reasons this in particular hub has seen over 3x avg rep churn this year alone.

review_title: Some great, some no great and loads of mergers
pros: Large stable organisation which isn't likely to get acquired by anyone else. Great work/life balance opportunities and generally above average employee benefits.
cons: Oracle has grown through a number of strategic acquisitions to date and will continue to do so. While this may be great news for Oracle's revenue stream it does bring with it a number of challenges embracing various prior work cultures. So one of the challenges any employee will face especially through acquisition is finding that next best fit role which provides the same level of career satisfaction. It is most definitely very easy to get lost inside Oracle world, and this unfortunately also creates another challenge for management  - you will find a lot of employees who are complacent and set in their individual contributor roles, staff attrition is typically low as people get comfortable and seldom seem to leave of their own free will which is no doubt attributed to the good work/life balance. So while I might score high on work/life balance below, I have put this into Pro's and Cons section as it simply means people get way too comfortable in the vast spaces of Oracle land and it's easy to get lost in the cracks.

job_title: Business Development Representative in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
Training
Company name 
Great international environment
cons:
Poor management; fires the most competent managers within the BDG organisation due to their low seniority (low cost). Instead of getting rid of bad managers (high cost).
Top-down management; no clear communication regarding changes within the organisation. 
Changing targets on a quarterly basis i.e. no consistency. You could be working half way through a quarter without knowing your targets.
People are placed in teams without consulting the individuals.
"If you don't like the smell in the bakery - find another one" is the attitude of management.
Managers are afraid of doing changes due to their reputation for upper management. 
No clear progression path - a lot of promises but in the end people are stuck in the role.
Managers are poor in coaching you with developing you.

Selling the worlds leading talent management tool in the market, but doesn't use it internally (Ironical). A lot of talent individuals have fled away, due to frustration. 

Advice to people with bilingual language skills : Go to another software company in Dublin - They would appreciate your education, skill set and it would save you a lot of time in your career path and frustrations.

review_title: Oracle pretty good but you need luck

Actually have a decent set of products.

review_title: RightNow was my passion, unfortunately it was sold to Oracle
pros:
Positive, fun, start-up company environment. Loads of opportunities to make a difference if you reported to a good manager. Felt like family and the it still does with the original gang from the early days. 

We worked really hard, accomplished more than any other company I've worked for,  but we also had a great time doing it. Everyone has a great sense of humour and often pranked each other in new, innovative ways, but all in good fun. I can remember the cardboard office created by Pro Services and the various office make-overs when someone went on holiday.

Excellent atmosphere all the way around!
cons: Small town American company that didn't understand the UK and European markets or salaries in those regions - often used the equivalent US salary and converted to GBP or Euros, so for example, a $40,000 job became a £20,000 in the UK. Generally paid incoming people far more than someone they promoted internally to the same position. Greg sold the business to Oracle, which caused a deep dive in morale, many demotions and redundancies and the loss of much of the best talent, but that is natural with an acquisition of this kind.

review_title: The worst company I could ever imagine

cons: There is absolutely no team spirit. I don't know if it is for all job in sales,but this guys make a pride of the fact that they are a Self service company.  They keep repeating it till you are sick, what they don't say is that the real meaning of self service is lack if accountability.  Some of the managers are absolutely useless, and the lack of real support is appalling. The turnover of people, especially in BDG ,is huge. People leave at enormous speed, looking for a better company, probably because of the awful culture  in this one. But the Company don't care. They  are so full of themselves that they are just too good to actually invest in their people, convinced they will find someone else to do the job.

review_title: Great company, but has lost its identity as it grapples with what it wants to be!
pros: Large org, with great technology, good people, lots of flexibility, can work remotely, aggressive org., lots of customers and has a big brand
cons: Its not employee oriented. No HR whatsoever. they do not care if employees leave or are unhappy, as they think, there are limited places for employees to go to, given they acquired almost every other software company and so, the logic at the top management is, let's stuff our pockets with lots of cash and options, while we squeeze the employees and partners. Mark Hurd has added no real value and all he does is try to screw employees, like he did at HP. Its a short sighted company in terms of patience to close deals, etc. as they have still not learnt that selling DB and Apps are different ball games and the sales cycles are different. They hve been losing good folks for a while now. Its overall a cold culture, with zero HR

pros: A large, entrenched US-based company in the database and enterprise software industry; some very smart employees and teams working on interesting products; decent and competitive initial salary; ability to telecommute and work with world-wide employees, partners, and customers.
cons:
As mentioned in other reviews, there are no further compensation adjustments after your initial salary - negotiate very hard at signing. No such thing as cost-of-living raises or regular raises; no compensation increase if promoted; no bonuses or stock options unless senior positions.

Although I don't doubt there are some great teams and organizations to work with, I worked with a mgmt team that were unethical and unreasonable in their requests of the people that worked for them.

Enterprise software strategy is a mess from a product development standpoint. Strategy is acquisition, which gains customers and removes a competitor, but from a product development standpoint involves the integration of engineering team, tools, and products - hardly ever successfully. A mash of products and teams doing the same thing; often Oracle sales teams compete against each other!, each team citing themselves as the "Oracle's preferred solution." Result is a mass of teams and tools, disorganization, and no communication. Frustrating to work with and/or support these teams.

A cold, US based company focused on the bottom line. Good if you're a shareholder, not an employee.

review_title: Product quality and staff retention take a back seat to sales and consulting
pros:
Oracle offers a comprehensive benefits package in the US. Medical/dental/vision coverage appears to be high compared to other employers. They also offer 401k matching, low cost life insurance, and other benefits.

At Oracle, you are exposed to many different technologies, industries, and complex customer implementations. These present plenty of opportunities to learn a wide array of skills.
cons:
Although there is a lot of training available to employees at no cost, it frequently has to be done on the employee's own time due to understaffing.

Employees are overworked and undercompensated. Off-shoring is relied upon too heavily as a cost-cutting measure, ignoring the increased cost and burden that it creates for the rest of Oracle and it's global customers.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Boston, MA

pros: Large enough to offer a great array of benefits. Strong culture, lots of support for community service/giving back, great people. job_title: Applications Sales Representative in Redwood City, CA

Good work/life balance....except near quarter-ends.
cons: Go-to-market structure creates internal competition that shouldn't exist and is counter productive. Very process and systems intensive - overly time consuming. job_title: Principal Systems Administrator in Jacksonville, FL

Oracle is self insured, so some of the best health benefits I've ever seen.
cons:
Hiring process is long and tedious.   If you are on the short list to get hired, expect it to take a couple of months and don't get discouraged.  Oracle has acquired a lot of smaller companies over the last decade.  They have done a fairly poor job of culturally assimilating those companies.  Many people that came from acquisitions still have a "us vs. them" mentality.   

The benefits package in general is fantastic.  However...  they are stingy with vacation and it's non-negotiable.

In fact, you can often return after a couple of years away and get a much better salary than you had on your original stint.

job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros: If you join as a developer in the database organization, you are very unlikely to be laid off or fired. If you have a lot of other commitments, or you absolutely need stability (for example due to visa issues) this is a good thing.
cons:
Compensation is on the low end. As a core member of a high performing development team, I got a raise every year (apparently this isn't the case across development). However, it usually wasn't very much, about 3%. Most years I would get some sort of bonus or stock, but never both in the same year, with a value of less than 10% of base salary per year.

As many people in the organization have been there a long time, certain ways of working have become ingrained. There is little chance to influence the development process for the better.

Outside of the database organization, layoffs in development are more of a risk (for example a layoff was covered in the news in January 2017).

review_title: Management consistently demonstrates that they don't care about employees
job_title: Senior Solutions Consultant in Broomfield, CO
pros: I am paid well, but my understanding of coworkers' salaries is that they're very inconsistent, often lower than industry standard. The health benefits are great. I'm allowed a very flexible work schedule in which I can work from home pretty much whenever I want as long as I'm getting my work done.
cons: Management has done little to bolster employee morale. Last year, in our most successful year of revenue growth ever, management opted not to give raises. This year hasn't been as strong as last, so raises are once again out the window. The technology we're given to work with is terrible. Internal tools constantly break, and instead of hiring development resources to fix them we're only focused on revenue growth. Client facing employees like me are constantly tasked with making excuses for why nothing works. Management consistently makes decisions that put Oracle shareholders first and our clients and employees a distant second. Bureaucracy and fear of legal liability hog ties everything we do, and it's a generally unpleasant, soul-sucking company to work for day to day.

pros:
Good money
Excellent Benefits
Tons of self-study courses available.
Tons of classroom training available if you can find the time.
Large and growing pipeline of software sales.
Targeted acquisition of hardware and software sales indicate continued success.
Oracle's success is your success.
Oracle's failures seldom translate into employee failures.
cons: The downside for working at Oracle would probably be the downside for working at any software and/or consulting company. Sales are cyclical. When times are good, everybody thrives financially. When times are tough, and they were through 2008/2009, people can lose their jobs. All things being equal in the market place, the pros for working at Oracle beat the cons.

review_title: Dynamic work environment with some challenges
job_title: Senior Director Marketing in Redwood City, CA
pros: Oracle is a market leader with a huge portfolio of products and service offerings. Lots of areas of opportunities for those who aren't afraid to roll up their sleeves and work hard. Great selection of health benefits.
cons: As a result of Oracle's acquisition spree over the last 10 years, the organization is a confusing maze and the systems are cobbled together. It is very hard to get some things done. Informal and very proactive networking is the only way to navigate this massive company. There is also a lot of disparity in salaries and titles. Those who have been with Oracle a long time are often penalized and have not received raises in years. As a result it is not uncommon for a manager to have someone in his or her organization who reports to someone who reports to him/her that makes nearly double and has a grander title. There is very little career development. It is up to the individual to look for opportunities and go after them in order to get ahead.  It is also very hard to motivate employees without incentives such as raises, bonuses.

review_title: Terrible corporate culture, mismanaged projects and lack hardware to accomplish "critical" tasks.  Look elsewhere!
pros:

- Some flexibility of work schedule within development orgs. (if you work for the right manager)
cons:
- Zero focus on management training/skills within the development organizations
- Consistent lack of financial incentive (even for those in the top 10% come review time)
- An expectation that employees will work as many hours per day needed to achieve unrealistic project goals (part of the culture)
- Workaholic mentality is encouraged
- Many employees are deeply unhappy as a result of quarter on quarter penny pinching and lack of raises.

pros: Really good facilities, gym and  health care.
cons: The new ODP team has been set up completely disorganised. No product training what so ever. The expectation is to hit targets and the team has been forced to engage in customer interactions without any knowledge of what they are actually selling. Oracle is very self service but you cannot expect results if the employees do not know the core basis of what it is we actually need to sell.  Allot of new faces, many without any tech background at all. No real slow introduction at a high level to at least gain some knowledge

pros: Opportunity to be exposed to new lines of business via M&A. If you want to travel or relocate you may be able to - company has deep pockets WRT expenses. Prepare to work independently with little on boarding - if one is a self-start you'll do well.

pros:
-Fortune 100 company
-highly accredited reputation externally within Technology Services (in terms of product features and suite enhancements)
-somewhat competitive commission earnings (changes YOY; and slowly reducing employee earning potential)
cons:
-Disruptive restructurings that are poorly implemented and managed top-down

review_title: Great work culture, no room to grow
job_title: Principal Product Manager in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Great work culture . Feels like family

review_title: Oracle Does Not Support Employee Growth
pros: Lower management is usually friendly toward directs.  The initial salary is enough to get you to walk in the door.  The ability to balance work/life is great and there are opportunities to work from home when needed.
cons: Oracle management does no believe in talent development--there are some very basic education classes and beyond that nothing.  The initial salary is often your final salary, so long term employment for non-sales is out of the question.  This approach is counter intuitive as Oracle is always in a cycle of training new employees and/or retraining employees brought over through acquisition.  It is readily apparent that Oracle has a formula whereby they calculate the value of an employee, expected rate of return and cost of training a new employee, thus allowing Oracle to essentially carve out the need for salary increases, bonus structures, etc.

review_title: Very low pay and appreciation to employees
pros:
- Good people
- Option to work from home
cons:
For the past 9+ years, employees have gotten no salary increase or whatsoever. In fact, as time goes, employees keep losing more and more privileges every year. At the same time, Sr. management keeps getting 10s of millions added to their already fat salaries every year.
 Employees in the US are expected to work US time in addition to India and China time, all expected with zero compensation or recognition from management.
 Bonuses are not given for performance, they are just not given at all. When the company decides to give rewards or salary increases (every few years), it becomes all political. Money is only given to the employees that are "way" below market range (opposed to the other employees that are just below range). Also, raises and bonuses average about 1% to 2%, it is a slap on the face and you don't even see it in your pay check.
 The slogan at Oracle, if they do not leave, why pay them more?!

pros:
Great work-life balance
If you are looking for a company where not performers are recognized and stay there for a long time "surviving" being hated by your reps but loved by your VPs , Oracle is the right company for you
cons: If you are a talented professional and want to progress your career unfortunately is not the right company for you.  Also is you are not Irish and do not support the big Irish management gang working there you are not the right person at all. Do you want to know how a 80/90s  company is working in 2016? Welcome to Oracle!! No strategy or plannification! CRM is the worst ever ..main tool used internally is Excel which means data is highly not accurate so everyone can make up numbers easily. BDG is a total mess, ISRs too. Cold calling and ridiculous KPIs that can't be measure properly are main part of the job for fresh graduates or experienced reps that are totally by their own to achieve targets. Unfortunately most of the directors and VPs are dinosaurs that never sold Cloud solutions in an Inside Sales org which means they do not have any clue how to go to market. Creativity and proactivity is being killed internally by Directors rather political environment and personal favours are seeing as normality

pros: I can't really think of anything. Some groups might have good immediate management.
cons:
Oracle has so many problems, I don't know where to start. They don't express their appreciation for employees. Raises are very rare.

The hiring process at Oracle is impossible. All new-hires go through the CEO's offices and can take months. This means that only the least-employable people get hired. In addition, the company likes to hire new-college grads and pay them more than existing engineers. They tend to stay for 2 years, get lots of coaching from senior engineers, and then leave for greener fields. This leaves frustrated, underpaid engineers behind.

I had faith in the upper management's ability to look at the long-term goals. This ended when Oracle killed off Solaris and Sparc development. They have some idea of focusing on the cloud, but killed the only differentiation they had. Now they will be racing Amazon and Google to the bottom on Cloud offerings. I was particularly amused that they killed Sparc development right before Meltdown and Spectre undercut Intel/AMD.

review_title: Oracle, a great place lacking great compensation
pros: Dynamic environment, always challenging the paradigm, continually presenting new scenarios that require creative thinking and problem solving.  An environment that fosters individual thinking and contributions, where opinions are taken seriously and valuable contributions are recognized.  Incredible, hard-working people, with great personalities and very strong work ethic; slackers are weeded out and don't last.  Successfully weathered the great recession, growing substantially even during the downturn.
cons: Low compensation when compared to other tech companies.  An inconsistent bonus pool that varies widely year to year, with no real reason or explanation as to why.  Acquisitions have reinforced this notion, as those coming into the company typically make 50% more that their Oracle counterparts, where historical bonuses were 2-4x of those at Oracle and usually were contractually spelled out based upon the company's earnings.  Acquisitions happen so rapidly, it's getting more and more difficult to successfully integrate each company before the next acquisition hits.

review_title: Difficult company to work for now. Customers dont like us
pros: Although travel for training has basically disappeared, there is a ton of online training. You can also take any OU courses. Broad product set keeps you interested. Very smart people working here. Compensation is probably average. Pretty flexible about working from home or taking time off. Some managers are good - very supportive and dive in to help. Being #1 in a lot of areas helps with meeting customers.
cons: Sales model SUCKS!!! multiple reps claiming they are the "go-to" rep drives customers crazy. The latest desupport news for Itanium has them hating us now. Rather than talk to people, the default is to immediately over react to any situation and throw people under the bus. This atmosphere of paranoia starts at the top. Very difficult to advance, you must be highly political. Managing up is valued more than contribution. HR is rude and unhelpful.

review_title: Great Benefits, Great Vacation time, Good People - hard to move around.
job_title: Senior Technical Support Engineer in Bloomington, MN
pros: The company is so large that if your main concern is stability, this would be the number 1 choice to be in MN. Oracle is an international company as well, so people have found positions in Oracle offices around the world. Workplace is Diverse and the people are great to work with. I Tele-commute 3 days a week with some of my co-workers doing it full time. So this is a great work at home position that allows me flexibility to be with my family.
cons: Its Big, so big that sometimes you feel like you can't make a difference. The bureaucracy also makes it hard to move around to other positions that you desire. In addition, once you have obtained the position, it may take another 6-12 months for the approval process to complete before you can start your new position.

Saying out the gates that you don't compromise on where and when people can move within the sales org has already cost a handful of good people, but the mass exodus of good people wont happen until people finish out their deals for Q4 in May. Then they will lose so many people - good people - that the policy will change, but only after they lose all of the good people they've invested in.

review_title: Horrible Management and Senior Leaders who lays off
pros: Putting Oracle's big name on your resume.
cons: Oracle is all about the big money clients who pay over 4 million ARR to Oracle.  They will bend over backwards for them.  The rest of the clients smaller than 1.5 are treated like the redheaded stepchild.  Smaller clients who don't spend big bucks but eventually would if they bought multiple suites have drifted to other vendors.  Stock went up 11% after the massive layoffs.  Real nice, instead of keeping your employees you fed your own pocketbook.  To anyone with Oracle stock.  Sell your stock as it's going to tank when these clients they've forgotten move on.  They can only support the big guys so long before the small ones eat them up by going to competitors.

review_title: Great company to work for, beware experience will vary by group
pros:
Many products ranging from the flagship database to infrastructure like cloud and hardware, which means you have access to one of the deepest and broad-subject knowledge in the world. 
With so many products, there is room for growth, change in career, and learning new technologies. 
For the most part, there is good work/life balance with flexible hours and flexible work locations. Note I didn't say few hours :)
Steady stock rise, sometimes a bit slow, but it pays off.
cons:
Experience will largely vary by team, team policies and manager in everything from focal reviews to professional development. 
Customers work with Oracle through representatives from many groups, so often there is a lack of communication across teams before defining a customer strategy. 
Because there are so many ways to solve the same problem with different Oracle products, you may find yourself in competition with another Oracle group and loose sight or attention to the real (external) competitors and sometimes even the customer.

job_title: Sales Development Representative in Redwood Shores, CA

pros: Nothing to say about this

job_title: Applications Database Administrator in Redwood City, CA
pros: Good to have on your resume - its "Harvard" for the Database World. The flagship product, Oracle Enterprise Edition Relational Database System (RDBMS) is as rock-solid as a Mac truck. Oracle Apps only has a few competitors left: SAP and Salesforce.com. The headquarters has nice buildings - 6 round buildings around a lake - we called it "Lake Larry." Other Pros: good healthcare, subsidized food in cafeterias, good Gym, and going to training classes regularly was supported. Also even though working for Larry is tough, at least he knows how to make money and generate healthy profits, so the stock is more stable than a bank stock!
cons: Larry's ultra-competitive personality trickles down and you either have to be a shark, or face getting eaten. Don't be surprised if you get trampled on by the next guy trying to look good for the boss. I had heard that managers were told to rank-order their employees and have the list ready at all times. They were also told to give 80% of their bonus pool to the top 20% of the people, and little or nothing to the rest. Certain individuals seem to do well with raises but most are left to languish with a few thousand dollars of what they came in at, even after many years.

review_title: Great work life balance... but don't expect to feel like you're saving the world.
job_title: Senior Field Service Engineer in Minneapolis, MN

review_title: Don't get fooled ... no future here

Recruiters might tell you differently but about 5% reach their target, another 15% sells one product or more... the rest sells nothing.

No travel on Sunday and other approaches to minimize OT. Presales folks are paid below market rate salary but the spin is that you are paid for OT so your salary plus OT is in line with market rates. The rub is that lower mgt pushes to keep OT low, which limits your individual earning potential.

job_title: Business Process Analyst V in Redwood City, CA
pros: Great people at the real worker level. Lots of diversity. Lots of experience and varying backgrounds from all the acquisitions. Was able to work from home and travel domestic and international. The first couple of years were great. But read on for the bad news...
cons: NO RAISES. Seriously, in 7 years, nothing. None of my co-workers got anything either. And don't think this is about performance because I did get a promotion after I got a masters degree. Just no money to go with it. Executive management is VERY political and back-stabbing. Also, you can't transfer up into a higher grade or salary. It's not allowed. For someone like myself working from home in a remote location, when they stopped allowing travel, that was the writing on the wall.

pros: Great first job experience for recent college graduates. They put a lot of resources into sales training and career development, but opportunities for pay raises are slim with promotions. Management truly believes in enabling millennial employees and growing your skill set. Company culture is great, and if you want to work at a company with a lot of young social people this is a great fit.
cons: Oracle is in the middle of an organizational shift to the cloud, and the company is struggling to adapt its sales/customer service model to this new product focus (cloud). Management can seem disorganized at times, and the company is slow to respond to customer needs/demands, which can be frustrating for salespeople. Oracle is trying to change its negative perception with the Customer Success Manager program.

review_title: Good experience, terrible management, priorities misguided
pros: Good experience and a great resume builder
cons: The company has grown too large and doesn't know how to be scaled. Too many bad experiences to count or say here. Company priorities are misguided and technology is outdated while refusing to change. The management cares more that your dashboard is clean and that your dial number is up more than actually selling anything. The rules they put you under are not there to help you, they do nothing but make your job harder than it already is to make management look better. Wastes of time, lack of communication, being treated like a child doing menial tasks in a college class, all while the fake Netsuite culture is being forced on you to make you think its the best company ever.

review_title: Good people, interesting work, mediocre compensation.
job_title: Corporate Counsel in Redwood City, CA
pros: Interesting and challenging work. The people are almost universally friendly and, despite generally low morale due to inadequate compensation, are always willing to help one another. Experience at Oracle is a good resume builder. Attorneys frequently leave to join exciting startups or top-tier companies like Google, Uber, Facebook, and Salesforce.
cons: Compensation is so far below market that managers apologize to you about it when they're out of the GC's earshot. Because Oracle is so stingy with raises, new hires are brought in at salaries higher than more experienced attorneys in the group, which destroys morale. Yes, the salary structure actually gives you an incentive to leave for another job, because if you ever came back you would be paid more than when you left. The company is tone deaf to the problem, so most people use it as a stepping stone after leaving a law firm before moving on to better positions elsewhere.

review_title: Treated Well but Missteps in Upper Management and Missed Opportunities.
pros:
Good Salary, Benefits, and Excellent Vacation and Holiday Schedule.  (Bank holidays and Christmas through New Year's as part of Holiday).
Telecommuting encouraged and reimbursements for all work related expenses from cell phone to ISP to land line.
Telecommuting worked well for both employees and SUN.
Ability to work with new technologies.  
Breadth of hardware and software solutions and pioneering projects should make most technology enthusiasts very happy.
The Good Guys for open source.
cons:
Too many re-orgs and changes in strategy and direction.
Too much reliance on partners for delivering key services and solutions that should have been handled in-house via Professional Services.

Too many layoff rounds that affected morale.

Software for a while was always less important than hardware and treated as such.
Too many hardware folks trying to run software with mixed results.

Open Source model was hard to make money off of.  Some poor execution and missteps.

review_title: Interesting but too much operational bureaucracy.
pros: Interesting solution set to sell to customers.  New products are exciting and fun to position. Some managers are creative but that is not the majority.
cons: The company cannot decide it it wants inside or outside sales and as a result it pays very low.  Top management for the division are long time oracle operations and finance people who have never worked anywhere but Oracle University so sales is considered a low status job but does all customer facing work. Salary is low and comp does not begin to be competitive.

job_title: Technical Support Engineer in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: I am one of the many number of people hired for their product support after Oracle closed down their many offices overseas, and getting in here has shown that the benefits are pretty good compared to other companies; the cafeteria is reasonable, the soda and coffee(so-so at best) are free, and lastly, you are definitely going to be busy once your training(mines was very short) is over....
cons: ....which leads to the downsides of working here.  There are not enough hours in the day to sometimes get your other work done especially when you are dealing with a large customer who wants to be first in the line to get their issues resolved; its a really thankless job, sure you get the occasional free food (ran out of taco meat last time) or ice cream, but extra compensation in recognizition would be nice. And from what I've heard, pay raises are as rare as a dodo bird here, which could make some people leave in a year or two; if you can get the later shift, at least you can get some extra pay(which can take place of a pay raise).

review_title: Lots of racism, both casual and internalized, by Account Managers and their managers, respectively.
pros: There's a LOT of money to be made. Very fast-paced and exciting. You typically leave work on Fridays at 3:30.
cons: LOTS of implicit association that will work against men-of-color. Frat boy environment full of casual racism, blatant racism, and exclusionary behavior.

pros: Good health benefits / that's all

review_title: What a mess (can only speak to public sector office in Reston)
pros: Not stressful, casual dress, decent pay for the amount of work, really nice people who work in customer-facing sales
cons: public sector sales leadership management strategy  seems to be "spray and pray" (not unlike much email client outreach), they have no idea what they're doing and are hiring directors who are even more clueless, training is terrible and disjointed, deals move extremely slow because of working w/ gov't, unambitious working culture, bad compensation compared to competitors (Amazon, salesforce, etc.) and high attrition, company seems to be falling apart beneath itself. Our CEO (PE background) is ruthlessly trimming the fat and selling her stock as soon as it vests—very obvious they're getting the company small and lean enough to sell off in the next few years, as it is way behind competitors when it comes to market share and quality of product in the cloud. The only people who stay are the ones who are too complacent to get out—makes for a very unenthusiastic workplace.

pros: It’s an ok place to work
cons:
It’s a decent place
To work

pros: A great place to get in at the crack of 10, take a two hour lunch, and be done by 4. So very easy to retire on the job if you kiss the right a@@es. The executives have really, really nice exotic sports cars and they're cool to look at in the reserved parking spots right next to the building entrances, but they make sure you'll never be able to afford one. Ever.
cons: Where do I begin? Bad pay, bad management, no opportunity for advancement (unless you are politically astute, but even that often backfires). If you don't have a technical degree, you are scum and treated as such. Way too many people doing the same thing you are doing. Enough deadwood to heat Siberia for years. Fiefdoms and territories that are defended with nuclear devices. Management just plain, flat out, utterly, completely does not give a s**t about you. Until it's time to lay you off. Then they're glad you're around so they have someone to chop.

review_title: Decent company for starting and building your knowledge
job_title: Database Administrator in Redwood City, CA
pros: The work from home option is the best i can think of, as it allows you to spend time with your family....and the flex time, plus the technology you get to work with and the ability to move between groups....that's about it.
cons:
Pay raises are non existent. Thats pretty discouraging when the CEO gets $500 million in cashed stock options....and forget about bonuses....only certain employee levels are entitled to bonuses and those are "discretionary"...They also have this rule that you have to be in a position for certain amount of time prior to being considered for a promotion...like longevity means anything?
Promote people based on performance....HR also says they consistently perform market analysis of salaries to ensure they are competitive, that's a laugh....They are competitive in a good economy, otherwise, forget it.

review_title: Good Company if you can accept some tough truths
job_title: Senior Director in Redwood City, CA
pros: Great people.  Flexibility when needed.  Ability to move around departments when you get bored in a particular role.  Great products and innovation to keep abreast with the new Cloud and SaaS world.
cons: Inconsistent and poorly communicated pay increases, usually quite low if there is a raise, 2-3% at most.  Lame bonuses if/when they actually give bonuses, but there is never an announcement one way or the other about there being or not being a bonus pool, even when the company has a great year.  My prior companies gave bonuses based upon a % of salary based upon company performance, so a person could plan accordingly and enjoy the bounty of a successful year or quarter, as do most companies on the peninsula.  Not so at the O.

review_title: Oracle Digital Malaga- Watch out for the Victorian Workhouse!
pros: Working in Malaga, nice weather, good beaches.
cons: Total micro management,  they use inside sales as business development and to make up for the lack in marketing. Add to this the new ver suspicious compensation rules, and the yearly rotation of territories meaning that global finance can alway dispute you compensation, and you may find yourself working on deals that you will not be paid for. Add the this the micromanagement of Sales Managers that do everything to hang on to their desks, and are really only there for reporting .In the age of startups and collaborative companies this is really a monolith from the early 90's. WARNING:  there is a very high turnover of sales reps, and most are only waiting for their relocation packages ( 1.5 years) condition to run out before they resign so they don't have to pay it back. Wondered why Orcale is always hiring ? ... now you know.

pros: Chilled out atmosphere, no deadlines
cons: No career progress, no promotions, hikes

review_title: Oracle University is a Horrible Place to work!
job_title: Education Sales Representative in Reston, VA
pros: The is a division of Oracle that sells the training for all Oracle products.  No Pros
cons: Very demanding with quota. The quota can never be met and the expectations are unfair.  Then when you don't hit your quota you get put on plan or written up. You have to talk a more than  2 hours on phone to customers and if you don't you get written up.  Some territories are set up so you sell against other Sales people and compete within the organization leaving deals to get poached and stolen from you.  Internal management is horrible with large egos and no understanding of what the sales people have to do to close a deal.  Very unfair on how they approve discounts with customers all for different amounts.  No consistancy and policies quickly changes with the weather changes.  Don't work for this Oracle Division, it is HORRIBLE!

review_title: Have a lot of mixed Feelings
pros:
Good starting salary for freshers /laterals 
Great learning opportunities
Brand name of Oracle 
Lot of onsite opportunities( depending on the group to which you belong )
Banking Domain knowledge  
Flexible timings 
job security much better than other companies
cons:
Not good hikes for existing employees . A 5 year guys and a freshers salary may be almost same .
Though they tell Oracles name while hiring the perks and benefits to oracle are not passed to  OFSS employees . 
All oracle policies which are disadvantageous to employees and profitable to company are selectively   implemented and beneficial perks are not passed on saying by discretion of senior management.
If you stay here too long not much growth . Even if you get promotions still you will be doing the same work you were doing 3 years back .  A lot of long timers are present due to which difficult for vertical growth . 
Long hours  and Slogging needed .
Disconnect between middle management and senior management .
Employee job satisfaction is low in most teams . 
Onsite not much  money as you have to  provide bills for all the expenses and get that reimbursed from company .

review_title: sales arrogance and margin focus overshadow compelling technology and work/life balance
pros:
Mandy different areas to work in/focus on within this large company
Enjoy the status and name recognition of a large global company  
A leading edge technology company with constant IP creation or acquisition of quality IP
Technical support teams are valued
good benefits ( healthcare and 401K programs and many others)
cons:
Direct Technology SW sales reps bully customers, VARs and other sales reps
silos of sales rep compensation create little cross product selling synergies inside of Oracle
Oracle sales focus and investment always goes to large customers and SIs/partners 
Employee salaries are never increased and sales comp is managed to be sub-100% to improve Oracle margins
Complicated programs for partners and so very little content is partner ready/accessible
Employees deal with a self service / find it yourself tools system, information, and culture throughout

review_title: No raises, no promotions, no travel, and managers have no authority
job_title: Critical Accounts Manager in Colorado Springs, CO
pros:
Oracle used to be a fantastic place to work, lots of energy, lots of fun, promotions, raises, bonuses.  Not so much now.  I am speaking of the Support folks.
So I can't actually think of any pros other than the benefits and paycheck.
cons:
No more work at home for Support.
No more paying for home internet for those who work from home unless you have Senior VP Approval (seems like a waste of SVP time, but if they have nothing else to do... Petty, really petty.)
Managers have no authority, they are beholden to the 'higher ups'
No raises, not even cost of living - some support folks have gone 10 years without a raise.
Support Engineers at our newest US location (in Utah) start at $20-$40K more than the ones who have 5-15 years in support. (Verified in writing from one of the managers)
Support engineers have upwards of 20-40 cases they are working on at once.

pros: I had a good manager and very much enjoyed the people I worked with. Co-workers and also manager were great, always willing to share knowledge and help you out when you needed it.  Benefits are good, I enjoyed the projects I worked on and my manager always backed me and others in the group up when dealing with difficult clients.  Luckily for me I just had one bad one.
cons: Education and training opportunities were very limited.  Senior Management seem to also be  the cutting consulting side.   It was like being Larry's red-headed step child.  Sales and consulting did not work well together.  Forget about promotions or raises.  They are always have salary freezes on the consulting side.  Even when you are billing 100% they stiff you on the bonuses.

pros: Every group/division can be different in how they treat their employees, but I'd say overall there is very good atmosphere of trust and fairness. There is a strong focus on education, and they reimburse for outside classes taken (Up to 5k/year I think). Benefits are good, and I'd say quite competitive in the market. Good 401K matching (they'll contribute a max of 3% of your 6% or greater). Free drinks in the breakroo…
cons: They don't try to make the workplace anything special (maybe a pool table and arcade game are cliche or gimmicky?). In the 10 years I've worked there, they've given 2 measly %1 cost of living raises (this is the same with most everyone I've spoken to, some don't get any raises). You will not get a substantial raise ever, unless you leave then get rehired on (they will not match offers, better to leave). New employees…

job_title: Sales Account Manager in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Great people, lots of different nationalities and genuinely excellent products to sell.  Basic money is not great, but commission can be good if you're lucky and you work hard.  Benefits like pension and medical are excellent.  Really good canteens.
cons: There was a seismic shift about a year ago with some very strange decisions being made. Me and many of my colleagues were inexplicably moved to sell a completely different range of products, which meant we had to be retrained. The training I received when I first joined was truly world class. Second time around, it was a joke. This time we were trained by managers who didn't want to be there and others who hadn't a clue what they were doing. Worst of all though, my pay will now take a huge cut while I get to grips with the new things I have to sell and it could take months to work on new deals. I love the company, but after 3 years, this might be a bridge too far.

job_title: Sales Compensation Analyst in Sacramento, CA
pros: Great Benefits. Some awesome managers. You can get the chance to work with people all over the world and travel.
cons: Promotions and Bonuses are almost non existent. If you do have a chance to receive one it is very unclear what managers are looking for to receive one. If you want to have a career at oracle make sure you get hired on in a position as high as possible or you will get stuck at your pay until you either switch to another org or leave the company.

job_title: Business Development Consultant in Dublin, Dublin
pros: The people in my team were really nice and we had lots of fun.
cons:
I worked as BDC in Dublin and started right after my Master studies. It was really the worst first work experience I could have had. Oracle is not interested in their employees as human beeings but only in the numbers. Also the management is more than poor. You wont get much of support because mostly the managers themselves do not care. 
The overall atmosphere on the BDC floor is very depressing, not only because of the ugly office but also because there is no communication or transparency. There is literally no corporate culture, no communication and politics are horrible, which leads to many unmotivated employees. 
I think every second person wants to leave at the moment. 
Oracle does everything so that all good people leave. Its sad to see that such a big known company has such a poor management style and treats their people in such a bad way.
So if you want to gain experience in an international company I would really suggest you to go to the other numerous IT companies in Dublin.

review_title: Good career start, but lots of internal issues
pros:
Lots of stability. You could fall short of your quota for many quarters and still have your job. The Class of Sales Academy was helpful and a really great launch pad into a sales career. The people at Oracle are for the most part a fun bunch.

Pay is good straight out of school and the benefits are comparable to that of many Fortune 500 companies.

Although you start off with 12 vacation days, the work life balance is amazing. Flexible hours depending on your schedule, cutting out of work by 3pm on Fridays, and ability to win "work-from-home days."
cons:
Oracle's mission statement: To be #1 in everything hardware and software.

If this mission statement doesn't identify with you, you probably won't have a great time. The thing people here value more than anything is money and there can be shady things that happen because of that. Oracle has no strong sense of culture because there is no strong sense of Oracle values. There are a lot of internal headaches and it feels at times there is a lack of resources to do your job.

Your fate is dependent on what team, territory, and patch that you work.

pros: Can make some good money if you land in the right spot and are smart/ can sell.  Internal tools to mine information are available
cons: Very difficult to hit/exceed budget YOY with shrinking territories  and growing budgets.  30 plus Oracle reps calling into the same customers is a huge turn off for customers of all sizes.  Mobility is harder and harder every year as field sales roles are being eliminated, around 30% this fiscal.  Kids coming right out of college in an inside sales role seems to be the direction the sales org is heading and more experienced reps with a history of achieving and over achieving sales goal are forced to leave. (to Salesforce primarily)

Good brand to have on CV
Office gym
Parking
Office being refurbished

Oracle audits customers for most of it’s revenue not enough data centres in Aus to support its cloud products, 
few customers are using Oracle cloud.

Oracle Digital Prime Has a huge turnover, sacked & leaving. 
No ODP leadership 
Lots of empty desks
Extremely toxic environment 
Most customers want to move away from Oracle
Management by fear
North Ryde isn’t a great place to work
In country leadership has no control of local market

pros: The people I work with are Wonderful, We have a Great Team. Everyone gets along with everyone and always willing to help each other out at anytime. I never have to worry about competition or jealousy among co-workers. I enjoy coming to work each and everyday. IF YOUR NOT HAPPY WITH YOUR JOB THEN IT MAKES IT FOR A DIFFICULT WORKING DAY
cons: Sometimes it takes along time for Management to approve certain things but with the state of the economy today and right now I am sure that has alot to do with them being cautious about spending and budgets at the moment. I also think that sometimes things are done a little backwards, but when you own a big corporation you need to make the decisions that are best suited for everyone involved

review_title: Great work experience for your resume, but not a company you can retire at.
pros: You are selling the best products in the industry.  When competing against other companies to win a deal, you have an advantage, because everything Oracle owns is the best.  It is easy to get in the door with customers because everyone uses at least one product within the Oracle product stack.  It is a good thing to have on your resume.
cons: This is a very cut throat company and they are not known for treating their employees with the greatest of respect.  Management does not have the upmost in talent.  They are incredibly cheap with things such as travel, awards, team lunches.  The processes to close a deal are too overwhelming.   For eg. you have to negotiate contracts with the lawyers on the customer side, but Oracle will not put a lawyer on the phone.

review_title: Demanding, high stress environment, but a good opportunity to work with good people
pros: My team and the larger group I worked for were a terrific group of very talented people. Employees had access to sophisticated technologies (subject to some budget restrictions). Company policies and administrative processes were well defined and highly automated. Oracle provided significant resources for tech support, mental and physical health, investigating career advancement, and human resources issues. The company took ethcs very seriously.
cons: Job performance demands were exceedingly high, with tighter deadlines and more responsibilities per employee becoming the norm. Different groups within the company often did the same things in completely different ways, using different sets of tools. Development projects often skimped on the design phase and requirements changed frequently, resulting in wasted time fixing bugs and redesigning features. The members of another team who served as my primary working partners were good folks who had trouble allocating sufficient time or effort to our common tasks.

pros: As with any employer, your experience is more a factor of who you are working with and what you are doing.  In my case, Oracle has turned out to be the best job I've ever had.  I avoided Oracle for years because of its reputation of such a hard driving, aggressive sales force.  Instead, I've found a professional culture that respects and values the contributions of SCs.  My products work, and they are some of the best in the industry.  There is none of the "blame the SC" culture that I've found at other companies when things go wrong.  I'm making as much money here as I've ever made.  The benefits are some of the best I've ever had.  My teammates are knowledgeable and helpful.  The hours are reasonable, plus we make overtime due to Oracle's unique comp plan.
cons: There is a definite competition between different sales groups as Oracle, specifically apps versus tech.  That can make it difficult and frustrating for SCs who just want to get the job done while the reps argue account control and strategy.

pros: Free snacks and food (sometimes), decent team to work and collaborate with, seems to be open to innovation, OK to start when you're new to tech/ just graduated
cons: Hire Right sucks for their background check(also be aware that all your information is sent to random third parties in different countries), will hassle/delay your hire date until you want to tap out and forget it, no firm offer letter for months while waiting on Hire Right to not follow up with any real people, no movement, pretty stagnate once you're in, no telecommute

review_title: Challenging, good pay good work life balance
pros: Sensible work hours compared to last job -- work 50 hrs week compared to 70.  This is due to having more people supporting you with your tasks.  Next, I value working with colleagues all over the globe. I'm home assigned which works great. Manager treats as adults in that no questions asked or bother if you're professionally competent do a good job. If you go above and beyond with your work you get raises and are supported by managment.  Finally, Oracle knows how to monitize on products and sevices.  This is a plus as I have not had to deal with constant layoffs like at my previous company.
cons: Raises amounts could be higher.  The culture differs based on where you are at.  California HQ is pretty dull, whereas the old Sun Microsystems campus in Colorado is much more interactive with brigher facilities and staff events.
