pros: It's a great way to build your resume after college and everyone knows Oracle and it is likely any company you would've liked to work in the past has been swallowed up by Oracle and thus their tech is available to play with.
cons: Compensation is horrible compared to similar tech companies. There is no work/life balance and you are expected to work  nights, weekends and holidays. Wait until you work there for 5 years and you realize you've been on call for 5 years.... Managers are the worse and depending on the manager you get you might have a great or horrible experience at Oracle but never expect your manager to come to your rescue if that means putting his own neck on the line.

review_title: Be wary of the obnoxious PM manager..
pros:
Hands down, some of the best people I have worked with
Engineers are fun, passionate and will make your ideas real
Marketing folks are absolutely humble and smart
The VP is a rockstar, and will listen to the most simplest ideas with lot of attention
Overall, fantastic vibe in the office and you'll enjoy working here
cons:
It only takes one rotten apple to infect the whole basket
I experienced racism @ BlueKai, but due to visa issues remained quiet, and when it was unbearable, I quietly moved on
Other folks have gone through similar situation - some are still on and while others moved out
Bottomline - If youre joining the PM group, make sure you're not joining the obnoxious PM's team. You'll be taunted, micromanaged and picked on the smallest of things. For instance the oxford comma, the emails, how're managing your time, unclear communication and a great deal of knee jerk reaction from the manager...

review_title: Good Benefits and Culture but Bad Strategy to retain Talent or almost none.
pros:
Probably you will work with the best IT people in your country either technical or functional, and obviously, you will learn a lot.
A lot of benefits, not only in your country even worldwide
They have an amazing Culture, it is not weird to spend probably one or three months working from your home, for example, because you are working on an international project
If you are a Millennial probably this is the place to work
cons:
- They don't have a detailed career plan to follow for you
- They don't try to make you better (0 courses during the year to improve your skills, nothing is prepared, probably if you ask and search a lot you can find something online, but nothing presential and well structured)
- Normally you don't receive any feedback from your superiors
- They don't have a competitive salary for Consulting
- You will just work with Oracle Products and nothing more, Consulting is almost viewed like just a value-add for the Software

pros: Very broad and deep portfolio of IT products, solutions and services. Best kept secret is that the cloud applications (SaaS) portfolio is the richest in the industry. Oracle is also becoming very capable in IaaS and PaaS, in the main matching or exceeding any competitor's cloud services. Oracle hosting centres in place and growing. Oracle holds a lot of potential in the increasingly hybrid cloud world.
cons: Oracle has a poor reputation with some customers and is the subject of some negative industry sentiment, which can be hard to stomach for employees of Oracle.  Customer sentiment is mainly taking aim at *historical* experiences where customer perceives that Oracle has behaved arrogantly in commercial engagements.  Oracle is quite rigid in terms of sticking to policies and internal processes, which often stifles employee engagement, trust and ability to engage with customers in a more responsive and agile way. Read your compensation plan carefully, negotiate your pay well coming onboard, salary increases aren't frequent occurences.

review_title: No less than  a BPO  (Oracle Tech Park Dairy Circle,  Bangalore)
pros: good percent of weekend  and night shift allowance
cons:
Hike with minimal  percent once in 2 years.
No flexibility of work from home.
No work life balance.
Highly  scrutinized  environment like  of a  BPO industry  with  metrics monitoring  /  login - logout  timings.
Bound to do Rotational shifts.
Hell lot of work every single day as they run with  minimal resource staffing.  No  little  relaxed time at all,  be it  new year day or Christmas.
Higher management  had  'we damn care'  attitude  even for the  good performers . 
No  financial  growth  and  career growth  even for the  good performers. 
Last  but  not  the  least, no  gifts at all  for  Diwali  / Christmas  /  New year.

review_title: Good team atmosphere; smart and pleasant people doing exciting work; internal processes could use some improvement...
job_title: Senior Product Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Lots of exciting work getting done by smart and pleasant people.  Good team atmosphere even with teams operating virtually across the globe.
cons: Having joined from a small acquisition, it has been very difficult to get up to speed on what's required to do my job.  Getting information about other teams/parts of company to do my work is very difficult.  Internal aps and info sources are inscrutable - requiring much time to mine.  Even long time veterans don't know much about how to get essential info.   Raises were delayed by months this past year and were not retroactive to the beginning of the new evaluation year.  Bonuses were very small to nothing for my team, which is a pretty strong one.   As in many large companies, some people seem to have very little to do, while others, such as my team, have deliverables and deadlines that wouldn't be possible with 5 X's the number of people.  Technology supporting internal processes is flakey and training on it is abysmal.

review_title: Offers opportunity for a work life balance, but don't expect much influence on salary
job_title: Senior Manager Product Strategy in Redwood City, CA
pros: Oracle is a great place to settle down in.  In general at least in my job, there is a lot of flexibility in the work schedule.  This is mainly due to the fact that it is an international business and many of my colleagues are overseas.  It doesn't make sense to work 9-5 when you have either early morning calls or late night calls with overseas or people on the other coast.
cons: I would not recommend it as a place for a first job though.  The training and people development is not as good as I have seen it.  I used to be a consultant working for the big 5 and at those companies the training is top notch.  I'm lucky that I got that training and development before I came to Oracle.

review_title: Incubation Cell to enhance Technical Experience but monetary benefits  below market par
pros: Flexibility to pick up Technology and work on, Work From Home / Remote options, engagement with customers/partners enables to build good network. Lots of time to learn on technology/products and improve technical skills. Seamless interaction with colleagues over the board and exchange valuable information.
cons: Lack of Direction from Management on individual growth. When compared to market and competitors the salary levels are no match. Lack of transparency and process in appraisal/hike/bonus. No retention plan what so ever. If it takes more than 2 months and sometime 6 months to hire/transfer an employee in the name of approvals something is seriously wrong here. No plans/methodologies/systems to groom future leaders.

pros: Good product set and strong industry reputation as a leader in applications and technology.  If you have a solid territory with strong install base, you will do well.  If you don't, and have the patience to stick it out until you get a better patch, it will eventually pay off.  A lot of sales reps leave for greener pastures and end up coming back, so that must say something.  And if you leave on good terms, they are good about bringing you back.
cons: There is a lot of large corporate BS that you have to deal with, and a lot of infighting between sales pillars selling within the same accounts.  There has been significant change in the sales organizations for the last three years, which only adds to the heartburn because of uncertainty that the accounts you nurture will remain your accounts in the next fiscal year.  Also there tends to be a lot of reps that get their commissions messed up (usually for the worse) which results in an onerous fight to get it fixed.

pros:
Lots of products, the ability to get in and be known at most organizations. Leader in some of the software space.
Lots of upward mobility.
cons:
Bi-Polar comp plans. You don't get to accelerators unless you sell a big expensive piece of hardware, however All Oracle is pushing now is Cloud based products. Two opposing goals in one comp. plan.
Sales Leadership is weak. Mark Hurd does NOT care even a little bit about customers or employees. Only investors. 
If you come thru the Oracle "farm system" you get small raises which put me in a field sales role making 50% less than my peers in the industry. It is called the "loyalty tax".
Endless red tape that actually impedes upon sales.
Support is some of the worst support in the industry and it is expensive.

job_title: MICROS Support Engineer in Lehi, UT
pros:
- As part of the Oracle enterprise, the health benefits and sick time are quite good and the 401K matching is decent, albeit only fully vested after four years.
- The break room is nice, assuming you find time to use it.
- Multiple opportunities to train (allegedly).
cons:
- Micro-management to death: Oracle uses proprietary software to track when you log in, for how long, how many calls you make and take, how long your calls are, how long your breaks are, and how much you're available to take calls. You will be repeatedly hassled if you're not available.
- Training is non-existent: You will be expected to take calls and support a software with meager-at-best training. Training comprised of watching a few video playlists about how to handle service requests. After two months, we finally had an on site person train us for an hour a day for 2 months. During this time we were still expected to take calls.
- Unrealistic expectations: Management's expectations for worker productivity are so high, half the department has been written up, which certainly doesn't improve morale.

review_title: Oracle Amsterdam; Dynamics of a high-energy work place
job_title: Site Leader A'dam Cloud Sales Center in Amsterdam
pros:
- Multi-cultural, high diversity/energy millennial community (19 nationalities, 35% female!)
- The Warehouse (opposite the Maritime museum), our new office as from Sep, in the heart of Amsterdam with the latest & greatest like work- and social zones, video labs, gym and a biological kitchen (take-out food possible)
- Proud sponsor of the Food bank Amsterdam with monthly slots year round for teams to do voluntary work
- Continuous training and possibility to improve your game and learning curve
- AMSTERDAM; home to 180 nationalities, gateway to Europe, center of “dance culture”
- Weekly after work drink "borrel" to close the week on a good note
- Great opp. to tap into business, challenge yourself and improve the resume
- Oracle Women Leadership
- Be part of the “Cloud journey” to become #1 Cloud Vendor WW
- Oracle investment in its people through continuous learning, training and  coaching; many perks inside/outside work
- Big family; exiting fun office environment with respect for each other
- Easy access to EU Leadership Team/executives with our top executive (G. Sangiorgi) regularly working among our people
cons:
-	Improving new hire experience/on boarding – work in progress
-	Processes sound but sometimes lengthy & complex – KISS

pros: Brand name.....its a good resume builder for sure. If you are motivated, self-starter and can build your own network within the company then this is the place for you. If you expect the support or a team to be supporting you constantly then this is not the place you'd enjoy.
cons: If you want the guidance then expect it remotely. No support for growth. You are just a number making the utilization. Decent benefits and good RRSP matching. The folks who have the knowledge are available remotely.... but you struggle reaching out and to get support. So if you are stuck working for a client in Public Sector then its a Dead End for you. The company has switched to Cloud focus. But there is no defined path for you to get there!

job_title: Business Development Consultant in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
The only reason why I kept my sanity is because of my awesome colleagues. There is good camaraderie in my team and on the GBU floor in general. International and young atmosphere.

Good life work balance, start at 8:30 and leave at 5pm. This means you get to have a life outside of this terrible job.
cons:
- Getting in a GBU that works is a complete crap shoot. If you are going for Primavera or Financial Services you will be alright, all the rest is terrible and you will just be fighting against the system

- Self service system is a joke

-Management is really poor. There are two managers for the GBU BDCs, one of which is a micromanager who likes to control your every move and push you over the edge, while the other is really nice and approachable. I sincerely hope you get the latter if you are crazy enough to go for GBU

-Everybody leaves. The best people try to get out of the company, as the progression is slow and basically just about politics.

-Senior management is basically non existant

review_title: Huge IT company with lots of -maybe too many- resources, some great people in the wider organization & a good experience
pros: Lots of internal resources and great colleagues to collaborate with, great initial "Foundation" training in Dublin, lots of learning resources (technical, managerial, etc.). One of the highest compensation scheme in the industry. Great vision and overall execution. Nice offices in the area of Malaga, close to the sea and in driving distance from a skiing resort, Marbella, frequent high-quality sales training. Excellent quality of life.
cons:
No incentive for software sales to collaborate with their hardware counterparts in order to leverage the "Red stack" message and potential benefits for customers.
Too much of a bureaucracy with kind of "permission to sell" processes.
Self-service company (can be listed in Pros sometimes).

review_title: Use this job as a stepping stone to your next
job_title: Inside Sales in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Decent work hours. Great benefits. A wide range of training and personal development resources are available to all employees, so take advantage of it from the get-go. If you do join, go in with a plan and get the experience you need to move on to the next job. Better yet, have that next job in mind so you know exactly what skills you need. Oracle is well known for being a tough place to work, so a decent run here earns you a badge of honor.
cons:
Very political environment with little opportunity to advance unless you're a friend of management.
Many inexperienced micro-managers who only know how to manage by intimidation
Below market salaries, delays in comp plans, and lots of problems getting paid correctly on commissions. 
Growing trend of offshoring inside sales to low cost centers.

review_title: Too much bureaucracy and very old tech stack
job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros:
Work-life balance
Lots of benefits
DB group has lot of new projects. Pay/Bonuses are really good if you join one of the teams in DB.
cons:
Not fit for new grads
You don't learn new things until you take initiative
Some of the older people are dinosaurs. They live in their own world and do not like talking about newer technologies as they are not comfortable around them.
Managers lack mgmt skills and no effort is taken to learn them.
You are stuck with the same pay grade even if you get promoted. Get hold off another offer letter if you want a raise or stay at the same pay grade forever.
A lot of communication gap between teams. 
People don't give good advice. They do their work and leave for home. There are no mentorship opportunities and code reviews are just formalities.

review_title: Make your way for an easy ride now, but uncertain future
pros: Oracle takes tremendous care of its sales engineering team from a financial perspective.   While you will be put into a salary band based on your profile, skills, and experience, there is really good upside if you are tied to the right products.  There are many benefits such as a car allowance, overtime pay, and more that are hard to find or beat in the industry today.
cons: Massive bureaucracy as expected with a large company, requires knowledge of corporate politics, and navigation.  Half of your sale will be devoted to selling to your internal audience rather than customer.   The cutthroat environment creates significant internal strife and competition, therefore collaboration and team building is not necessarily fostered.  Not sure it is best for the customer or the company in the long run.  As far as the SE role, it is easy to get pigeon hold, particularly if you came through an acquisition.

review_title: Great to get your foot in the door, or great to come back to later in your career
pros:
-Very structured (could be a con, but if this is an introductory sales job, it can be very helpful)
-Pay is relatively competitive for an entry level sales position, albeit it is hard to make your number during your first year
-Very fun if you have a good manager and solid team
-Campus offers a gym, multiple restaurants, and good running trails
-One of the best sales training programs in the industry (MAJOR PLUS for introductory salespeople)
cons:
-Managers are really more like micromanagers
-If you don't have a good territory, it is very hard to hit your number, and you've left with your base pay (which isn't that much by itself)
-Very hard to get any kind of base pay raise
-Doesn't have the "fun" atmosphere of most other tech companies (if that's what you're looking for)
-You definitely feel like a cog in the wheel... Oracle does not care whether you come or go, and most individuals that I know leave before their first 2 years is up
-Quality of life at Oracle is heavily dependent on whether or not you have a friendly manager and team

job_title: Applications Sales Representative in Burlington, MA
pros: Great people, good pay if you get lucky.
cons: In my time at Oracle I watched coworkers get emotionally bullied by their direct manager (regardless of performance, which in 2/3 cases was not an issue), saw a coworker get a promotion, then have it taken away from her after she had started the new role, I saw a guy with 0 integrity and pathetic quota attainment get promoted to field because he was a part of "the boys club," and day after day, saw shady field reps put their names on deals they had nothing to do with and rake in $10, $20, $30k checks while their hardworking inside sales counterparts get paid little to nothing on these same deals. This place is so crooked, and the management teams pretend they have no power to change it. Oracle is losing the cloud game. Oracle could not care less about its employees. The class of program is the biggest sham/waste of money I have ever, unfortunately, been a part of. Recruiters and interviewers lie about the BDC/SMD/SBD roles to get butts in seats because turnover is so high. Burlington, MA is a hell hole for millennials. I could go on forever....

pros: Open and frank culture. Corporate invests in maintaining its solid culture of social ethics and mutual respect.
cons: The only reward is "good job" words from top to bottom through management. Oracle doesn't believe in real rewards such as pay increase or moving up the hierarchy in professional growth. Unless you happen to be the 2% of lucky and successful sales who can and do potentially earn more from commissions. You are expected to work 60+ hours per week including odd hours and weekends when needed.

review_title: Made redundant, like over 50 others at the time, and was selling cloud?
job_title: Inside Sales Representative II in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Health care covered, Flexi system is handy, nice desk if that is a bonus, nothing else really, nice location and nice food that can easily cost nice money without realising
cons: Ineffective management, uncooperative and honestly do not care about anything outside of the Oracle bubble, unaware of the competition alot if the time making the sales process a bit like a false positive pregnancy test, exciting till you realise it's a mistake and customer is annoyed by the constant over pricing and tactics,  not customer focused in my opinion,  to many processes just to get a quote out

pros: I can share my perspectives with respect to product dev org in Oracle India. Donno much about other orgs(some 20 are there...product dev consists of just 1 or 2)There are diverse products/technologies available to work in. They were not really built by oracle but nonetheless it owns it and they all have been best of breed. Lots of developmental/design efforts are continuously going on, which keeps you learning all the time. And that means learning real good stuffs. I work as product dev engineer in Siebel and the work is nice. Compensation is pretty decent. Nobody minds the hours you work at your conveience (you have to work pretty long hours though) , the result is what counts(you have to explain ofcourse in case you take longer than expected..no free lunch there). Overall, I would certainly recommend joining oracle.
cons: Long hours. IT infrastructure is not very good in Siebel prod dev..not sure about other groups. Somehow, it is recruiting a lot of very avg. engineersfrom private unknown institutions just to ramp up the operations fast, which is not a good thing.

pros:
The base salaries are higher as at the competitors.
It's a good place, if you don't have any ambitions, and need a stable job with a good salary.
cons:
We were a small company bought by the Oracle one year ago. The main part of the company only sales the products, but we are developers. The infrastructure is bad, the expenses are minimized. (We were unable to buy a RAM modul even in our laptops within one year.) The bonus and salary changes are not based on your work, my manager is never asked. For example I've got a higher position for the same salary, no bonus. Everybody else got 10 percent annual bonus and 10% salary incrase remaining in the same position. Explanation: "Somebody made a mistake". :)

It's true only for our small developer team. It can be different to work in the main part (sales) of the company. Maybe we can't fit into the organization.

review_title: Take this job if you want to earn half what they pay the person next to you.
pros: At first I liked the prospects of working for a multinational corporation, now, a few years later I have changed my mind.  Although the cafeteria and health benefits make it worthwhile for now.
cons: The work environment is stifling with little job satisfaction. My colleagues with the same job title earn twice the salary for performing the same duties, many had the same start date and no more experience or knowledge than myself. Other coworkers with the same job title make triple my salary.  I have been told by management that there is no room for advancement, promotion, or wage increase within my current department.  However, you will not see the same dissatisfaction from my colleagues that hold the same job title of equal performance  that earn twice my salary. Oracle management seems content to pay a portion of the department higher salaries to perform the same job that I do.

review_title: Good place to work, if u don't worry about lower than industry standard salary
pros:
-Good exposure to enterprise software applications development
-How things work in a big software company; like version control, build management, release management, various aspects of SDLC
-Good work life balance
-Very relaxed environment
-You usually get promotions every 2-3 years if you perform decently well
-You directly can talk to customers: good experience
cons:
-Hikes are not great
-Benefits are not great
-Internal transfers are very difficult : It's easier to leave company that trying to join a different team. Moreover, you may have to compromise on the Salary as well because of transfer
-Code quality is really bad. Not much emphasis is laid on it good software practices. Not much to learn in terms of software programming. On contrary, you might become too lazy after working here for a few years. When you quit Oracle, you'll usually find it very difficult to cope up with the work pressure in the new company as no other works at such a relaxed pace.
-No knowledge sharing across teams
-Few personality development programs

pros: Great team, Vision to see big financial rewards, Good immediate leadership, Team shows a lot of potential to grow, The company in itself offers a lot of options
cons: Higher Leadership conflicts in mentality- very confusing to have one Manager say one thing, and their manager to say the complete opposite. ODP in APAC has been put together very rapidly- with seemingly little thought. We have all been thrown in the deep end and management have scrambled to throw pieces of lifesaving equipment- it is surprising that more people have not thrown in the towel so far. Internal processes are impossible to deal with. Commissions are not guaranteed and base salary is what you need to be able to live off for months.

review_title: A place to launch and end your career
pros:
* Work Life Balance is awesome, except for cases when you are working for a manager who doesn't understand what are the benefits of working for Oracle.
* A beautiful camps that is a landmark of Silicon Valley.  It is very well maintained.
* Great Gymnasium.
* An aggressive CEO with a vision, a well defined market strategy, zeal to kill competition, and an innate capability of eeking out profit margins for the share holders.
cons:
* In many divisions  of the business, employees are treated as resources, and not human beings.
* No culture to breed innovation from within Oracle.  Innovation is happening at Oracle because of acquisition. 
* Employees/Engineers have to create their own challenges, unless your division is under the focus of the office of the CEO.
* Teams stay together as a group for many many years.  Hence no exposure to other team members with different skills.
* Managers typically lack skills to motivate and excite the teams and people.  They work for themselves and promote themselves.

review_title: Great retirement company with good work life balance
pros: Flexible timings and good work life balance. Sexist remark: "But its an amazing company for women". Carrier growth is faster if your perform. Subscription to good online resources if you want to learn. Work will be good if you are in a good team. Encourages higher education while you still continue to work.
cons:
The work life balance is a trade off offered for lesser than industry average growth. No wonder Oracle is a great grooming school for Amazon, Microsoft and Google and also IIM's. 
Legacy software maintenance, this can be a nightmare for you if you want to create something new. Most of the good teams (Server technology group) are in Bangalore and most of the R&D effort happens in the US. 
Campus recruits from tier one colleges are looked upon as candidates already having higher salaries compared to veterans. Don't expect to grow at-least for couple of years. 
Some managers also earn less than their subordinates. 
You can find managers with minimal technical know how and just gather updates. Don't expect mentor ship.

review_title: Oracle has been a great company to work for.  People are great, schedule is flexible, opportunities in many groups.
job_title: QA Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: Flexible schedule in order to accommodate a global company.  Working remote has been great, and a necessity with a global team.  Advancement opportunities are available, but sometimes hard to find.  Always new projects that keep employees interested.
cons: It is a very political atmosphere and sometimes, there can be a lot of negativity and low morale because some managers seem to lack basic management skills in keeping their employees engaged in work or maintaining a work life balance.

job_title: Principal Applications Engineer in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Good Benefits: 18 Days Vacation, 401k matching, Health Benefits, Occasional Work from Home, Flexible Hours.
cons:
No salary increments for 5 years.  Salary scale below market.  Company doesn't care for loyal employees.   Only a few departments like Cloud, Database, Fusion gets the attention from upper management and gobble up all the bonuses and hikes.  Applications, Peoplesoft and other low key projects get nothing.  

Poor management style - Micro Management, A lot of dev managers have no people management skills.  They will suck the blood out of you.    I had one, who made my life miserable, eventually made me quit the company.  Be careful not to be reporting to such a manager.  If you get one, move out as soon as possible.

Late night meetings, coordinating with IDC (India) and CDC (China) teams will keep you at work till late night almost 3 days a week.  You cannot escape this in any team.  Almost every team has a counterpart in one or both the countries.

review_title: Do not invest time in your career at Oracle
pros: cannot think of any at this time
cons:
- sales culture is thankless and toxic
- they have missed the cloud
- customers do not want to do business with Oracle due to lack of trust, dated maintenance fees, overly cumbersome and complicated contracts, confusion between different regions and countries all trying to own the same deal
-I can't think of anyone who worked for me or who I know who still works at Oracle who actually wants to be there
- so much churn of reps and managers means constant account/exec sponsor transitions which has lead to customers scratching their heads as to why Oracle can't keep hire people
-B, C players and below since top talent knows of the reputation and issues
-forecasting is non existent 
- never had a 1:1 with my manager - every conversation was a business review
- never any downtime

job_title: OD Sales Representative in Austin, TX
pros: Great support system, access to resources, great benefits, great facility
cons: The opportunity for career progression and a lucrative sales career is greatly diminishing with the company moving its salesforce to a "class of" model- which is despite what Mark Hurd publicly states is primarily intended to lower wages and shrinking field headcount towards a primarily inside sales model selling cloud subscriptions. Rather than paying the most capable sales reps in the market commensurate with the value they bring, Oracle continues to hire armies of Business Development Reps days out of college with no IT background, who through no fault of their own add no value to the company and if anything are counterproductive in their requirement to harass customers who are already being called by the sales reps in all divisions of Oracle.

review_title: I've worked here for about 2 1/2 months and am already wanting to leave.
job_title: Internet Sales Representative II in Austin, TX
pros: The pay can be great and the health benefits are very good. There are free soft drinks which is nice.
cons: There is a "self service" model set up for finding everything. This makes it difficult to figure out how to do some of the most basic tasks. The sales cycle is extremely slow and deals can take a very long time to close. I won't see my first commission check till Sept/Oct and I started in May. Management expects pipeline management and account updates despite the reps having little to no knowledge about the account. Customers aren't our biggest fans because the pricing is crazy high and the licensing agreements are extremely confusing. Compensation is cut throat and there is an adversarial relationship between the inside and outside team. If deal sizes are over a certain amount (this is the swim lane where it could go one way or the other) then inside sales may lose the deal and get paid out a much smaller portion than the AE. This competitive structure is counterproductive because it makes the inside rep want to keep deals from getting too large.

pros:
- Disclaimer: Company bought by Oracle, my company is Oracle MICROS
- Traveled to new places
- People at company are friendly and very willing to help
- Can learn a lot in short period of time
- Oracle themselves is great: Great benefits (pay for phone, 401k, healthcare, provide free instructional classes online encourages you to learn on your own)
cons:
- Communication between levels is not great
- Treated as a number and name and not as a person many times. They can grind you with work hours (was doing 100 hour weeks consistently three weeks of the month for most of the year)
- Pay is not great and is not consistent between seniority or even work performance (no annual appraisers. New hires will make more and management will not increase your salary to match)
- job notifications and travel dates can be given one day in advance making it hard to make plans in life

pros: The money is good. There is a lot of possibility for mobility within. If you like being a number, it might be the perfect place for you.
cons: Oracle calls it self-service, but what it really comes down to is Oracle doesn't care. You will onboard on your own, learn on your own and survive on your own. There are 20 cooks in the kitchen and all are pulling on different ropes. No one is on the same page. Oracle acts like it invented the cloud, when in fact the rest of the industry sans SAP has been in the cloud business for years. Some of the products are pretty good, most are pretty mediocre. So, if you just want to make a bunch of money, go to Oracle and make some money. Don't expect Oracle to care one way or the other, though. And when you leave, make sure you're ready because Oracle won't do anything but the bare minimum required by law upon your exit.

- job notifications and travel dates can be given one day in advance making it hard to make plans in life

cons: Oracle calls it self-service, but what it really comes down to is Oracle doesn't care. You will onboard on your own, learn on your own and survive on your own. There are 20 cooks in the kitchen and all are pulling on different ropes. No one is on the same page. Oracle acts like it invented the cloud, when in fact the rest of the industry sans SAP has been in the cloud business for years. Some of the products are pretty good, most are pretty mediocre. So, if you just want to make a bunch of money, go to Oracle and make some money. Don't expect Oracle to care one way or the other, though. And when you leave, make sure you're ready because Oracle won't do anything but the bare minimum required by law upon your exit.

review_title: Get ready for a bumpy ride.
pros: The brand is highly regarded by other companies and recruiters.
cons:
The three Ts of sales (Territory, Timing and Talent) are what makes or breaks you.

Territories are remarkably unfair cut. Do not get fouled the majority of reps will never! make their target and thats not due to a lack of trying. (Amsterdam is an expensive city if you live of your base salary...).

Timing becomes a gamble due to very long sales circles.

Talent can’t overcome the bad territories and bad timing.

Moreover the company change the compensation plan, to their favor within an ongoing fiscal!! Meaning you got less for your deals than agreed on before...

Within 2 years the new department was started and closed. All 40 employees who were recruited from Germany lost their job. 

The office was transferred 4! times during this period.

The company is claiming to produce state of the art IT, but runs itself on 80s corporate IT. Tools are even crashing on their own! Java products.

In general internal process make up a the lion share of your task. Talk about selling internally rather than to external.

Career improvement is difficult because your manager will change every year, which means starting from scratch.  

It is a difficult place that will you leave cynical and emotionally drained.

job_title: Senior AI Engineer in Beijing, Beijing
pros:
1. Personal enrichment: working at Oracle might not be as competitive as FANG, but if you want more time for personal growth in terms of tech skills, This is the best place on planet earth.
2. option for Work From Home: sometimes you can work from home if you really needed to. People at Oracle are extremely kind. As long as you get your job done, we do offer flexible working hours.
3. Working environment: the office is super nice. everyone has a separate block. So far it is the most comfortable office I ever had.
4. Oracle offers the most comprehensive benefits among all Companies in China. Such a great company.
5. Only 8 hours a day. Unlike those 996 internet companies in China. We only require ppl to work 8 hours each day. Your career will be long and health here at Oracle.
cons: 1. basically not a lot of things changes at Oracle. It is very much matured. But it also means this is a good working pace for someone who is age above 30. Oracle is number one for work/life balance.

review_title: Some teams have great work. Pay can be skewed toward cloud teams.
job_title: Senior Product Manager in Redwood Shores, CA
pros:
Great for work-life balance and the comfort of job security
Pivotal moment in time as a Cloud vendor. We're not leading right now, but are positioned to become huge in the cloud which is exciting.
Nice HQ office, with a killer gym
They do take employee feedback somewhat seriously.
cons: Most of the concerns of a huge company. Getting things done takes time, influencing big strategic changes is very very difficult. There's no concept of feedback or evaluation of one's performance, and in turn no bonuses or raises. Raises and promotions are basically bound to the number of years you spend here. There is little to motivate you to perform better except the love for your work itself.

job_title: Business Development Representative in Denver, CO
pros:
-Resume Builder
-Lots of young employees, fun environment, easy to make friends
cons:
-Misrepresentation of PTO. They say you get X number of PTO days but fail to mention that some of those will be forced PTO as the office is closed, and no you can't work from home. You don't get Christmas Eve off, seriously, who is going to take a sales call on Christmas Eve?
-They have call competitions among the BDR's but everyone is logging fake phone calls to win. 
-BDR's "cheat" to hit quota, working leads that are not in there territory.
-AE's misrepresent the annual revenue of leads they are working so that it looks like they are in their territory. This fosters a hostile work environment with AE's fighting over leads and arguing with BDR's.
-The BDE team is an absolute joke, the meetings they put on for the BDR's are time sucks and not at all valuable. 
-They hire more BDR's than they have the bandwidth to promote, pushing out many BDR's once their year is up. Churning and burning through sales employees.

pros: Salary is good and better than other companies.
cons: The emotion is not good.

review_title: Oracle - We make investment bankers look warm and fuzzy
job_title: Business Development Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: To learn sales from the best in the business. By far the biggest reason to work at Oracle, particularly in sales and marketing, is the world class training you will receive, both on the job and in the classroom. Every technology company has a culture, Oracle's is a sales driven culture. Big deals make this company tick. You won't find bleeding edge technical innovation at Oracle. No, instead you will work alongside the most successful and well paid sales professionals of any Fortune 1000. Top field sales reps him earn well over $1 million a year with bonus, but their tenure is typically short-lived, unless they can keep that pipeline full. As a result the company attracts the top sales professionals in the field. Come to Oracle if you want to learn sales, but don't think of Oracle as a technology company. It is not.
cons: Ruthless, take no prisoners culture. Willing to do anything for enough money.

review_title: You need to be self sufficient and prepared for no or little management interaction.
pros: The have an extensive software product line.  You could learn JD Edwards, Peoplesoft, Hyperion, and Siebel. If management permits, you have opportunities learn products that may further your career.  The company name will look good on your resume.  The benefits are comparable for a company of this size.
cons:
They view employees strictly as headcount.  A person can get lost in all the bureaucracy.  The current bonus structure for consulting does not compete with other services organizations.  If you do not like large organizations, then this is not the company for you.  If you are joining as a consultant, then you need to come in with a solid base salary.  The bonus' have not been that good since I have been with them.  
There seems to be a reorganization every other quarter.  When it comes time for an annual review some people will have had 3+ managers in a 12 month period.

pros: Freedom, flexibility and professionalism is best in Oracle.  Apart from this, the culture is very friendly, people are highly supportive which makes Oracle a great place to be.  It is upto the individual.  If somebody is highly ambitious and also gets a good manager, then there is no stopping.  Highly ambitious and bad manager, you are doomed.  If this somebody is laid back and just does the work - a perfect place to be.
cons: Highly manager driven and no skip level at all.  Performance reviews are not done in some of the groups and how the salary is reviewed is totally unknown.  In some groups one can also see a lot of favouritism and its difficult to break and grow up purely based on performance because end of it all, its your manager who will be rating you.

review_title: Don't start your career at Oracle. Get used to the saying "Life is not fair".
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros: Stability, Good Health Benefits, Oracle HQ Gym, great landscaping, beautiful campus. If you want to cruise in your career, concentrate on other things while still holding a job, this is the place.
cons: Salaries are low, professionaly growth is bad, not a good place to start your career. No recognition for performing well. Rewards are hardly in line with performance. Management cannot explain why you were not rewarded even for doing well, low and middle management is pointing towards upper management (Maybe Larry is to be blamed for everything?). Employee moral is low, everyone talks against the company (but they still stick around!)

review_title: Mostly happy, but for the money
pros: Oracle is a solid, stable company, doing some fairly innovative things, especially considering its size.  There's a good bit of opportunity, and you can succeed if you work hard and have talent.
cons: Pay, and politics.  Raise pools have been extremely weak over the past few years, and apparently will stay that way as long as we keep buying companies.  Part of the problem is they're trying to keep cash on hand for M&A activity, and part of the problem is all the new companies we buy come with people making much higher than Oracle-average salaries, which skews the #'s for the rest of us.  On the politics side, Oracle management culture puts far too much weight on titles and the number of employees a manager has, resulting in a tendency toward premature promotions, power grabs and cutthroat reorgs.

review_title: Good place to work if you are looking for stability, not good if you are looking for professional growth.
job_title: Business Development Consultant in Mississauga, ON
pros: It's a global company, leader in it's field, always looking ahead, it has recognition in the market, sometimes to the level that it is overwhelming for clients.
cons: It's just a branch, no meaningful opportunities for professional advancement within Canada.  In particular Oracle Direct, it is considered as the 'call center' of Oracle, and eventhough your senior management will be requiring you to be strategic in your work, the compensation only compensates the ones who meet the metrics (eg. average 50 calls per day, etc)  If you can't deliver that on a consistent manner, you could be in serious problems.

review_title: Beware what you are getting into. Slash and burn rules.
pros: Talented people overall and smart engineering folks. Ability to learn a lot and stay current with new trends and technology. Good benefits. Life work balance OK, but expectations are high.
cons:
This is not the company I joined years ago. Too many employees no longer have the  common good as a goal, but rather their own personal interest. Politics (and favoratism) galore. Do not expect much in salary increase or bonus even if you do a good job. HR's view is "people must be happy because they stay"
Oracle gets rid of people all the time, year round with little or no explanation (good or bad performance does not seem to matter in this respect).  They have no qualms in getting rid of hundreds of people if that helps in propping up the quarter end numbers. Meanwhile the fat cats are getting fatter.

job_title: Product Management Director in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Oracle has a very nice gym, and there are lots of very experienced people to work with. The pace is slow, so if you are looking to spend more time on other interest or with family, Oracle is a great place to hang out.
cons:
Stupendous bureaucracy. Really. Process checks on top of process checks on top of process checks. It is not possible to be responsive to customer needs or competitive threats in this environment. 

Many companies in Silicon Valley have an HR policy that basically boils down to "Not Oracle". After joining, I understand why. Oracle is very hierarchical and status-bound. You need to kindly ask assistants to talk to anyone VP-level or above. There are tables where you look up you pay grade to see when you can travel business class and whether you get an office or a cubicle.

There is no leadership: as a Director or VP you don't have any inside info on the agenda. You will get your best information from earnings calls. 

Oh, and don't think you can escalate to senior management if someone isn't doing the best thing for the firm: you need to come with something to trade with.

review_title: Oracle has some of the smartest and most experienced software engineers in the industry.
job_title: Product Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: Oracle is a very big company, with ~120K employees, so my experiences don't necessarily apply across the board. In my group - a technology development team at the heart of the company - we have flexible work hours, and flexibility with working at home as needed, Compensation is competitive, and very much loaded into the base salary. The primary goal is to remove compensation from the daily concerns of employees, and to provide long term stability.
cons: The primary downside of working for Oracle are the mis-perceptions of outsiders, especially in the area of technology innovation. The perception of most people seems to be that Oracle is so big and "old" / legacy that it's not possible for us to be innovative, or disruptive, or to do anything but follow in the path of smaller, more nimble, more innovative startups etc. Nothing could be further from the truth, but it's "accepted wisdom" in most circles, even within Silicon Valley.

job_title: Software Development Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: It is a technology Mecca to learn new things, engineers are very smart but unfortunately these engineers are not recognized since the directors, senior directors, VPs are dead weight in this company since they have no clue on what’s going on. These mid-level management are all concerned about their survival hence the politics overshadows the individual contributors.
cons: This is one of the worst companies ever I worked for. They keep acquiring companies and has been disastrous in integrating them. This company has the worst culture ever and people are identified based on the company from where they come, people in Oracle never embrace the new people who come onboard when their existing company gets bought over by Oracle. There is no recognition or bonus or raises for last couple years, the middle mangement (director to all the way up) are filled with bunch of morons and idiots who has no clue on the company’s direction or strategy. Mid-level Management is bloated.

pros: Solid company who knows what it is doing and provides best of breed products. However, some business units are better than others. Oracle is shifting to become a cloud company so traditional businesses are not recommended. Everyone is intelligent and experienced, albeit older so do not expect a younger, vibrant environment. Everything is self-service. It's not similar to other companies where people are willing to help you. Everyone will just direct you back to a "portal". In some ways, it is great for people who have are industrious and hungry to learn.
cons: It's highly bureaucratic, you need to network and know people to get any promotion or lateral shift internally. Managers are hired for who they know and how long they've worked vs how good they are as leaders. Basic salary is quite low comparatively, and increments are rare so make sure you negotiate. There's also not much room for upward career growth, unless you move laterally to another business unit.

job_title: Director of Sales in San Francisco, CA
pros: Can’t really think of anything positive to say even though I exceeded quota over the 3 years there as a rep and manager after being acquired.
cons: You really are a number at Oracle. They don’t invest in their own talent as shown by inability to provide raises from internal hires.  For example, I could hire someone from the outside for a rep role for 120k/120k but could barely get someone we trusted to move from inside sales role 75k/75k.  And there is always more risk and expense by bringing someone from the outside. I was an honest employee and oracle came after me for 400 dollars worth of expenses even though I submitted all my expense reports prior to leaving. Also messing up on commissions was the norm and good luck getting them to pay you what is owed. In the 300 page comp plan, it protects them to withhold commissions etc. it is also common for lifers as we called them to sit on crm and wait for a deal to almost e closing to then state that it is owned by some private equity firm and that the deal should fall in their territory. This happened multiple times to my team.

review_title: Management taking a turn for the worse
pros: The pay is good, and so are the benefits.
cons:
To get a great pay, you need to work long hours. I have been working 65 hrs+ per week for the past 8 months. Not only have I been working long hours, but management seems to turn a blind eye. They have never once reached out to see how I was doing while I have been slaving away. 

To top it off, my manager was just recently changed without any communication coming from my previous or existing manager. It has now been a month, and nobody has still reached out to let me know officially, I had to figure it out on my own.

To top it off, my career growth has been completely stunted. I am asked to work on many internal projects that advance our department, and receive no recognition. I am working with one of our largest customers, and nobody stops to ask me how it is going. It's almost as if Oracle views me as a cost rather than a benefit to the company.

review_title: Get some experience in writing world class products and leave. There is no one here to appreciate you or care for you.
job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros: One will be exposed to develop world class enterprise applications. There are very few companies that do such a large scale applications. Learn them while you were there. Your hard work is really appreciated by your peers.  But don't expect to get any growth. One can grow when you stop working and just do talking. One should learn to play politics.  If you just work silently and solve the company problems, no one cares for you and you will stay without any promotions.  Keep in mind to negotiate a good starting salary. No one gets a good raise after joining.  Company cares about the shareholders rather than employees.  So, don't get too much emotional with the company. You are paid for your work "period"
cons: Hardwork or smart people stay at the bottom of the hierarchy. One has to play politics to grow up the ladder.

review_title: Good employees not valued and worked into the ground
pros:
Pay if you come in high enough 
IT team great.  Offices if you are lucky enough to get one
cons: No value for good/great employees.  You are expendable.  No matter how hard you work, it is never enough and you can't keep up with the OT needed.  You cannot ask help of anyone.  Even Assistants are hard to come by and very childish and unwilling to be kind.  Only a handful even at svp level are not terribly rude and calculating.  You are kicked out of offices or cubes at their whim without ANY notice or respect towards you even VP level.  You are easily replaced even if stellar.  No one will fight for you even with a 5 out of 5 review -- No one

pros: Some get the opportunity to work from home with significant autonomy.  Excellent benefits (health, etc) and high salary is also possible (though most complain of the opposite).  There's so much to learn and experience across so many technologies, industries, roles and locations.
cons: Too many people who are useless and don't do much at all, but seem to survive at the company for many years.  Hopeless lack of innovation, direction or strategy across senior and exec management.  Management by spreadsheet leading to inexplicable decision-making.  Middle and senior managers who are too scared of being shot down by their own managers to ever stick their neck out.

review_title: It's a job, not a career.
job_title: Senior Sales Consultant in Kansas City, MO
pros: Oracle has some cool tech and is well positioned with Java for the coming Internet of Things revolution.  Benefits are great and very cheap to the employee.  I have met some great people and that is honestly the best part of my time at Oracle.
cons: No raises, ever, not even to keep up with inflation.  Career Development is lacking as well.  The biggest tech problem is that we completely missed the boat on Cloud and became a hardware company and went after Engineered Systems.  We should have bought Salesforce instead of Sun, although having Weblogic and Java in the portfolio is nice.  Maybe just sold off the hardware stuff after buying Sun.  Starting vacation at 2.5 weeks for your first 3 years, regardless of experience, is cheap too.  Honestly, I wouldn't be leaving if I was 10-15 years older and planning to retire in the next 3-4 years.

job_title: Inside Applications Sales Representative in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Although Oracle is clearly huge, the sales org is broken up into smaller individual product groups, and then into account size (mid-market, up-market). So although we may have 1000 sales reps at headquarters in Redwood City, you work directly with about 50 people. Due to heavy college recruiting, it's a young atmosphere. Fairly slow paced environment as well when considering some of the very intense sales orgs in the SF Bay Area. Have the opportunity to make a lot of money, base is low but some reps will double that in commission.
cons: There is a lot of turnover from the college hires, so it is sort of a revolving door of people. Not really a bad thing, there are just so many opportunities in this area. Base is a little low for the area average and prestigiousness of the opportunity.

review_title: Good place to jumpstart a career in technology
job_title: Associate Sales Consultant in Austin, TX
pros: Oracle is investing heavily into entry-level talent by means of product and functional training. Obtaining a position as an Associate Sales Consultant at Oracle out of college is almost like college all over again. You are hired in a "class" of people your age from some of the best schools in the country, you receive extensive training and provided ample time to "ramp up," and the job isn't as demanding as investment banking or implementation/management consulting. It's a great balance and pays well.
cons: It's easy to get comfortable in this position. You're paid well, Oracle allows a long "ramp up" period where getting fired is actually difficult, and you're given all the resources your need to be successful. It's easy to sit back and relax. Also, Oracle isn't the happiest place to work. Negatively pollutes some pockets of the company.

review_title: Nice place to work but not in the long-term
job_title: Applications Developer II in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros:
- Flexible schedule.
- A lot of good benefits.
- In the best part of the city.
- Nice initial pay.
- Relocation bonus i you come from another state.
- Very smart people to work with.
- Some teams make their employees travel a lot and/or take courses, certifications and conferences.
- You can apply to swap teams after being here for a year or a year and a half.
cons:
- Depending on the team you could get stuck responding to support tickets.
- The code base for some products is very outdated.
- The company takes too long to adapt to an ever evolving market.
- Few and low pay raises.
- Promotions don't necessarily mean you'll get a significant raise.
- New employees could start earning more than someone that's been in the company for 5 years, for example.
- The recruiting process can take a few weeks or several months, it depends on the team you are applying for and it's very inconsistent.

pros: legacy health care is good. but it's just a paycheck, if you don't care about your job or integrity you'll survive
cons: oracle has historically and continues to "go cheap" . do not expect any raises, ever. be prepared to lie & cheat your way to success, just google hurd's background and how he got hired from hp. oracle is now working to "shed" older well paid legacy employees in favor of cheap Eastern Euro and APAC "warm bodies". evaluations are now based on automated nitpicking (didn't answer the phone fast enough) or complaints from "out of scope/ beyond contract" requests instead of real feedback from actual paying customers. oracle is expecting senior grades to train in their cheap entry level APAC replacements before they are "let go".. Oracle has also dumped well paid good performing senior sales teams for new grads staffing "cold call sales centers".

review_title: Oracle is a good place to work overall
job_title: Senior Principal Consultant in Orlando, FL
pros: Good benefits, good base pay, ok culture. Although a sales culture there is a lot of decent technical focus and a lot of smart people to learn from. Oracle's negative reputation is somewhat overblown, the work environment is fast paced but there is a culture of balance and technical talent can be developed if the employee seeks mentors and training.
cons: bad reputation among some pros, small raises/raises held/bonuses held too often, difficult to move up within department without lateral move, slow to change, self-service culture is taken to extreme sometimes making it difficult to get answers or costing a lot of time on the part of the employee execute a process that is unfamiliar.

review_title: Good work life balance but slow growth
pros:
1. Domain wise good exposure
2. Uses most of the time oracle products
3. Good for Java and oracle database guys as most of the products are using these technologies
4. No delivery pressure as long as you have a valid justification
5. work from home facility but again it depends on your repo with your reporting manager
6. Top management mandates all products to get migrated to cloud-based technologies but implementation is slow.
cons:
1. Adoption of new technology or cutting edge technology(cloud/big data/machine learning etc) is  slow
2. Better to bargain a good salary at the time of joining, later very less hike.

review_title: OK Projects, only one good team in 5 years, inexperienced Project Managers and long time consultants set in their ways.
pros: Oracle offers a good benefits package at a great price.  The medical, dental, life and disability are some of the best you can find and the cost is very low in comparison to other consulting firms.  I can't think of other good reasons to work for Oracle.  Awesome deal if you travel and are paid hourly as a Senior Consultant.
cons: Slow to give pay increases even after the company is making money and increased license sales quarter after quarter.  Slow to recognize employee's for their hard work and consultants are encouraged to work in areas outside their skill set creating unfavorable work conditions and poor representation to customers.

review_title: Oracle - Good Company, But Be Careful
pros: Oracle is a profitable company which is a good thing in today's IT environment.   Sales reps have great opportunities to make significant incomes.   Oracle offers very good benefits.  Good family/work balance (working from home).
cons: Management is too controlling.  Approvals have to be made way up to senior management for everything.  This slows processes significantly.  Manager needs to be empowered to make decisions.   Acquisition of Sun was not handled well from the employee standpoint.  Tough transition with little direction and feedback to be productive in the new environment.   Oracle did not seem to value the acquired employees.  Disappointing.

review_title: A place for information hungry perfectionists
pros: Great place for learning and improving your skills. Everyone is highly qualified in their field,  dedicated to their jobs and helpful. The company's culture is very process oriented with most tasks done on your laptop without human interaction. Working from home is highly encouraged and allows for a flexible schedule. The company is very committed to diversity and fosters a professional and understanding culture.
cons: Of course, this is a high pressure environment and the processes to perform any activity can be very complex and bureaucratic. Approvals for anything can take a very long time. The first year is very tough as you have to learn so much about the company, the processes and the products. The company is driven by quarterly results which can lead to knee jerk reactions in bad times. Flip side of working remotely is very little personal interaction with coworkers.

review_title: Oracle is an experience to live...Some love it others don't but to know you need to try
pros:
Oracle is a great company to work for. It 's a famous company known for the quality of its products. if you are successful there, many companies will want you to join them.
A step there will definitely boost your career, within or outside Oracle... Lots of amazing trainings are available (Sales, self development, product trainings...). Oracle Direct is a safe place to learn and  grow.
cons:
Oracle is a huge company where there are many processes to know before being able to perform well. To get things done it can take ages. Franz Kafka is never far... You accept this fact or you leave..no other option.
As in all big companies, you need to play the game and have a great strategy to get promoted...
Your performance will allow you to be seen, your strategy will allow you to move forward!!!!

review_title: Excellent company, but bureaucratic and no room for promotions
pros:
You are working for a major technology company. Expect access to many resources and be able to move internally to work with different business groups and products.

This is probably one of the best companies I have worked for. You can get the most of it if you really look for the opportunities. You will be placed in several high profile customers and is able to interact with people from around the world.
cons:
Promotions rarely happen, when they do it takes an enormous amount of time to get thru management and when they come, you are already ready for another one. Salary increases does not happen often as well as bonuses payouts (they are always late and never are fulfilled at 100%).

Several acquisitions that are not always completed 100% internally which makes internal processes extremely bureaucratic and slow.

job_title: University Account Manager in Reston, VA
pros: Oracle is a great company with a lot of stability.  You never have to worry about Oracle being bought out.  There are clear titles, roles, and expectations laid out so there are no real surprises or "reorganizations".  You are able to put your head down and work hard with little distractions.  The benefits package is also one of the best I have ever seen.
cons: Along with being a large company comes tough upward mobility and career potential.  Oracle knows it is a world leader and compensation is slightly under industry average.  Oracle also does not give raises in sales.  You must be promoted to receive a bump in your base.  Oracle is very set in it's rules as well so being flexible for customers is difficult at times.

pros:
This company was there when the internet wasn't even a thing. At this moment there are about 130.000 employees world wide, working for Oracle. The atmosphere is really good, everybody is helpful and welcoming. 

Your network grows instantly and you feel you belong to a big, a very big family. 

There are numerous opportunities and you will get a chance to shine.
cons:
Because of the enormous size of the company and numerous take overs they have done, it is very easy to get lost. 

Lost physically, in Dublin alone there are 5 different building occupied byb Oracle. 

Lost in information. There is so much to find about all the products they have, the things they do and the initiatives people take to make a difference, it's easy to get lost in all the information that is available to you.

job_title: Sales Account Manager in Calgary, AB
pros: Excellent brand recognition, very talented technical people, excellent software
cons: insane working hours, spend 95% of my time filling out spreadsheets and reporting on things, treated like a child with huge oversight and governance, no problem with treating people like garbage, very male dominated, people are enticed with huge incomes that very very few people make, the rest starve and get micromanaged and verbally assaulted, customers HATE Oracle because they treat them like they are lucky to do business with Oracle, void of ethics and morality, the most inflexible and rigid company I have ever worked for, no opportunity to be creative with deals or solutions

pros:
Work from home for many roles.
Good retirement contribution matching.
Excellent Employee "assistance" programs (counselling/relocation/etc.).
Support for community volunteer programs.
Most employees work well together (when management supports it) both locally and globally..
cons:
Executive team is focused primarily on cost reductions and has been for years now, hence: work from home is encouraged, no raises or promotions for staff but very high pay for co-CEOs compared to market peers,  significant recruitment efforts around fresh grads who will not receive real salary increases either, see OpenWorld keynote by Co-CEO for perspectives on cost cutting, forced time off over Christmas season using employee's personal vacation time allotment.
No performance appraisals, focus on "development plans" and "talent reviews" without compensation/promotions.
Considering the business environment and claiming to be a market leader the stock has been a laggard for years now.  Time will come for staff reductions soon.

New hires must negotiate for a high starting salary, you will not receive a raise so take advantage of the opportunity while you can.

job_title: Applications Sales Executive in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Job Security?(you will know when you are getting fired) Since you're a cog in a wheel, nobody cares whether you actually do good; they just want you to make them look good. You work with so many people, some of them have to be inherently good people.
cons: Where do I begin. Managers tell you that you're worthless and expendable. Creates a culture that thrives off of negativity and breeds base riders and unmotivated people that settle for mediocrity. Your counterparts will tell you that you need to flirt with your customers in order to be successful. Incredibly sexist culture in some ares. (all depends on who you work with) I do not know more than a few people that are satisfied with working here. That said, Oracle acts as a good career springboard. In the interim, they will pay you way less to do the same (even better) job than the guy next to you. You can learn a lot here, but if you stay more than a couple years, it is inevitable your morals will be compromised in order to remotely succeed here.

review_title: flexible work hours but not for a long term career
job_title: Applications Engineer in Redwood City, CA
pros:
Most people including me would chose flexible work hours for the best reason to work for Oracle.   Normally, you will just need to complete your project in a timely manner, and you manager would not count your work hours.  Sometimes, I have to work late or weekends to finish up my projects, but I am also very comfortable to get out of work early for my personal matters.  

Of course, it is the best place to learn Oracle application products and databases.   They offer excellent training resources such as Oracle university.
cons:
The company is huge , and I often found poor internal communication. 

Definitely, compared to a small software company, it is very hard to move to a management position from a developer.  
There are many developers who have been there more than 10 years and still have been waiting / looking for an opportunity to get promoted to a management position.

review_title: Happy with the work, dissatisfied with the pay
job_title: Advanced Customer Services Configuration Specialist in Reading, England
pros: Work with the people who are one of the best at what they do. Looks great on the resume. One gets to interact with some of the biggest names, installations in and around the UK. Opportunity to look into and understand the way BIG (and I mean really BIG companies work). Allowed to work from home, which is a BIG plus. Very environmental conscious. Good starting salary. Great colleagues.
cons: A brick in the wall. Very little attention to individual growth. Very bad pay masters. Pay rises not in keeping with the inflation rate. I have many peers telling me that they have not seen pay rises in years. Very little team activity except drinking. No team day outs.

pros: Customers are held hostage by huge investments in Oracle products.   The cost of switching from Oracle is too cost prohibitive.  This is the only thing maintaining Oracle's market share right now and a few key employees who like the work life balance and are riding it out.
cons: Mid level managers who don't understand products or markets or customers or employees.  Destroying what used to be a good company.  The strategy would be a good one if management cared a fraction about quality as much as they do ripping off customers and talented employees.

review_title: zero learning experience with frustrating and redundant process for everything
pros:
Having the oracle brand value to your resume.
They give good machines to work with
I couldn't find any single pros other than these
cons:
Trust me, i tried to keep it brief

1. The so called work life balance is nearly gone, it depends on the team you work for. If you are into a fusion team, there is less chance that you will have work life balance.
2. The long and redundant procedure make sure you take days to fix 2 lines of code. which decreases your learning curve a lot.
3. Nearly zero hikes... here the company is destroying itself. They are not able to keep their good performers, and then they are hiring other employees .. who don't have any clue about the product.
 4. Changing team or projects is very very difficult.
5. Lot of system testing is done by the developers coz they are told that the testers are busy. Thus you would be wasting your whole day testing an end to end flow in some random environment.

review_title: Solutions Consultant or Engineer if you go by Oracle's new Salesforce look and feel
pros: Oracle has a very flexible work environment and if you are lucky enough to have a good manager it can be a good place to work.   The applications are slowly being innovated to meet the changing workforce so they are committed to the cloud vision.
cons: Oracle invests nothing in it people that have been with company any length of time.  Their focus is millennials and hiring and training them.  They have continually cut compensation to the point that after 13 years with Oracle I couldn't afford to work their anymore.  I found many companies out there with better benefits, pay, and work environment.

pros: This was a fun company a few years ago. I enjoyed going to work and looked forward to the challenge. It was big boy sales with the autonomy and reaponsiability of that statement.
cons: The culture has changed from one of challnge and excitement to one driven by fear. It’s really unfortunate as it was not like that before. Extremely political. Meat grinder at times. Look for a decent manager and negotiace the highest salary you can. You won’t ever see a raise of any substance.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Redwood City, CA
pros:
Flexibility. If you are developers then you can pretty much work from home since we could connect to office machine via VPN.

Meetings also can be attended via conference call.

The benefits such as medical and 401K are pretty good comparing to other big companies. 

There are so many options for medical benefits so you could choose one that fits you. The vacation also pretty good since you do not have to report sick days =)

Working experience differ from groups. If you are in ST group then consider yourself lucky since you pretty much got all the perks.
cons:
The downside is probably lack of promotions and raise. Promotions are very hard to get since there are so many to do list that need to be checked off, especially in ST.

Since the company is big, you may feel your contributions are not significant since you mostly work only in small part of the product. But thats to be expected from big company like Oracle.

review_title: You work hard and are rewarded but too much politics and favoritism
job_title: Senior Contract Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: If you have good management you can go far, prove yourself, share innovative creative ideas and are rewarded for it.
cons: There are many that don't belong there based on experience - looked good on paper but no in practical standpoint and politics can have them survive years beyond their life expectancy. It's worse if it's poor management. Worklife balance is only good in certain roles, but not ours.

review_title: Routine work, good compensation, zero advancement opportunities
pros: I was extremely well paid when I started working there several years ago. Benefits are great and Oracle pays a large portion of the premium. I am able to work from home 100% of the time and my boss is very accommodating and nice. I am also largely self starting. As long as I get my work done I rarely have to interact with anyone other than my boss, though that can be a pro and a con.
cons: Raises are next to impossible to get. I have gotten one raise in all my time there, not even for cost of living increases. I have searched for advancement opportunities or for other teams to move to but they are very hard to get unless you already are within that organization. I.E. I am in Support, its hard to break into HR or Business Ops.

pros: Products were always fun.  Environment was typical sales (what have you done for me lately attitude).
cons: Take away items such as car allowance which was part of the compensation package so removing that was an immediate reduction in your pay.  Bonuses are not as good as other companies in the industry.  They do not listen to the employees.  I always felt that they would not care if I left as they could just hire another one just like me and cheaper.  Very disappointing that after 16 years with Oracle I felt it was necessary to leave as there were just too many changes that affected you as an employee.  This past year it was mandatory that employees take leave during the Christmas holidays and you had to use your vacation.  The company closed that week.  That benefits Oracle and not the employee as is the case with most of their changes.
