review_title: Great place - if you have a good manager, but things are changing
job_title: Principal Sales Consultant in Austin, TX
pros:
* High salaries for the industry
* Good home/work life balance
* Ability to work from home in many jobs, especially in sales
* Very good technology
* Great place to be for technical people - lots of innovation
* Some new Cloud services are innovative and show that Oracle is committed to Cloud
* Not struggling as much as other older, large tech companies like IBM and HP
* If you have backing from your manager, you can get promoted
cons:
* Executive management did not decide to invest in Cloud services soon enough
* De-emphasis of sales consulting, despite the fact that the products are getting more technically complex
* Compensation of sales consultants and sales reps is declining
* Turnover in the sales force is accelerating
* With three CEOs, it's difficult to figure out who is running the company
* Hostile licensing and pricing policies, especially for VmWare customers - but this is changing

review_title: A great place to work but not without a lot of pitfalls
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Redwood City, CA
pros:
You will work with bright and hard working people most of the time. Oracle has a rich history and a lot of talented management that have been around for many years. Also, Oracle is huge and there are a lot of opportunities in different areas.
Overall, I believe there is an excellent work life balance. This is truly one of the best reasons to work at Oracle. Most of all management understand this and are supportive and encouraging in taking care of business at home and work.
cons:
Oracle is in the midst of a rough transition to the Cloud. They are late to the game but are investing significantly. In certain areas they are still losing marketshare or are very stagnant. There is significant turnover in certain areas of the business.

Promotions are hard to come by. Management can be thick and superfluous at times. 

Pay is lackluster in comparison to most of the industry.

review_title: Good company to work for- Very dependent in what group you are in!
job_title: Channel Sales Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Flexible work hours, great benefits, sharp coworkers, challenging work. It's a massive company so with a little legwork you can essentially move to another group/location based on your changing interests.
cons: Sales Training went more towards self service and away from actual training workshops (which I found to be more impactful). It's a very "right place, right time, who do you know" kind of company when it comes to promotions (however lateral moves are much easier to get since they are always re-orging). Raises are practically non existent. Depends on what group you are in or your manager - but lots of top heavy layers of management requires a lot of time giving the same updates with a slightly different data set for different managers, and sometimes this leads to your manager micro managing you so that they can respond to the 3-5 people that are calling them for opportunity updates.

job_title: Principal Software Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: I was part of the Sun Microsystems acquisition, and since the acquisition, the part of Oracle that came from Sun—the "Systems" org—has been largely independent, retaining its culture and able to manage its own direction.  The work has been very enjoyable, with good projects to work on and good people to work with. The company is stable, and has a large portfolio if you want to work on different things. There has generally been enough money to go around for good equipment.
cons:
The Santa Clara campus is not particularly close to public transit, making getting here a pain unless you live close enough to avoid traffic, and the shuttle connections to the trains are few and far between.

The compensation is below industry standard. This works well enough, even in the Bay Area, but is frustrating. The work has generally been good enough to compensate, but not always.

job_title: Senior Marketing Analyst in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: It was interesting to work for such a large company. I felt secure, until I wasn't, and I learned so many new skills. My direct supervisor and the group vice president of our team were both incredibly supportive and creative. That made for a very interesting experience, which I have heard is not the case for everyone. I especially appreciated the flexibility.
cons: It's easy to get lost in a big company, and I certainly felt that way when a new leader was brought in. He didn't take time to look at the talent he already had, and I doubt any of his bosses ever asked him to do so.  Because it's so cutthroat in the higher ranks, you often need to be looking ahead at how to protect yourself. Sometimes my co-workers appeared to be a little blood-thirsty as they fought to save themselves.

review_title: The experience certainly depends on the specific teams, as is the case with larger organisations.
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros:
Fairly good compensation.
Brand value.. I guess!
cons:
- Some teams are still not upto the speed of latest technologies in the field.
- Backward management tactics ( Literally abusive environments - in some teams. The abusive nature will cascade upto the point of upper management making it very hard to escalate such issues.)
- Internal movement to various projects is not that easy and has longer notice periods than exit.
- Every process takes a frustrating amount of time, from hiring to promotion.
- Hikes are absolutely biased and solely awarded based on the number of hours churned. ( as is the case with most Indian companies!! )
- Expectation to work very long hours during the week days and week ends. My colleagues used to even jokingly ask if I have applied leave the following Saturday and Sunday if I mention any weekend plans.

( I really did not plan on writing any con.. but here I am! Ah! the good old memories.. :-) )
-

review_title: Good company name for your resume.
job_title: Software Development Engineer In Test in Chicago, IL
pros:
It's an amazing team with good communication and teamwork. Everyone works hard and does extra on bigger projects and attack projects as a team.
Another pro is that Oracle is one of the bigger companies around the world, so it will look good on your resume for your next or future job.
It is a great company to work at if you are joining as your 2nd or 3rd job in your career so that you are decently compensated already.
Another good thing is that Oracle has the "unlimited PTO" as a benefit for salary employees, but it depends on your immediate manager to approve or not. My manager was amazing at allowing me to have time off when I needed.
cons: The issue is that once you join Oracle at a certain salary, you are going to be stuck at that salary for a long time.

review_title: You're only as good as your last fiscal quarter
pros: There are plenty of oppritunities to make money at Oracle and those who are sucessful are well rewarded.  There are great benefits like in-office gym, frequent catered meals, and extensive training, all free of charge.
cons: There is an unhealthy influence from management to do whatever is neccesary to "get the job done" which prevents a clear distinction between work and personal time.  This wouldn't be such a problem if they were more flexible with salespeople working from home.  The pressure on the sales staff is average most of the time, however, pressure increases exponentially during the end of fiscal quarters or due to turn-over related issues.

review_title: Some great teams/Managers also lots of mediocre folks
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Great products, innovative and never the same. Every couple of years Oracle extends their scope and goes after a new market. If its industries, hardware, engineered systems, cloud, mobile you name it, Oracle will be there sooner or later. Its a great place to learn and you can work with very talented people who are at the top of their game.
cons: too many acquisitions which on one side bring very bright and talented people,  on the other mediocre folks who don't know how to survive in a large global company. They think that running a 100-1000 people company is the same as running one of 140.000. Many times they get paid waaaaay better then existing employees who have to suffer and manage folks who are getting paid more than they are (and ever will earn).

pros: Every day I go to work, it's basically up to me to make the best of it.  That's something I really like.  You are given a lot of latitude in what you need to do to get your job done and make it a satisfying place to work.  In my job, I get to touch just about every piece of IT equipment you can think of. It's fast paced and never boring.  No one ever hassles me in my job and people are super easy to get along with. It's just a good stable place to work.  I really like it.
cons: Everything is self-service at Oracle.  However, it's probably a plus.  Other drawbacks could be that it seems like you are just a number and can be a little cold but after all, it's a big company.  Again, no one bothers me so how can I complain?  Sometimes it can be difficult to find out information but there's always someone there that can get the answer for you.

pros:
If you wanna learn a lot and looking for good opportunities, then Oracle is one of the right places.

If you're not worried about monetary benefits and just wanna learn, you can apply for this company without second thought.
cons:
You won't get a proper hike/salary/bonus. Even God wouldn't know if you will get any pay raise/bonus. Even if you get, it will be pathetic most of the times. Very few get what they deserve. You will never know how some got at all! 

Most Developers complain that the work is monotonous and there is nothing new to learn and the work is restricted to one framework.

In appraisal meetings, You will hear totally weird/senseless feedback like 'you didn't attend the meeting on such and such date' 'you should have been more aggressive' 'your communication isn't good. Director did not understand the email you sent on this date' 'you were not there in the top 3 in our ranking'. Dare questioning and the response will make you regret forever.

job_title: Sales and Business Development Representative in Reston, VA
pros:
Great Health Benefits
Great Training 
Job Stability 
Career Advancement if you really like sales 
Opportunity to make a ton of money
cons:
Low stating Base Salary
Upper Management doesn't listen to employees
Few locations to select from they only give you the option of having this job at HQ, Austin, TX, Reston, VA or Boston, MA
Really stressful it's sales one quarter you may make $8,000.00 next quarter you may make $8.
Only except this job if you have no other options and you really like sales, this job consists of heavy cold calling and quota attainment. 
Just trying to give you as much advice as possible I wish someone would have told me before I accepted the position.

review_title: Toxic,unorganized, despised by its customers and its employees
pros: Pay and benefits are good
cons: Lots of fake reviews on here. I don't know a single person that likes working here. Everyone is looking to leave. I've never had the misfortune of being a part of a culture that is so toxic, arrogant and clueless.  To say there is zero collaboration between sales groups would be understating it. Oracle thinks it's beneficial to pit the teams against each other. Lunacy ensues. I can't tell you how many times I have heard customers complain about how hard it is to do business with Oracle because, "its like working with 8 different companies". the happiest day of my long IT career will be the day I have Oracle in my rear view mirror. I was warned by former employees and colleagues that this was a horrible place, my fault for not listening.

pros: Flexible, Best Exposure to Financial Services, Single Domain - Banking and Finance, Lot of Training (Technical, Functional and Behavioral), Employee Friendly Policies
cons: Transportation Facility Needs Improvement. Nothing else comes to my mind.

review_title: Great place to stick around for non performers
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros:
1. No work pressure if you are not willing to work
2. Unlimited work from home if your manager is your relative or from same native place
3.Very easy to get hikes and promotions if your manager is your relative or from your native.
4.Similarly easy to crack interview if you already know your hiring manager personally since you will be selected for the job even if you do not clear the basic first round.
cons:
For people who have been recruited based on merit and not personal linkups, please be prepared for work as you will be doing the work of 2/3 non performers. Also forget about hikes or bonus.
2. Lower and middle management is full crap.
3. No agile implementation and transparency

review_title: Good place to work and settle but no hikes and bonus
pros:
Flexibility of timing and work-from-home options help provide a good work-life balance
Team members are very co-operative, and since most of them have stayed with the company for very long, you will get a lot to learn from them about the product.
No micro management from managers
Company values and HR policies are good
Stay here and work if you have a family to tend to!
cons:
Not a place for freshers and ambitious people, 
mostly work on support development as new projects are always handled by the US folks
No Travel
No compensation hikes and bonus
No career growth

job_title: Senior Principal Consultant in Solihull, England
pros: Flexible work culture with remote working
cons:
- No transparency on pay rise, bonus. Worst employer in this regard. Nobody knows how one qualifies for bonus and when one actually gets it. Appraisal process is flawed. Managers don't do appraisals honestly.

- Managers constantly lie about bonus budgets and will always tell nobody got bonus but some people actually get it.

- Racial profiling at workplace based on skin colour.

- Racial discrimination at workplace. White skinned Eastern workers given more preference by managers than British employees of coloured skin.

- Managers are selectively favourite towards some employees to give them more overtime opportunities 

- Some employees, managers even indulge in threats & bullying to their subordinates 

- Selected few employees enjoy special favours from managers for not doing certain types of work

- If you raise concerns, HR and managers simply ignore them no matter how serious they are.

- Paid leaves are very less compared to other companies 

- Don't expect bonuses and pay rises, Oracle abuses discretionary bonus

review_title: Great benefits, Slow innovation and Growth, High base but no raises
pros:
- Flexibility of work schedules and work location (No complaints in this area - they are the best)
- Good base pay
- Great team members (depends on the team)
- Free access to a great gym and pool (HQ)
- Excellent bakery. Really top notch baked goods and pastries.
- Good food options and several cafes, but not cheap.
cons:
- Rare or no performance bonuses or raises, so make sure you negotiate for a good base salary right at the beginning taking this into account. 
- Work culture is really bad for some teams. Make sure you pick the right team.
- Food is not free. 
- Not sure what some people do in their roles or how they got there. Few incompetent people at higher positions.

pros: Great company to work for as long as you are in with the chosen circle of people.
cons: If you are lucky enough to get the right manager it could be a great journey. If you get a spineless one that blames other people for his failures like I had, then your tenure will be a very short one.

review_title: Good products and solutions to customers but bad HR to employees
pros: Very good products and solutions portfolio to sell in the market, technical support varies from region to another, very good incentive plans for Sales teams.
cons:
HR are not up to standards for an international company based on my experience, they do what direct managers orders them to do rather than being clear and transparent with employees, not that solid backbone to employee if he/she have a bad manager.

Appraisal is not the only channel to evaluate employees, there are hidden things that employees do not see and hidden arrangements can be done between some managers and HR against an employee, I am talking about my experience in MENA (Gulf) region I don't know if the rest of regions have the same issues, hope it is better than that.

review_title: Time well spent for the motivated...
pros: Intelligent, talented employees.  Most are highly motivated and driven for success.  Benefits are excellent.  Access to information is good as long as you know where to find it.  Benefits of resources a large organisation can offer. Opportunities for movement across line of business within the organisation.  Oracle is a strong brand within the market.
cons: Strong entity within Europe, however there is a feeling of being removed from US and corp strategy. Frustrating to work within the sales model of the organisation. Feeling that you spend more time selling internally rather than externally.  Career progression depends completely on self motivation, with no management support - though this may depend on one's manager.   Based on conversations with colleagues, if you are not self motivated it is very easy to get lost within the organisation.

review_title: Minneapolis, MN - Not THE Oracle - just re-badged Retek. And stay away from a group called "S.E."
pros: Looks good on your resume and in your network. People look up to the Oracle name. After all it is one of the benchmarks of progress in information technology field.
cons:
This review is only about the Minneapolis location. 
There is really not much about "Oracle" but just an old company called "Retek" that was bought by oracle in one of its shopping sprees. so a lot of old leftover culture  (not good) has been retained from the retek days. Some manager are just self centered egoists who spend the whole year only caring about what they can show to their directors and VPs as their accomplishment at the effort and expense of their employees They are of authoritative attitude and partial. This is especially true with "SE" (sustaining engineering)managers that first give a lecture on how there have been orders from teh "top" to reduce work from home yet they would be the ones who work from home the most.

review_title: Slow & absolutely demotivating place to work unlike before.
pros: None as I can think of currently.
cons: No Salary hike, No promotions, no learning, Absolute let down when it comes to employee benefits or learning(courses). They say grass is greener on the other side, so if anyone wants to see this side of grass, think again or learn the hard way. I also hear that one VP said, employees can leave the organization if they cannot tolerate that fact that no hikes and salaries are given (even though the last hike was in 2010 that was almost negligible). So think again!! Why work for an org that does not have a human side.

review_title: Big MNC, Wild Ambition, But No Passion
pros:
Sthanding for the first class for IT industry, you can see the comanpy acquistions news every year
Working system is variety & user-friendly
You can learn a lot here
No worry about welfare, it's above local everage
cons:
Unfair to support team. Definately salse-oriented company, top managers always support sales even though the sales don't follow the procedure. They will approve the special and restircted request which seems very   difficult for delivering and bring very little benefit to company. Maybe everything can be addapted as long as it isn't illegal.
No salary increase, which makes senior empoyees(working in Oracle more than 5 years) leave the company. Then give the new hire higher salaray with less experience, lose-lose situcation. 
Working range is not clear, sometimes overlapped, if you're not very aggressive, no excuese to give the job to any other, god bless you, it is yours.
Hard to get promotion.
From the above, I can understand why some of the co-workers refuse to take responsibilty to every work they haven't done before.

job_title: Senior Principal Technical Architect in Austin, TX
pros: Great benefits, pleasant working environment, technical staff is very experienced and knowledgeable in the traditional retail domain
cons: Management lacks the ability to define a strategic vision and stick with it long enough to see it through.  Organizational structures create pfiefdoms that cannibalize each other rather than work together for the greater good.  Reactionary to market demands with minimal thought leadership or internal innovation.  Siloed culture that doesn't foster collaboration or nurture organic multi-discipline teams to solve big problems.

pros: Flexible work schedule, can work from home a few days a week, the coworkers are nice and brilliant, free sodas and juices and other drinks, because the teams are very specialized you are likely to become an expert in the one small area you are working on - be it SQL, C, Java, Forms, etc.
cons: no yearly standard of living raise, promotions don't come with raises so you are likely to be there years and years without making a dime more, they give you ample vacation time but you are forced to use 4 days over Christmas break and if you don't have 4 days you don't get paid, the teams are very specialized so you are likely to be in the same team working on the exact same thing for years at a time and it does become monotonous after a while

review_title: It's a great company if you take the initiative to forge your own path
pros:
In the currnet econmic environment Oracle is one of the few safe havens of stablility.  Wth the acquistion of numerous companies the portfolio of applications and products is becoming even more balanced.  This leads to a tremendous amount of career opportunity across products.  Employees have access to excellent training and the latest software to gain industry knowledge.  
Oracle continues to support acquired applications (PeopleSoft, JDE, Siebel etc) while at the same time developing Fusion applications for the next generation of software.
cons: The size of Oracle prohibits a close knit community.  It often takes several weeks, or longer, for important decisions to be made.  I work for a company that was acquired by Oracle and the communnication has been deficient.  There has been very little implementation of strategy, mostly  talk of how great things will be. So far the numbers have not backed up the talk.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Portland, OR
pros: Oracle is a global corporation offering some employment stability in a dark economic climate.  The benefits package is good and offers reasonable options.  Oracle encourages team oriented activity and growth.  Continuing education is offered and encouraged.
cons: Because of the size of the organization, it is easy for an employee to get lost and dehumanized.  Even though continuing education is offered, it is almost impossible to get it approved.  Salaries and wages are usually minimal to midline of what the current area market is, and once you have accepted a starting wage it increases a maximum of 3%, and often several years pass by with no raise (irregardless of performance.)  Oracle only matches a small portion of the 401K and that match can exclusively be invested in Oracle stock, an exact quote from the benefits page, 50% of your first 6% in contributions, so Oracle is matching your first 6% at 3%, almost nothing.

review_title: Was acquired by Oracle in the SUN Microsystems acquisition
pros: Oracle is a terrific brand to work for, when working in the IT industry, if Oracle is in an account, it's never going anywhere so there is tremendous upside to continue to sell into the account.  As part of an acquisition I was given better benefits and resources to sell.  I was also able to tap into their tremendous sales force that has great reaches into multiple contacts within accounts.
cons: Their existing software sales force is very hard to work with as they are controlling and look at those who were acquired by Oracle as direct reports when that could not be any further from the truth.  You receive a sizeable car allowance a month but can not expense mileage unless you are traveling an exuberant amount of miles a week.  My major issue was the lack of ability to move within the company for 6 months after the acquisition and thus no pay increase.

review_title: I was there for over 15 years. Got worse every year.
pros: Quite a lot of training is available. So if you want to learn it is a good place. However,they didn't hire any entry level people for many many years, so good luck with that. I was in the support Area, perhaps it is different in other divisions.
cons:
For a company whose only REAL asset is people, they treat the employees pretty badly. Pay increases are few and far between, bonus usually none or small. Benefits cut year after year. Job security is non-existant. Layoffs very common place. 

The entire company is silo'd. Very hard to move around, left and right hand don't know, etc. You are pigeon holed as to you capabilities are only what you are already doing. 

I could go on, but you get the picture

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Austin, TX
pros: Excellent pay, work from home, great benefits.
cons: Antiquated processes, redundant jobs/groups, high turnover.  They hire a lot of people away from other companies with the promise of a 6 figure salary (which was true, at least in my case), but then lay off a huge number of those employees within a year.

review_title: Don't bother working here if you ever want a raise or promotion
pros:
-Great benefits: health, dental, vision, life, 401K match -- all stellar
-Work/life balance: everyone in my town has great flexibility to work remotely
cons:
-Pay could be better; don't ever expect a raise once you are hired (so go for broke if you get an offer: get as much as possible up front because that's likely all you'll ever see here)
-Many, many jobs involve at least a little bit of travel
-The HR policy is to handle internal moves as "transfers" regardless of higher level or external salary that will need to be offered to external candidates
-No raises or bonuses for most in most years; you feel dispensable

review_title: High three or low four stars ?
job_title: Principal Sales Consultant in New York, NY
pros: As a technology company, Oracle is good company.  They have strong technical leadership in Kurian and Fowler and they invest heavily in R&D to develop world-class products around their vision (currently Cloud).
cons:
The leading issue with working at Oracle is a number of your customers will hate you.  Ironically, these are the same customers that make $M's (or $B's) using our solutions.

Other points:
- Hadn't seen any raises in 6 years, had overtime cut, and dropped car allowance
- For a given customer need, we (in many cases) had competing solutions and the Oracle Sales Teams spent more time fighting each other than engaging with the customer.
- A tendency for employees to myopically focus on their compensation only and to disregard interactions with other groups.  This manifested itself in un-returned phone/email messages and unmet commitments.

pros:
- Good starting salary package, partly due to the government's tax deduction for technical jobs
- Good new-hire orientation assistance
- Coke/tea/drinks paid by the company
- Good job to have on your resume
cons:
-Top-down management style
-Exceedingly strict rules without needing to be
-Limited possibility of remote working
-Huge differences in salaries, with some members earning nearly three times as much than other members, without any possible reason that would explain it
-Virtually nonexistent salary increases or any kind of bonuses
-No realistic respect for work-life balance, job comes first no matter what
-Rather confusing process, with multiple opinions for any questions and no clear correct answers
-No higher-management trust in employees, you're treated as if you don't care about your job at all; this is a senior role, yet we're treated as if we're college kids in a minimum-wage call center.
-Resistant to change suggestions, even carefully explained ideas are shot down without explanation
- Management does not stick up for the team
-No team-buildings
-Confusing goals

review_title: Good products, out of touch senior management
pros: Good products, good brand, big market share, lots of products to sell, stable company with lots of internal team support, some really smart people in the company, lots of cash on hand to make acquisitions hence more products for sales to sell
cons: Out of touch senior management, ever-changing strategy, too many products through acquisition to maintain and manage, missed the start of the cloud trend and now desperately trying to catch up, too big so bureaucracy is entrenched, little room for advancement, pay is an issue as good people have left due to inadequate pay, personnel strategy is not favorable for experienced AEs in the market, company culture is a big negative as it promotes internal competition with little to no collaboration which causes customer relationship to suffer

review_title: The sales org is all over the place, good people here and there, pick your manager, pick your team well
job_title: Applications Sales Representative in Redwood City, CA
pros: Sales training is good, although enforcement isn't great. Well known brand everyone knows about it.
cons: Typical cons associated with a giant company. Systems are disparate, and everyone has their own way of doing things. So many  companies being bought by oracle, but don't do a good job of integrating everything well. A lot of different resources all over the place, no good processes, everyone's just trying to bring order to chaos in their own way. Bad place for young people to be in, unless you get lucky and have an awesome manager, and awesome team. But yet again, some people's experience might have been awesome. Because of the disparate processes, and no transparency, you never know who might be enjoying their job and able to advance their career.

pros: You have the opportunity to justify and do just about anything - I was able to travel to India several times for projects that I built from the ground up, and had a lot of fun with it.
cons:
Financial quarter ends are the worst. This is when the whole company throws all of the existing process and guardrails out the window to bow down to the sales team outrageous ideas to work the system and bump their own compensation.
Also, the compensation for anyone is Bozeman is automatically deflated because of where we live and they never give significant raises. Negotiate your salary to as high as you can when you first start because it will never go up again.

review_title: Plagued by dysfunctional large company issues
pros: Because of all the acquisitions, there is a strong "virtual" culture where many people work from home - this provides a lot of flexibility & freedom. Many talented architects & developers that it's a pleasure to work with.
cons:
Highly inflated middle management layer, leading to: 
- Talented developers/PM's leaving due to lack of growth opportunities.
-  Political infighting resulting in a lack of focus on the Customers 360 degree experience.
- Lack of effective performance metrics down the management hierarchy leading to an inefficient culture where success is measured by the size of your org & the customers voice is drowned out among ubiquitous internal power struggles.

job_title: Staff Sales Consultant in Redwood Shores, CA
pros:
The job itself is fun, you are a product expert supporting sales representatives (inside and field) and get to have conversations around how people are running their business and where their inefficiencies lie. The product demonstrations are easy to learn. Some other pros:
-Autonomy - as long as you get your work done and perform well during sales calls, you're left alone
-Benefits - Oracle has nice health benefits and 401k matching
-Flexibility - hours are not strictly 9-5
cons:
Because it is a huge corporation, the culture has a corporate feel. The job is to support the sales teams, so if the sales teams are not selling, you are not busy. While there are a lot of resources to become a better sales consultant, the information is hard to find. Some other cons are:
-Promotion - it is a slow moving process due to the big company workflow process
-Pay - the pay is under market value

review_title: All ideas must come from the top
pros: Oracle has some great people in the development organization.  Pay is reasonable.
cons: Unfortunately, a lot of the great people in the development organization end up leaving because they cannot deal with executive management's "no ideas except the ones we come up with" attitude and schizophrenic approach to engineering (e.g., shifting their attention and resources to address the problem of the day).  Executive management keeps the strategy so compartmentalized that no one outside the inner circle understands where they are trying to go.  They parcel out and delegate, sometimes overlapping work to groups that don't realize others are also working on the same tasks.  This approach not only leads to a lot of wasted effort but also a "house of cards" architecture where nothing hangs together without a great deal of post-release integration.

job_title: Senior User Experience Designer in Seattle, WA
pros: Oracle Cloud Infrastructure is trying to differ itself from the Oracle Monolith. It prides itself on delivering fast, having a different set of values, and growth. It also is showing a lot of promise in it's design departments. Oracle is starting to really embrace design culture, which is a significant shift from past history.
cons:
Oracle Cloud Infrastructure has been scaling at a rampant pace. It has a lot of maturing of basic services, internal and external, that you would expect from a large enterprise company. 
Oracle is still very dogmatic. It is an IT business and does not treat its IT department as a business. A lot of Oracle's internal tools are out of date and so owns a huge IT tech debt. It actively chooses to not use the most efficient options available on the market, just because they are not in Oracle's portfolio. Legal and compliance is also a shadow that looms over development.

pros:
great location with a nice view (if you're lucky to sit in the bright side of the building)
very good cantine
cons:
It's a terrible place to work at, people are leaving every week and many are depressed. 
Most people got a relocation package which means they have to stay 18 months if they don't want to pay it back. In the apps part of the business no one is making any sales, which means no commission and no money to pay off the relocation package from the own pocket. Thus, people are stuck and completely frustrated.

Lack of sales led the management to the idea that they should to micromanage the employees, which they do to a ridiculous extent.  The job consists mainly of cold calling.

If you'd like to know what it's like to work here try to imagine the most miserable working environment. Now imagine it's 3 times as bad. That should give you a rough idea.

review_title: Oracle CASB Group, Palerra -Join only  for Relaxation and work from home and nasty Politics  Not for learning and growth
pros:
Work from home and if you want to be expert in politics and boot licking.
Nothing precisely
cons:
Favouritism.Each manager has his/her own favourite cronies.
Hostile and toxic environment with some managers are even ruthless physic.
Most people who worked as contractors with Palerra  here from service industry are made permanent and has spoiled the place.
Recruitment is a joke here. Huge number of selective loyal people mostly contractors are being brought via got up and fake process so they remain quiet and loyal.
No  appraisal process, cronies selectively gets hike/stocks from time to time for being loyal, for others fake promises are being made and made to work till they leave.
High attrition, if people are not boot lickers they are bullied to leave.
All tall claims by the sr. director here in India failed flat and the product is hardly used by any customers ,  teams only do maintenance jobs and this is beautifully camouflaged by the sr director here  as “important critical work to the business”.
Consequently, there is a constant celebration of mediocrity in telling we are startups within Enterprise etc.. Passable / run-of-the-mill engineering outcomes are celebrated wildly.

review_title: Oracle is a good place to work, but if you're used to being productive, be prepared to get less done or work overtime.
job_title: Principal Software Engineer in Camden, NJ
pros: Oracle is a huge, successful software development company, which means that software development IS the business, and development staff is not treated as just another cost center. Compensation and benefits are very good, and there is a great deal of flexibility when it comes to the hours one works. The ability to telecommute whenever it is necessary or convenient is also very nice.
cons:
Due to the breadth of software produced, a lot of time is spent integrating the products, which necessitates long release cycles. It's hard to get anything done quickly. There is also an abundance of process to control all of the continuous product integration, which also dampens one's ability to work quickly.

Also, it is quite difficult to get promoted. The running joke is that you have to leave and come back to get a promotion.

review_title: Not a place to develop career path, and hard to see career progression. It's a giant company with lots of bureaucracy
pros: Lots of products trainings and soft skill training, but you need to know your way to register those trainings yourself. No HR or managers will help you in skill development. A great place to learn different Oracle products but you need to self motivate to learn those products and technology.
cons: Too many products which are not well integrated within the stacks and the work wise is quite silo. If you are good at one thing, you will always be assigned for those roles instead of moving to new challenges as everyone is looking for an expert in the area. Only when the product is end of life, you are forced to move to different products skill sets. Does not care of what do you want, more on what can you be billed to the customer.

pros:
As an individual role, I am closely working with Sales operation to administer timely and accurate incentive payments and submission to payroll. Working with Strategic finance and Sales operation for Accrual Analysis, Sales credit analysis, Payment Analysis, Payment calculation and submission, Revenue analysis, and Revenue achievement; gives me more analytical approach and high level of interaction knowledge. Works with Sales Operation and Strategy Finance to roll out compensation plan changes and calculate quarterly and monthly commission for sales employees focusing on accuracy, completeness as per commission plan.

As a role I will be receiving the Journal Entries from the Oracle sales representatives and making the debit and credit adjustments for them to pay the correct payment.
cons: To take up challenging tasks where my skills would scale up the development of the organization and also enhance my expertise. This could be offer professional growth for me and my organization, while being resourceful, innovative and flexible, willing to work as a key player in challenging & creative environment.

review_title: Falls much shorter of great than it used to be
pros:
* Product Required for on going financial acccounting
* Some fun young folks
* Quite a few corporate drones seeded from oracle that have not seen the sun in a decade
* Very strong corporate policies
* Office is stocked with a medium variety of snacks and drinks
* Fairly Stable just a mess.
cons:
* Awful IT assistance and Laptops that reboot in the middle of customer calls and constantly require maintenance
* Lack of Management Decision Making
* Micromanagement
* Too much focus on getting customers on perpetual support contracts which cant be maintained due to lack of staff
* Extremely poor training for internal staff and external partners/customers. Please hire a marketing dept that doesnt sound like an IRS video
* Upper Management extremely unfriendly
* No money to do events, go to conferences or 
* Lots of Nepotism
* Completely misleading PTO policies favoring managements favorites and lacking consideration for a normal 15ish day vacation policy employees merit
* CEO is primarily not present any more.

pros:
- very chill environment 
- everyone is so friendly and open to help (tell you what to do, not actually help you do it)
- very very self serviced (you need to do everything yourself, no one holds your hand)
- great breakfast and lunch, that you pay for out of your salary at the end of the month
- great benefits (bike2work)
- flexible 40hr
- work from home available but dependant on manager
- paid bank holidays and 20 days holiday (as far as I remember)
cons:
- monthly pay
- low pay
- as an intern you have no chance of growing, unless you apply for a graduate job and hope they take you in for an interview
- turnover of staff is very high
- too much politics interns should not have to deal with
- not enough training
- no realistic or clear goals
- some peer will act like your managers just because you are new
- no chance to jump from intern to junior, you need to go from intern to graduate to junior.

job_title: Business Analyst II in Tarrytown, NY
pros: Flex-Time. Telecommuting. Competence of management at most levels and lines of business of the organization.
cons:
I've worked here for several years now and management is not very timely about reviewing personal appraisals and when you do get to finally sit down with your manager and talk about it they are extremely conservative in their review assessment. That's been my experience. 

I'm actually earning less after working here several years than I did when I started and management is still towing the company line about the economy being bad,etc but I don't buy it in Oracle's case.

I think there are a lot of opportunities for professional growth and taking on more responsibility however there isn't a good process in place for doing a focal review of skills utilized/leverage, increased responsibility and contribution to meeting strategic objectives from customer satisfaction and product standpoint in making salary decisions. This needs to tracked and quantified better in order to keep good people.

pros: Decent pay, good flexibility in work location, decent benefits, large company makes for a semi-safe environment.  Customers really have to you and if you get to understand your patch and product set, you usually can figure out how to position and sell them.  Oracle has everything under the sun technology wise.
cons: There are some good sales territories and jobs at Oracle, and some lousy ones.  Better know your manager and area VP very well to ensure your deals can get approved!!  Biggest challenge is the terrible customer management strategy.  It's every sales rep for themselves, and customers know it.  It is a "good old boy" network in management.

review_title: Selfish and arrogant environment where negativity and blame run rampant.
job_title: Territory Sales Representative in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great sales training.  Good benefits and compensation.  Quality technology.  Methods for meeting preparation/ presentations are very good.  Good account planning processes.
cons: Majority of co-workers & management are selfish with no regard for teaming-to-win collaboration.  Customers always came LAST at this company.   A very self-help type work environment where assistance or guidance is non-existant.  Management style is to grind down Sales reps rather than build them up.   Inside Sales counterparts compete for same customers with Field Reps resulting in no mutual trust.  Account assignments are set in stone with no flexibility for reseeding.  Success can be very difficult if you do not have executive support to pull you along.  In my opinion, this is a company where your ethical conscience is constantly pressed and tested.

job_title: Product Manager/Strategy III in Morrisville, NC
pros: Oracle is a great place to develop your skills and learn how business works.  They have great benefits and do treat their employees well.  Great training is provided within the company through Oracle University.  I think that Oracle is a great place to start your career, and then maybe 10 years later go back and end it.
cons: The company is so big that it is really hard to get things done quickly.  There is a lot of "red tape" for every process.  Raises are very low.  Even when you do make a career jump into a more senior role, the pay will usually not all come with the increased responsibility or title.  Do a good job of negotiating when you first become a part of Oracle

pros: Aggressive product strategy designed to dominate each market they play in.  Financially solid.  Anyone who works at Oracle should have a sense of pride since it is a very good company.  Good compensation
cons: There are less than 100 Key Account Directors (Prime Sales Reps) in North America.  As a result most customers and prospects have an army (20 - 30) of uncoordinated and aggressive sales people calling on them.  That creates decision maker paralysis.  Further, the combination of having many similar products (HCM Cloud, PeopleSoft)  offerings and a compensation package that drives behavior, cannibalization across similar product lines happens.  In other reviews, people talked about internal competition.  This is very real...  You will have your internal competitors that will sell against you, Oracle Partners that can add value where you cannot, and your external competitors.  For any sales person, this shark tank adds significant risk to every deal you work on.

pros: Great benefits, good people, job security. I went through the Class of Program and have been at Oracle for over a year now, and really cannot believe how much I've learned in this role. Regardless of how boring or unfulfilling the job can feel some days, I absolutely cannot regret taking it in the first place. And having it truly be a 8/9-5 job is great.
cons: Personally, my one major grievance about Oracle is how non-transparent the recruiting/interview process was. They definitely paint a picture of the job as something very different from the reality. I think this contributes to the rapid turnover, and had I known where I would end up within the company, I would not have taken the job.

job_title: Business Development Consultant in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Work life balance & name in the CV
cons:
Sales Training: a lot of pilot training with bad teachers and no learning at all. If you have a  degree everything is a repetition. 

Management: Bad, bad and bad! Managers are not supportive, they are not allocating time to team members and there isn't much you can learn from them. You definetely feel smarter than your manager!

Salary: Companies in the same industry pay waaay better.

If you are a YES MAN! I recommend this company for the name and the good life-work balance. If you want to prove yourself,  bring your skills and make an impact, do not join Oracle.

pros:
Good health insurance that comes in handy to help pay for all of the psychological treatment required as a consequence of working at Oracle

I was lucky to be part of a good team of good people that have made the environment tolerable
cons:
- Toxic Environment 
- Customers hate you
- Managers are mostly bullies
- Company has a callous disregard for staff
- Company has a callous disregard for customers 
- Lack of respect for individuals 
- No career progression 
- Culture of bad behaviour 
- Protection of bad behaviour 
- Must disregard values of decency to be successful 
- There is nobody that I dislike so much that I'd reccomend working at Oracle

pros: Generally laid back environment if you are making your numbers.  Health benefits are solid and other perks such as happy hours a plus.
cons: Competition with other lines of business will prevent you from making sales. Absolutely no incentive to work with other lines of business and collaborate on deals. You are taught to not speak about your deals on the floor/cafeteria/any public area for fear that another Rep will swoop in and take credit out from under you. This has happened an unbelievable amount of times to myself and others.  For success in sales at Oracle, all that matters is the territory you are assigned, of which you have no say, even as a tenured employee.  The companies only concern is the bottom line. Lastly, your job will be in the chopping block every new start of the fiscal year. If you are laid off you will likely be replaced with a younger version of you.

review_title: Great company. Getting diluted by acquisitons.
pros: Many work at home jobs. Management is not a nanny to control your every move, only intervening as needed. Solid company with many great products and a slick reputation.
cons: Wave after wave of acquisitions have diluted the company in key ways. Some companies fit in better than others. The effort to change the entire support infrastructure by dismantling a highly successful system developed over the last 30 years and replace it with newly acquired products that are slow and limited is a formula for disaster for both customers and employees.

review_title: Sad to see Oracle emasculate Sun..... it was a great company but no longer.
pros: Innovation, cool technology, opportunities to grow, great working environment, provides a good challenge for the engineer looking to expand their skill set.  Typical tech vendor experience.
cons: Poor choices by management, loss of direction and unclear intentions.  Sale of the company to Oracle, which is in the process of eating the remaining young.  There is a state of fear among all the legacy Sun employees, no one is willing to stand up and voice an honest opinion for fear of loosing their job, which sadly is already gone.  Oracle has no idea what to do with what they've purchased.

review_title: Small company. Obsessed with FlexCube product
pros: Small company, so you will get immediate attention, HR ppl are responsive and supportive.
cons:
If you join in flexcube division, then well and good. But if you join in consulting (primesourcing) division, then its not a good place to work. Not many projects, so you have to continue in same project even if you dont want to. Citi group only major client. People who are in onsite, they remain in onsite for ever and till they want. Very less onsite of others even if you perform above expectation in offshore. 
Last but not the least - its still not clear if this company is "Oracle Financial Services" or still "i-flex". Policies are not clear. Managers at high position do whatever they want(like sending onsite, promotion etc). Not a clear process oriented company.

review_title: Oracle Romania could be great, too bad that the catch phrase is "Dog eats dog"
job_title: Service Response Analyst in Bucharest, Bucuresti
pros:
The salary is quite good.
Good additional advantages, like meal tickets and medical insurance.
Nice colleagues.
You can learn a lot of interesting stuff.
cons:
The salary will not change for as long as you work there, no real bonuses, nothing to keep you going.
The work environment is stiff, you are discouraged when it comes to socializing, you are viewed as a threat by your managers if you come with ideas to improve things.
Eventually, if you keep trying, your manager will do his best to get rid of you.
The appraisal process is just a bad joke, the manager's pets will always get great results, while the people that really do something will be frustrated by the results.

review_title: Big, advantageous, but a bit slow
job_title: Software Engineer in Redwood City, CA
pros: There is a lot of opportunities that you could see in the business sector. Oracle as a leading company in this field has a lot to offer. In strategy level company is expanding aggressively to the cloud computer software services with it's advantages in terms of capital and scale. The core database business is not developing as fast as the emerging internet+ unicorns. The culture here is pretty friendly. You could meet different sorts of people. But the more aggressive ones often opt to join a more start-up based companies. You could have your own schedule to manage things. And it is more likely for you to have a good balance in work and life
cons: Some may say it's not as rewarding or as challenging as they want it to be. The hourly pay is definitely among the best...

review_title: Overworked, No Room for Career Growth
pros:
(Mostly) fun people to work with
Easy work - repetitive
Work/life balance
cons:
Oracle doesn't care at all about morale - as a result a lot of the company is unhappy and looking. Turnover has been high, and will only get worse. Many key employees are leaving/have already left.

They'll ask you to take more and more work on, but you'll see nothing in return. No promotion/raise for ANYONE, Oracle has taken snacks and the holiday party away.

They've also forced PTO for all employees, where we must take our own vacation time during a specified period. This affects the bottom line, which impacts stocks, which fuels CEOs bonuses. They saw a huge increase, all employees saw nothing.

Management is flustered. Take care of your employees, and they'll take care of you.

job_title: Internet Sales Representative in Redwood Shores, CA
pros:
-Still a bit of a relaxed atmosphere
-If you like to party they only hire directly from college now.....so its frat city.
cons:
-CRM SUCKS.  You waste a lot of time with redundant info....not good for a sales rep.
-Pay is waaaay below PAR for the area
-Most management only got promotions based off of others sales.
-They hired a new top dog for sales and a new top dog for SDRs....so theyre in the process of revamping the entire sales structure, comp, cycle, process.....this has been going on for almost a year now and changes are constantly coming in.
-Too many internal processes to get anything done...even with new changes
-Zero transparency into accounts or installs
-Still use excel as a formal of CRM
-A lot of people have just been faking their numbers/pipeline and now the lack of real revenue is bringing the hammer down
-minimal referenceable customers (most products or the implementation suck)

review_title: Disorganized Business Culture and Values - Poor On-Boarding Training - Senior Colleagues too Selfish to Help
pros: Competitive salary, globally well-known brand, internationally leading database provider, attractive locations world-wide, equality between bother genders, sexual orientations and origins
cons: Disorganized business cultures and values: Oracle considers itself a 'Self-Service Company'. This self-service structure, however, is poorly to not functional due to excessively high amount of internal processes, tools and involved contact people. Poor on-boarding training and several senior colleagues' minimal to lacking willingness to train new hires contribute to disorganized business culture and values. Unstructured business planning and execution: Minimal investment in marketing strategies (2%) leads to Oracle pressuring sales and other departments to raise brand awareness as a newly position cloud provider. More budget shall be investested in marketing. Lack to absence of internal growth opportunities. Unprofessionalism: Customer data poorly treated. Some colleagues having inacceptable interactions with eachother and business partners.

job_title: Customer Support Engineer in Lehi, UT
pros: Benefits. They don't lay people off, they transfer then to different departments.
cons:
Pay raises are scarce.  If it happens it's a cost of living increase of $1,000 a year.  Would be nice if instead of Senior Management buying islands or receiving $10 million bonuses, we could see some of that too afford putting tags on my car. 
No training; after 3 years, the only training has been from coworkers.   No official training, no certifications.  
People promoted to manager do not get a raise year 1.

pros: Sales teams, tech teams and lower management teams were the best. Upper management sucks
cons: Upper management is the worst. They act like they care about the employees but they don’t. They raised our quarterly goals So much higher that it was impossible to meet. This way they didn’t have to pay out bonuses to management. Example. I had a team of 8 and their goal was 1million per quarter  so as a team that would be 8 million. My goal however as a manager was 18million.   Also they decided manager would have unlimited vacation and sick days. Sounds good but they make you feel guilty every time you want to take a vacation and if you leave they don’t have to pay for unused vacation or sick time. Clever right but it shows that they could care less about the people. They shift you around like cattle so you never know what your doing and there is no room for growth.

review_title: Big company- easy come easy go
job_title: Principal Sales Consultant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Pay was great.  Lots of free training opportunities.
cons: Oracle is actually many smaller companies not related other than they are all software products.  Outside of the core Database company, they are held as separate entities that get treated like they are being held by an investment company.  Over 40% of the profit goes to the mother company making the individual "Global Business Units" run very skinny and have very little money for R&D, growth and talent investment.  They aggressively recruited me, paid to have my family relocated from Chicago to Atlanta, bought a new company during the first year I was there, changed directions due to this new company,  and laid off most of the folks in my role because we weren't part of the new direction.  Hadn't had a product manager for the product I was hired to sell for 8 months.  Like any giant company, you're just a number to them and if their whim changes, they lay off people in droves.

review_title: Great for the Resume Building ... That's about it!
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Mississauga, ON
pros: - Experience and looks great on a resume.
cons:
- Compensation plan linked to Field performance.  If you're stuck with an incompetent Field Rep, you're screwed and will not hit your OTE.  Comp plan is also tiered and if you grow your deals past the first threshold, you get paid peanuts.
- No Career development. Dial for dollars like a trained monkey.
- High Turnover

review_title: Oracle: sacrifice pay to work in a big company.  Good for a few years of training and leave for better pay.
job_title: Principal Product Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: Oracle is a big, well-recognized, company with offices all over the world.  It also has a lot of opportunities within the company that people can transfer between job functions.  Oracle is a leader in most, if not all, the products in the market, and it acquired a lot of its competitiors in the last few years.  Employees are working on the best products and technology, leveraging a lot of these from its acquired companies.  Besides, Oracle has a wide range of customers from Fortune 100 companies to small or medium-sized companies.  Thus, employees know they are building the best products out there serving the biggest companies.
cons: Oracle offers very low compensation packages and provides very little career advancement guidance for employees.  Managers are not well-trained to lead teams, and have very inconsistent practices on promotion.

review_title: It's big.  It's really like 10 different companies all working under one title, but having very little overlap
pros: Really smart people.  The product management team is unbelievable.  Because it's so big, you are never at a loss for finding someone who can help and who is fantastic on the subject where you need help.  I have learned more working here than I have in any other job, so I'm happy I came
cons: They don't pay well anymore.  I work more hours and make less money than any other job I've had in the industry.

review_title: Reasonable work experience - but company is slow, bureaucratic, and top-down
job_title: Principal Product Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: My work experience was not bad as I did learn a lot about my domain, on how to sell ideas internally, and how to help ship products out on time. I also got the experience of working with sales, marketing, and support organizations that helped to round out my experience of how a software company works. Work-life balance was excellent most of the time.
cons: The company is slow and bureaucratic. Nothing moves in the product organization unless the product executive, Thomas Kurian, approves. Ideas don't seem to move up the chain, only trickles down the chain of command. There are a lot of overlap of products due to acquisitions, and no serious attempt to clean that up. Pay was mediocre.
