job_title: Sales and Market Development Representative in Brighton, MA
pros: The company has the right idea and vision for where cold calling is going. The hours are great. You never work beyond 5 so you are always home for dinner. The pay is great for what you do.
cons:
Upper management might have a great vision for where the company wants to go, but it takes a long way to move down through middle management. 

It's also a huge company which means you can easily get lost and feel like you are out on an island by yourself. 

And you will be cold calling. It's not as bad since the company is only selling to businesses and everyone in tech knows who Oracle is, but it is still cold calling.

review_title: Good company with poor Pay upgrade system.
pros: Good company to be upgraded with latest Oracle Technologies and getting chance to work on the same.
cons: No Salary minimal hikes at all nor re-structuring method up-to the market standards for long standing employees. Company is least bothered about employees moving out in a bulk. Now and then employees get fired as well as part of new company acquisitions to balance their  things. If any one wants to join this company, better bargain as much as possible at the time of joining...later you can not influence any one in any manner to get hikes though how valuable player you are. Over all, good company with poor monitory upgrade system.

job_title: Business Development Consultant in Redwood City, CA
pros:
The people make this company great. I truly enjoy everyone involved throughout my training, on my team, and in management. People are willing to help when on the same team, and help you get through the often frustrating times at Oracle. 

Pay is competitive.

Food is great.

Hours flexible.

Gym is incredible.

A lot of fun social activities, depending on manager
cons:
Everything depends on your team. The company is so large that management has its disconnects. Quotas and metrics can change instantly without the say of directors. 

In house products are clunky and slow.

Far from the city.

Bonus pay out is pathetic for applications pillar.

They tell you horizontal movement is possible, but it's not likely for 3+ years.

Aren't able to choose product you're selling.

job_title: Business Development Consultant in Austin, TX
pros:
I've met some of my closest friends here; great people make it easier to work here. 

GREAT benefits - 401K matching, THE best healthcare options are available
 
GREAT work/ life balance - in my role you don't really have to work on projects when you leave the office, but once you move up things usually change (more intense job description/ projects)
cons:
Decent base salary right out of college, but there's somewhat of a miscommunication in bonus structure when you're hired.

If you're hired in sales, it's a bit more difficult to transition to another department - they like keeping sales new recruits in sales and there's a specific structure to moving up.  

However, if you're comfortable in sales, it's easy to move up. If you put in the work, you'll move up to the next in a year.

Top management could communicate more with lower level 

VACATION DAYS - ONLY 1 DAY A MONTH (or about 12 days a year which isn't much);

review_title: Business Development Consultant 1-Corp Plan Sao Paulo- Brazil
pros: Great Company and excellent benefits
cons: I have cons to about Oracle but the description for this particular position

review_title: A pretty dysfunctional company and culture, struggling to be a real Cloud player
job_title: Vice President in Redwood City, CA
pros: Oracle has a lot of good people at the working level, many of whom are talented. The company is fairly well respected in emerging countries like Mexico, Romania and India and attracts good people there.  Many groups in the emerging countries are doing well and happy, but in the core regions and HQ, that is not the case.
cons: At the highest levels, the company is quite dysfunctional with a lot of blame games and politics, and management styles driven by fear and cursing.  A lot of managers have become good at managing up  rather than listening and caring to what their teams need for success, what the customer experience should be, and how to deliver amazing products.  In general many of the top executives have no interest to listen to useful insights from the troops. The company on the inside does not inspire great people to do great things, and morale in general is not good.  The products are complex in nature so not an easy task to deliver, but they have surprisingly poor quality and the Oracle brand is in serious decline.

pros: This is the best benefits package I've ever been provided, it's a good thing too otherwise I might have already left.
cons:
No annual raises, no annual bonus, politics are a mess...
I regularly receive emails that my business unit consistently exceeds revenue goals, yet no one on my team has been given a raise since Oracle acquired us. Whenever we ask during an all hands meeting, higher ups tend to brush it off and say "Oracle provides raises 100% based on merit". To me this means that if you're not getting a raise, it's your own fault. I have a hard time believing that no one on the entire ops team hasn't been deserving of a raise... I guess the only way to make more money is to leave.

review_title: Abusive boyfriend school of management.  Message is: "You're worth nothing and you're lucky I let you stick around."
job_title: Principal Product Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: Smart employees, some very nice people in the lower ranks. challenging business problems to solve with software
cons: Working on financial products at Oracle requires depth of business knowledge and a strong skill set, but senior management treats employees like numbers.  Before I left I didn't have a raise for 6 years (I was paid 25% below market but my managers explained they had to give the salary pool to others who were paid even less).  I also gave notice right when they were awarding bonuses, I had a stellar performance review and they completely yanked my bonus.  (I was not surprised).  Promotions are often awarded based on aggression rather than skill. HIghly political.  The company is not at all innovative.  If they had a successful app development strategy they never would have had to spend $5B to buy companies like Peoplesoft and Seibel.  They should have won that space.

pros: There is a large product portfolio and you do not have to know the products to make good money.  All that is required is that you need to get a good territory and you need to call on purchasing and IT.  There are no caps in the ROE (Rules of Engagement), Oracle's term for compensation plan.  However, see below.
cons:
Oracle will frequently choose not to pay you if you blow out your numbers.  If you do not like it, you can sue them.   Oracle will decide after the fact, whether they want to pay you.  It does not matter if this is legal in your state.  They are bold, they play the numbers, they know the downsides to doing this, they do it all the time, and they benefit handsomely.  If you sue, your contract requires arbitration which generally favors the Oracle because the arbitrator is paid by the company and they want repeat business.  (Oracle does not get to choose the arbitrator).  Cases will take 2 or more years and legal fees are very expensive. 

They frequently delay payment as well, while they think it over.

review_title: just another servcie based company nothing else
pros:
1. Free gym.

2. Good cafeteria.

3. Luckily got development project (scratch), really good team but bad Manager as usual.

4. Good HR Team.

5. Initially the company name was iFlex now it's called Oracle Financial Services. So the brand name Oracle in your tag.
cons:
1. Company was doing good but these days going too bad. No variable pay paid, some of team mates who really worked well and good talents are asked to leave the company just because they got less rating last time.

2. Project allocation team is very bad they behave like CEO and treat you like school kids. They simply order you to work on some project even though it's not related to you profile. 

2. Most of the clients are African countries. so due to lack of budget some projects are dropped.

4. They have their product side also but not good work there to learn latest technologies.

5. Top Management as usual will treat developers depends upon their mood, partiality, favoritism etc..

review_title: Enjoying my first months at Oracle
job_title: Sales Consultant in Redwood City, CA
pros: So far my experience at Oracle has been good. The six week training program was world class and Oracle really invests a lot of time and money trying to make sure they prepare their employees for real work responsibilities. As a sales consultant there is a need to learn a lot of products and the product trainings with sales pitches afterwards really helped keep you on your toes and wanting to learn more and more about the product. Its a real self service company meaning that if you want to succeed you have to do what you can to make it, if you're comfortable with just doing the bare minimum then you can get by doing that but you will not move up in your career.
cons: Since I just started my job, I have yet to find any cons associated with working here. A job is a job and I'm really thankful for having one.

review_title: re-org every year, very top-down driven by margin
pros:
- fast paced environment
- ensuring a profitable business, with a relative secure job environment
- wide range of soft-skill training available to enable personal development
- interesting environment and solid proven products.
- good product strategy
cons:
- growing by the margin and acquisition
- little investment on the HR side of life. staff is rather seen as a cost factor than a contributing factor
- focus on the quarter end for revenue and cost reduction, rather than optimizing processes for sustainable and lasting improvements
- optimization is often being attempted by making one position out of three, without optimizing anything around this and creating massive bottlenecks and reducing throughput speed / unless the individual is taking the burden, to work endless weeks.
- little empowerment of several management levels (small (value) decisions require approval from VP and above).
- salary is often below average, and particular do not count on salary increase, unless you are considered one of the top 3% high performer of an organization

job_title: Principal Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros: Good healthcare. Flexible working arrangements (sometimes TOO flexible for team work)
cons:
1. Pay - 1 tiny pay raise in 5 years. Plus my salary is 20% below the Oracle average. Thereby effectively taking a pay cut with inflation etc.
2  Vacation does not accrue after 18 days PLUS this year we are having mandatory time off at Xmas.
3. Constant chipping away at little things (like above forced vacation  PLUS taking away expenses for home internet connection)  to  save a small amount of money  just alienates huge swathes of staff.
4. Management has no clue on how to motivate the folks below and only care about their OWN stock options and bonuses.  We have seen way too many good technical people promoted to manager only to be a disaster in that role.

pros: My role has lots of autonomy, lots of travel, scope to meet with people, and a boss who is very protective of her employees.  I'm well looked-after and well-paid for what I do.  Lots of interesting challenges to solve and I have the means to solve them myself, which I like.
cons: Lots and lots and lots and lots of acronyms.  A very hard company to break into - you're better off joining a company and then letting Oracle acquire you through mergers and acquisition.

review_title: Good, small company atmosphere, but raises and bonuses are rare. New mandate about location in HQ for some positions
job_title: Senior Director, Product Marketing in Raleigh, NC
pros: Smaller company feel and not a lot of bureaucracy or politics given the size (although that might vary from group to group). Great people, experienced, helpful - doing the right thing, not the expeditious thing. Until recently remote working was more common than office working.  Great, very competitive starting salary
cons: Raises and bonuses are rare. (Although I did get a raise after 3 years - people often go much longer without raises or bonuses.). New SVP is pushing for everyone to be located at HQ (or within low percentage for now) - so layoffs going on.

pros: It's a household name, so future employers will be interested in seeing the name Oracle on your resume, but work here only if you have exhausted all other options or you have a great plan to extract as much experience as you can out of this place and leave as soon as soon as you find a role at a workplace for humans with hearts.
cons: Oracle has no heart. You know this. You've read the articles and seen the interviews. Oracle is all about winning. If you have a heart, you will not survive here. Employees that survive here will stop at nothing to do what they have to do to keep their jobs -- namely throw everyone else under the bus. And it's all about survival at Oracle. Managers love to pit co-workers against each other to extract the highest performance from them. It's literally survival of the fittest. There is no such thing as teamwork. Co-workers will not help each other in any way because it means helping the "competition."

review_title: Was once a great place, now a sales graveyard
pros:
EXPENSES!! 

Some wonderful colleagues

Pay new hires well

If you get lucky, commission can be good but it is probably 1 in 50 chance

No stress other than not making money

Impossible to be fired

Good benefits
cons:
Where to start ..

- inexperienced front line managers with zero ability to add value to complex opportunities. Have made so many awful management hires

- upper management sits in the UK and manage by bullying and fear

- 2 people smashing their targets and everyone else on 0%

- give people 20 accounts but want people to have 100 interactions per week. People just make up the stuff to add to crm

- not a sales job, basically an old school marketing role

- all the good sales people have left, nobody ever comes back! 

- the atmosphere is toxic as the majority hate the place

- now bad for your CV

- so disconnected from what prospects and customers want

- management treat employees like school children, it is embarrassing

- going back to the 80s on approach to working. At the desk from 9 to 5.30pm, no working from home etc

review_title: No better place to work to deepen your knowledge & skills of a specific Oracle product or niche, but...
pros: The training and skills you obtain during your time at Oracle are top notch. You get the chance to do the most technically advanced implementations of the particular Oracle product line you were hired for. Within Oracle consulting, you're also able to move around in your product family vertical (BI), and work on various systems (OBIEE, ODI, Hyperion).
cons: The constant re-orgs make it tough to have a relationship with your manager. Also, many projects within consulting don't have the same collaborative feel as our partner consulting firms (Accenture, Deloitte, IBM).

review_title: Life at Oracle CGBU (Oracle Communications Global Business Unit) Hyderabad
pros:
- Good Work Life balance
- Excellent Branding
- Excellent US Counterpart (Technical)
- Luckily my Manger is a very good person (Technically and at Understanding team concerns, but he is helpless, coz Problem is from Very Senior Management)
cons:
- Not the real "Oracle" culture these days, Culture from various acquired companies exists.
- No Salary Hikes for last 3 years
- Work culture is getting worse day by day
- Careless HR
- Working for a non revenue generating team @ oracle is the biggest SIN anyone can do. But while joining they promise many things and shows you a virtual paradise.
- Interview process is so tough as if they are Hiring you for System Programming.
- Answer from Senior VP when asked for any plans for Salary Hike: "Feel lucky that you people weren't laid off"

review_title: It's a job and nothing more.
pros:
Ability to work from home on occassion.
Decent health and dental benefits.
cons:
After achieving 5 weeks of vacation and 2 weeks of personal time each year at StorageTek (26 years), my paid time off has been cut in half. Only 18 days of vacation per year maximum, and some holidays have been eliminated.

Annual reviews and pay raises are non-existent at Oracle. What you get paid when you started, or in my case, company bought (Sun Microsystems) is the pay you can expect for many years to come. I fully expect to never get a pay increase before I retire in 12 years.

Oracle runs thier businees with the fast food model. Hire people for cheap, never give them a pay raise, and give them incentives to not stay at the company too long. The vacation policy is such an incentive, you get the max 18 days after 3 years, thusly promoting the feeling that you are not wanted around after 7 years.

review_title: You have to dig everything to Gain skills
pros:
1. People have a good attitude and I have met some technically very sound guys here.

2. Not much politics among co-workers (Developers). Can't say the same for managers.

3. If you are good at "self-motivation" then its like extended school. Online library subscriptions will help you in all the ways if you want to learn newer things.
cons:
1. Salary hikes and growth: Man forget about it. Its better you work here for learning things and look for other possibilities in industry. In this area oracle India is like govt jobs. All are same. Whether you work or sleep all the time.

2. The work profile is I don't know very crippled. After completely dedicating yourself to the work, its like you are not gaining anything technically as a developer. Although it depends heavily on person to person.

review_title: You may not have too much of quality work but you will be free from tensions at least
pros:
High pay grades
Supportive Seniors.
Easy work load
Enough time to pursue further education and certification
cons:
Not for ambitious people.
Appraisals are bad - by bad I mean as low as 0%.
They dont support for external certifications and further education.
Almost no onsite opportunity and if its there also forget about saving a single penny.

review_title: It could be worse, but it could also be so much better
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Redwood Shores, CA
pros: Job security, good on-site gym, reasonable timeline expectations, spacious workspaces, free advanced screening of Iron Man/Avenger movies for HQ employees, great health care coverage
cons: Highly political, no growth, too much deadweight, no innovation, no passion, title changes do not come with a bump in pay, salary increases and bonuses are virtually non-existent, hard to compete in hiring against other tech companies

pros:
Work life balance is good
Good sales training curriculum
Great  solutions they offer to customers
Flexible work hours
cons:
Senior Management manage by fear and not via respect for their employees
Pay is average or below average for some roles
Internal conflict between Lines of businesses is getting worse every year and out of control.
Processes and systems hamper and even block the sales process
The office Facilities is extremely poor, stale and outdated. Not sure why they even have a Facilities dept?

job_title: Applications Sales Representative in Reading, England
pros: I met some great people at Oracle, many of whom joined at the same time as myself, unfortunately we ended up bonding over how bad it was to work there.
cons:
I was hired as part of a change in hiring strategy - moving away from re-hiring people who had previously worked at Oracle to bringing in "fresh blood". Unfortunately the new processes to support this new strategy that were discussed during hiring process didn't materialize. 

Little or no interaction from Management - seemed to only be interested in securing their next promotion. 

For a software company their internal systems were abysmal. A 10 year old version of CRM and a HR system that looked like it was from the 1980s. 

I was actually paid the month after I left and when I tried to discuss this with the Oracle Payroll team their response was "are you sure you don't work here?".

job_title: Partner Account Director in London, England
pros: This is a dynamic environment and the people around you are fun to work with and, for the most part, very capable. The range of products and services is absolutely unrivalled in the industry. Unlike many other companies in the, you won't have your targets changed during the year, or next year's target hiked ridiculously just because you had a successful year this year. depending on your own manager, there can be a lot of autonomy.
cons: Salary increases are a concept which seems to have escaped the company (although there is still the opportunity to earn good money). Internal approvals are a nightmare, and the company loves a bit of sibling rivalry. If you can live with that little lot, it's a great place to work.

pros: Very good company to work for. As a Salesperson, you will learn a lot. The company is switching all its departments to Cloud and some nice sales positions are being created like “Territory Manager”.  Don’t expect to go there “on holidays” because work is taugh. This is not AWS where the Cloud sells itself. You will probably start a Territory from scratch and will fight over Oracle’s bad reputation on the markets. This is the “School of Sales” where “You cannot “not learn”! ...is of course you put the amount of effort and energy into the battle. And it’s worth because you can get a decent salary in a place where the cost of life is pretty cheap and where you get 8 months of summer / year.
cons: High pressured environment and sometimes very poor management

review_title: Great place to start your FP&A career
job_title: Lead Financial Analyst in Redwood City, CA
pros:
-Great mangers that are willing to teach
- good support from other teams 
- organized for the most part 
- good systems/dashboards that allow us to create automated reports
- management was very good at prioritizing and pushing back when needed 
- great environment and team culture

review_title: It is huge, with all of the good and bad that come with that.
job_title: Senior Principal Product Manager in Boulder, CO
pros: It's huge, providing it with a lot of resources that allow it to be competitive in a wide range of areas.  The benefits are decent, the compensation seems to be competitive, and for the attitude of most employees is positive.
cons: It's huge, which makes it less efficient than many smaller companies.  Those who work here who say things like "It's like the world's largest startup" haven't worked for a startup lately, if ever.  There are often far to many people involved in a particular task or project, and it's not always clear who is actually in charge.

review_title: Good company to grow with, but exceptional performance is not being recognized.
job_title: Senior Principal Consultant in Reston, VA
pros: The company is large, well respected, and it has a lot of opportunities. It also provides a lot of training opportunities. The benefit is one of the top among companies. If you are single, you pretty much don't need to pay for health insurance out of your pocket.
cons: Salary is not competitive, and they promise you quarterly bonus, which only happened once in the past year. As a consultant, there is no per diem, so you basically having a pay cut. Communication from senior is not sufficient. A lot of time they decide one something and just simply ask you to do it without getting your opinion first... and this is decisions regarding technical solution. Imagine having management people making technical decision.  Good performance is not being recognized. They'll tell you "good job" ... then just move on and keep quiet. This is wrong!

pros:
Talented senior management.
Good experience to put on your resume.
Lack cultural diversity.
Long release cycle, allowing work-life balance at certain stages of the cycle.
cons: Innovation is not encouraged on the ERP side of the business.  Often, product decisions are driven by middle management's own agenda (ie their own job security).   Middle management that comes from a customer support background do not know how to run a product management team.  They have no sense of what "market-driven" product means.  They only know how to run a team like a support organizaton.   The reason why these managers still have a job is because R&D spends most of the time fixing bugs and doing customer support.  What does that say about the product quality?  There is no room for innovation although the company claims to be innovative.   Alignment of strategies within the company is always a problem.

review_title: This is a lifestyle job - steady paychk. Go somewhere else for growth, money, challenge, intellectual satisfaction, ...
pros: Laid back culture, very flexible timings and easy to work from home
cons:
No annual reviews -- your performance is a mystery, as is your bonus, promotion, and salary increases

The easy working culture leads to a sense of complacency that can lead to slacking off, a decline in motivation to develop and maintain market relevant skills, and a general sense of working for the pay check without ever going the extra mile (which is rarely rewarded). The employee loses and the company loses...

Managers do not want their employees to push hard, and if they do, they feel threatened by them. So, they don't want to go the extra mile to grow, and they don't want you to either

Little management accountability for how your performance is determined.

review_title: Potentially a good place to spend a few years (four at most), but think carefully before you join.
job_title: Principal Member of Technical Staff in Redwood City, CA
pros: Superb work-life balance with a very flexible work schedule. Very professional company with competent, professional staff. Great opportunity for a self-starter to learn management and organizational skills.
cons: Hiring process took nine months. Mentors are non-existent. Performance reviews are usually skipped every year, or not taken seriously. Very poor career growth opportunities. Project management skills are very poor across the board. Salary stayed the same the entire time I worked there, even though I outperformed every year - it's not unusual to be underpaid 20-30% after spending a long time at Oracle. Architecture is a decade old - which means few opportunities to learn new technical skills, and any advanced skills you have will atrophy.

pros: High standard products and highly experienced consultants to work with. Organisation consist of a lot of various knowledge on different kind of businesses. Company actively seeks new rising technologies to keep on leading edge.
cons:
Organisation is extremely siloed and has many internally competing technologies and services. This confuse employees and even more the customers.
The company has 5-6 separate customer support and consulting organisations that are loosely coordinated with each others.
This makes people to protect individual business over everything else and this is not the best for the customer and may/has lead to customer dissatisfaction to Oracle as a vendor.
